Project.Title: strategising for sustainability: combating climate change in partnership with indigenous communities in kiribati and samoa
Project.Description:
In 2018, the Presidencies of COP 23/24 launched the Talanoa Dialogue Platform as a strategy for combating climate change, taking their cue from the indigenous Pacific tradition of talanoa: a process of inclusive, participatory and transparent dialogue, to enable decision-making for the collective good. This project uses talanoa methods to engage/empower indigenous communities in Kiribati and Samoa, both of which are experiencing increasingly severe climate change impacts. The project will include a series of workshops involving the sharing of indigenous narratives of environmental change and aspirations for future resilience/adaptation, to inform (i) the production of an environmental strategy game (and accompanying
website/resources) to be used as community education tools; and (ii) reports on health and environmental impacts of climate change to be used to guide resilience and restoration initiatives. All activities and outputs will be co-produced and transdisciplinary in design and execution, integrating knowledge across indigenous and academic communities.
Sponsor.Name: british academy
Scheme.Name: knowledge frontiers: international interdisciplinary research projects
PI.Name: Michelle Keown

Project.Title: climate change policies for people: implementing co-developed water governance and security in the upper atoyac river basin, puebla
Project.Description: Climate change is increasing the need for water governance measures in drought-prone areas. Our previous Newton project focused on understanding the diverse effects of climate change co-developing mitigation and adaptation strategies with local communities (including residents, government institutions and civic organisations) in Puebla. A major priority articulated by these communities was the urgent need for water security and improved water governance. The proposed project aims to deliver impact based on the insights generated by the previous research in the Upper Atoyac River Basin (UATB) by conducting a broader range of stakeholder consultations to co-develop, test, and implement policies for improved water security. We now focus on the whole basin, involving a wider range of data to enable long-term water security that will result in better-managed and more sustainable water resources for the entire basin. Outputs from this work will be transferable to many Global South contexts, where impacts of climate change are increasing human vulnerability in rural and rapidly urbanising communities.

Project.Title: improved phosphorus and eutrophication status assessments for humic lakes in light of climate change pressures and departure from eu directive
Project.Description:
Phosphorus is an essential component of most living organisms but it can also cause excessive growth of algae in surface
waters even when it is present at relatively low concentrations (10s of parts per billion). This process is called
eutrophication and it is a problem because costly management plans often need to be actioned to restore the quality of the
water, e.g. to achieve good or high status as currently required under the European Union Water Framework Directive.
Recently, it has been observed that phosphorus concentrations in surface waters, especially lakes in upland, organic-rich
catchments, are increasing and this is being linked to climatic change. Firstly, transport from the surrounding catchment is
being enhanced by increased loss of dissolved organic carbon and phosphorus, which is associated with the organic
carbon via bridging links with iron, is co-transferred to the lake waters. Secondly, internal loading of phosphorus in the lake
bottom sediments is leading to increased concentrations in lake waters because of climatic change. This is because
increased periods of stormy weather leads to greater re-suspension of bottom sediments and transfer of phosphorus from
the near-surface sediment porewaters (the water directly in contact with the sediment). It also occurs because there is
increased stratification even in shallow lakes which are a common feature in many upland, organic-rich areas and this can
mean that poorly oxygenated sediments are in more frequent contact with the bottom lake waters. These conditions are
conducive to transfer of phosphorus from the sediment into the lake water.
Although it is known that soluble reactive phosphorus (orthophosphate) is the main form which can be taken up by the
bloom-forming organisms in the water, total phosphorus is the currently used model parameter to determine water quality.
With total phosphorus concentrations increasing, it is likely that more and more lakes will not achieve the required good or
high status. However, we don't know how much of this additional phosphorus is available to aquatic organisms. For
example, if most of it is unavailable, management plans may be enacted where they are not needed.
From an initial screen of the literature, there is a large body of published information from studies in many parts of the world
and from many different disciplines that needs to be critically evaluated and drawn together to address this knowledge gap.
The main aim of this proposal is to carry out a systematic review of the literature and to draw together evidence that will
improve our understanding of the (i) processes controlling the transport of phosphorus from catchment soil to lake water,
and (ii) how phosphorus is cycled from bottom sediments tot lake water, under the pressure of climate change, in organic
rich regions of the world.
The outcomes of this systematic review of the literature will be to inform future research on how climate change will affect
(i) the forms of phosphorus and its associations with natural organic matter in catchment runoff and lake waters and (ii) the
availability of different forms of phosphorus for uptake by aquatic organisms in highly coloured lakes located in organic-rich
regions of the world. This will ultimately facilitate development of more accurate, climate change-proof models for use in
assessing the phosphorus concentration of lakes in carbon-rich zones will be of tremendous direct benefit to the UK's
environmental regulators (e.g. the Environment Agency, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency) and policy makers
(e.g. DEFRA) and to their equivalent organisations in other countries.

Project.Title: on the politics of hope and fear: utopian tendencies in current debates on climate change
Project.Description:
This transdisciplinary project contributes to the critical recovery of utopian thinking and acting by analyzing a major challenge that not only the UK, but the whole world faces: climate change. Climate change is a "wicked problem" for which no simple solution can be found. The project asks what future horizon academics, artists and activists imagine when they grapple with climate change. Precisely because the future is radically uncertain and full of risky choices, academics, artists and activists cannot but conjure alternative scenarios some hopeful, others fearful ofwhat is to come. The project's key assumption is that engaging with wicked problems, both in academia and in society at large, inevitably gives rise to utopian thinking and acting. I conceptualize utopianism broadly, as a flexible method, rather than a static end state, comprising both eutopian
and dystopian visions of the future. Furthermore, utopianism contains three dimensions, which deserve equal attention: social
and political theory, art and social movements. Equipped with this multidimensional notion of utopianism, the project pursues two objectives: (1) to excavate the main eutopian and dystopian tendencies in contemporary discussions about climate change; and (2) to work towards a new politics of the future that avoids the pitfalls of both fatalism and wishful thinking. My methodology will be grounded in social and political theory, yet also include approaches from cultural studies and the social sciences so as to paint a holistic picture of the problem under scrutiny. An important output of the project apart from the academic knowledge production will be creation of a deliberative space (the Utopia Lab) in which academics, artists and activists come together to collaboratively reflect on their ideas and practice.
School: School of Social and Political Science
Sponsor.Name: independent social research foundation, the
Scheme.Name: fellowship
PI.Name: Mathias Thaler

Project.Title: on the politics of hope and fear: utopian tendencies in current debates on climate change and racism
Project.Description:
UTOPIA is a transdisciplinary project that contributes to the critical recovery of utopian thinking and acting by comparatively analyzing responses to two major challenges that the world presently faces: climate change and racism. Despite their differences, climate change and racism share features that lend them to a comparative study: due to their complexity, multi-causality and scope, they constitute “wicked problems” for which no simple solutions can be found. The project asks what kind of future academics, artists and activists imagine when they grapple with climate change and racism. My key premise is that, precisely because the future is uncertain and risky, engaging with wicked problems inevitably gives rise to competing utopian visions – some hopeful, others fearful – of what is to come. I conceptualize utopianism broadly, as a flexible method, rather than a static end state, comprising both eu-topian (better) and
dys-topian (worse) images of the future. UTOPIA proposes to track utopianism in three domains – political theory, arts and social movements – in order to pursue twin objectives: (1) to excavate the main eutopian and dystopian tendencies in current controversies around climate change and racism; and (2) to develop a new account of radical transformation that eschews defeatist fatalism and wishful thinking. My methodology will be grounded in political theory, yet also utilize approaches from cultural studies and the social sciences to offer a hermeneutical, genealogical and critical perspective. Beyond the scientific output, I will create deliberative spaces (the Utopia Labs) where academics, artists and activists can collaboratively reflect on their ideas and practices. UTOPIA’s findings thus aim to improve our understanding of how we (should) reflect on an uncertain, risky future, which will in turn enable theorists and practitioners engaging with climate change and racism to productively interrogate their own work.
School: School of Social and Political Science

Project.Title: pathways to resilience: exploring interdisciplinary co-produced narratives in response to climate change in the marshall islands
Project.Description:
This is an interdisciplinary pilot project investigating ways to build resilience to climate change impacts in the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI). The core of the project involves a series of workshops, to be held in RMI in February 2017, in which the project team will engage RMI governmental, NGO, educational & community stakeholders in discussions about: 
(a) what is known about RMI's climate change challenges & needs 
(b) what strategies of resilience to climate change impacts already exist within the community, or could be developed in the future.  
Small islands developing states (SIDS), and particularly low-lying coral atoll nations such as the RMI, are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change & sea level rise. RMI faces a variety of environmental hazards (such as typhoons, droughts & flooding), and rising sea levels will increase the risk of erosion, wave inundation & food/fresh water shortages. The RMI government is already planning for the likely relocation of populations on islands such as Kili, a reef platform island that is experiencing increasingly severe flooding, and the trauma of relocation will be compounded by the fact that Kili's residents are an already-displaced population originating from Bikini Atoll, the site of multiple US nuclear bomb tests during the Cold War era.

Partners.Detail: EidgenoessischeTechnische Hochschule Zuerich,Collaborator,Industry,SWITZERLAND|Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique,Collaborator,Industry,FRANCE|ONF International,Collaborator,Government,FRANCE

Project.Title: landscapes (france) as carbon sinks co-design phase - land ecosystem in france - climate kic 19
Project.Description:
Landscape Ecosystem in France
Deep Demonstrations are intended to offer a showcase of a zero-net emissions, a resilient future and highlight the ways that innovation across whole systems can unlock the change we now so desperately need. We want to move toward unleashing exponential change through a systems approach.
The work of INRA, WUR, AgriCircle, the University of Edinburgh and ONFI will be responsible for collecting and curating the learnings and insights from across the different areas in an aggregated way and will be responsible for co-designing the Deep Demonstration "Turning Landscapes from Carbon Sources to Carbon Sinks" together with EIT Climate-KIC community. Specifically, the below described tasks and activities will aim to help on co-ordination, implementation and embed the tightly designed and iterative first stage of a four-stage process developed for Deep Demonstrations; namely the Intent with a view to understand the next phase of Frame. Learnings from the co-design approach will be used to roll out systems innovation as-a-service.
INTENT
is the set-up phase of the Deep Demonstrations process. It is designed to establish directionality, to scope needs, vision and objectives for systemic change and ultimately to agree to work together on a Deep Demonstration innovation portfolio focused on catalysing radical transformation of systems.
The key ac􀆟vi􀆟es in this part of the workplan are to:
• Agree who we will work with, on what and why
• Build a shared understanding of innovation as a point of difference that is non-linear, focused on accelerating learning and designed to surface opportunities for catalysing change in systems
• Explore, identify and agree the systems to work on and a vision of structural change to work towards
• Arrive at a joint understanding and agreement as to shared objectives, outcomes, needs, 􀆟me frames and ways of working.
FRAME
is about defining the field for innovation action, building understanding about how innovation might achieve the vision for transformation. This phase is made up of iterative steps that articulate why we want to deploy innovation, where, what to leverage and where to position ourselves to test for emerging, breakthrough
possibilities as well as scaling potential. A portfolio brief that emerges from this stage provides a frame of reference for learning and generating intelligence from innovation.
The key activities as part of this workplan include:
• Articulate where to direct innovation effort and w hy - in relation to what - what to leverage, how and why
• Identify cause and effect relationships, dependencies and opportunities to look for breakthrough possibilities
• Look beyond edges of known to usual actors, outliers, positive deviants and generating opportunities to move beyond defaults, core assumptions and biases
• Identify who could do it, why and where is appropriate
• Framing a portfolio hypothesis described in terms of inn ovation positions.
OBJECTIVES
The main objective of this co-design work is to i) engage highly motivated (a) problem owner(s); ii) identify an initial diverse portfolio of positions, in order to work
thereafter on bold and uncommon experiments; iii) learn lessons from embedding this process which can be used to catalyse further transformation.  Overaching objectives, specific to the needs of the French landscape ecosystem, will be to change organic carbon management in rural landscapes, by exploring with
possibly Planet A as a problem-owner how to increase carbon storage.

Project.Title: charter: drivers and feedbacks of changes in arctic terrestrial biodiversity
Project.Description:
CHARTER aims to advance state-of-the-art (SOTA) knowledge on Arctic biodiversity change and social-ecological systems
(SES) on four critical fronts: i) Feedbacks: To understand transitions in vegetation cover, energy balance and cryospheric
change at centennial, decadal, and present-day time scales; ii) SES and biodiversity: To understand the effects of
biodiversity changes on indigenous/local communities and traditional livelihoods, e.g. reindeer herding; iii) Modelling: To
integrate biochemical/permafrost soil carbon exchange, sea ice and albedo into an Earth System Model (ESM), and
incorporate these into the latest Arctic Regional Climate modeling efforts; and iv) Policy: To develop strategies supporting
Arctic communities with co-benefits and synergies between adaptation, mitigation and policy implications. To accomplish
these, CHARTER combines expertise from Earth System sciences, biodiversity indices and SES research. CHARTER is an
ambitious effort to advance SOTA modelling of 21st century Arctic change with major socio-economic implications and
feedbacks for the Cryosphere. We bring together our strongly participatory approaches that incorporate indigenous/local
communities’ ways of knowing regional changes with SOTA research on circumpolar climate dynamics and long-term
palaeoecological studies. CHARTER collates and processes truly transdisciplinary quantitative and qualitative empirical
datasets for a holistic view that can be modeled. Arctic residents and stakeholders work alongside scientists to identify risks
and viable adaptation strategies in relation to projected changes and future resilience in Arctic SESs. CHARTER combines
natural sciences with ESM and participatory approaches to leverage the untapped potential for wild ungulate and livestock
management to regulate global climate feedbacks through biogeoengineering. CHARTER’s results will lead to new tools and
data for implementing sustainable strategies and establish public dialogue on the Arctic.

Project.Title: prehistoric egypt: conservation, heritage tourism and global significance
Project.Description:
The prehistoric sites of Egypt are of immense importance, not only for their value in understanding the various stages that
went into making the great civilization of ancient Egypt, but in their own right within the global history of humanity. In Egypt
prehistory remains largely ignored when compared with the Dynastic era, and there is a near total lack of opportunity for
current and future generations to engage with the knowledge of how civilization emerged in Egypt, and to assert their
importance in heritage tourism.
School: School of History, Classics and Archaeology
Sponsor.Name: arts and humanities research council
Scheme.Name: large grants
PI.Name: Joanne Rowland
Name_of_Call: Cultural Heritage and Development in Egypt 5 September 2017

Project.Title: christianity and nature conservation in britain (circa 1800-1920)
Project.Description:
The roles of philosophical ideas, doctrine, ethics and spiritual experience in the origins of nature conservation and
environmentalism have been extensively investigated in North America, but they been subjected to much less scholarly
investigation in Britain and are therefore less well understood. This is particularly so in the case of religious beliefs since
virtually all the extant historical work on the origins of conservation movements in the UK neglects the role of religion
entirely. The received narrative is that nature conservation movements, including movements for public access to open
spaces or 'commons', and movements to conserve 'wild' places or special or 'sublime' landscapes from industrial
developments, such as railways and reservoirs, were driven principally from secular philosophical influences and sources.
Principal among these are said to be humanist and utilitarian philosophy, early scientific investigations of botanists,
biologists and ecologists and the growth of democratic movements and civil society in nineteenth century Britain.
With this research we will provide an accurate and informed historical account of the respective roles of philosophical and
religious beliefs, spiritual experience, and ethics in the origins of British nature conservation and early environmental
movements. Through original primary source research into the principal nineteenth and twentieth century figures in British
environmentalism, we will investigate the role of both philosophical and religious beliefs and institutions, spiritual practices,
and ethics in shaping the leading initiators of conservation and environmental campaigns in Britain in the period of their
birth and infancy from 1800 - 1920.
Our initial investigation will focus on the cultural origins of five specific claims which underwrote the environmental activism
of British nature romantics and conservation pioneers:
1. That human experience of certain 'natural spaces' is morally uplifting and spiritually redemptive, a claim associated with
the idea of the 'sublime', and the belief that sentiments such as awe, peacefulness and wellbeing are provoked by practices
including climbing, walking or riding in certain kinds of mountainous, riverine and forested landscapes (Brady 2015). This
claim was central to the efforts of conservation pioneers to facilitate public access to wild and beautiful places - such as the
Lake District and the Trossachs - as common shared spaces which are protected from industrial or urban development,
and private enclosure (Ranlett, 1998).
2. That the religious ideal of stewardship should inform human uses of natural habitats and protection of common spaces.
Attfield (1992) and Berry (2007) marshal evidence of the Christian religious background of this concept and its potential
role in promoting intergenerational conservation of soils, species and habitats. We will investigate the role of this concept,
and associated practices, in the origins of British environmentalism.
3. That uses of the environment ought to be subjected to critical scrutiny as to whether they will enhance its beauty and
fecundity for future generations or not.
4. That the environment ought to be available for common shared use and not confined to privileged or wealthy uses.
5. That there are natural limits to human uses of the environment arising from nature as a divinely ordered realm which
imposes certain duties of prudence and restraint on its human users.
Sponsor.Name: arts and humanities research council
Scheme.Name: research grant - standard
PI.Name: Michael Northcott

Project.Title: the knust campus drawings conservation project – preserving and recording west african modernism
Project.Description:
This application is to request for funds to enable the KNUST historic campus drawings be digitized, and a set of oral histories be recorded from those who were involved in their production and subsequent campus design in the 1950s-60s. These pilot records; would be made available to local researchers in Africa and
internationally (through the BL website), whilst the material artefacts would be preserved and placed with the KNUST University Archive. The application would also include funding for the training of a KNUST librarian/archivist in the handling and preservation of historic drawings and other artefacts related to the collection.
Sponsor.Name: british library
Scheme.Name: general scheme
PI.Name: Ola Uduku

Project.Title: gis-based conservation assessment methodology for modern gardens in china and uk
Project.Description:
This scheme is jointly funded by the RS and the NSFC (National Natural Science Foundation of China) with each country receiving its own share form their respective funder. It covers travel, subsistence and other direct costs for collaboration activities.

This research aims to foster scientific cooperation in the field of the integration of new methodologies for conservation documentation, assessment, and management of the heritage of Modern gardens in China and the UK. The Chinese and UK teams will share their expertise and collaborate to identify the
values and cultural significance of Modern gardens, and work towards developing a new GIS-based assessment methodology for their conservation. Such a methodology could be further adapted to other types of heritage and thus contribute more widely to the development of conservation-related tools for both
academic research and practical management by the respective heritage agencies in China and the UK.
Sponsor.Name: royal society
Scheme.Name: international exchanges
PI.Name: Ruxandra-Iulia Stoica

Project.Title: earliest egypt: conservation, management, valorisation and capacity building
Project.Description:
This collaborative project supports research and innovative capacity
building in Egypt for Cultural Heritage Management (CHM), to
preserve, protect and disseminate information on Egypt's most
invisible and neglected heritage: prehistoric and early historic sites.
This collaboration is conceived at professional, student and local
community scales, with the implementation of Information
Technology (IT) in site management reaching out to all stakeholders.
School: School of History, Classics and Archaeology

Scheme.Name: newton institutional links grant

Project.Title: air pollution, housing and respiratory tract infections in children: national birth cohort study (picnic)
Project.Description:
The aim of this study is to determine the contribution of air pollution exposure during pregnancy and adverse housing conditions (including overcrowding and damp/mould) to hospital admissions for respiratory tract infections (RTIs) in children under 5 years old in England and Scotland. RTIs are the most common reason for hospital admission in among under-5s in the UK, with 5% of children admitted annually. The relative contribution of air pollution exposure during pregnancy and adverse housing conditions to RTI admissions in young children is unclear, and has not been assessed in a UK context.
We will analyse administrative data birth cohorts including all children born in England between 2005 and 2014, and
Scotland between 1997 and 2019; data from 8 million children in total. These cohorts are constructed by linking data from birth and death registration, maternity systems, and maternal and child longitudinal hospital records. We will further link these cohorts to individual-level Census 2011 data on overcrowding, housing tenure and socio-economic position, and small-area level data on air pollution and building characteristics, to meet our study objectives. These are to:
1) Estimate the association between long-term exposure to ambient AP exposure during pregnancy and the rate of RTI admissions in infancy
2) Derive exposure variables indicating adverse housing conditions (including overcrowding, indoor air pollution, and damp/mould) and estimate the association between housing exposures and infant RTI admissions
3) Based on the outcomes of analyses for objectives 1) - 3), estimate the relative contribution of AP and adverse housing conditions on infant RTI admissions
4) Estimate the relative contribution of AP exposure during pregnancy and adverse housing conditions on RTI admissions in
children less than five years old
5) Establish the enhanced, linked administrative data birth cohorts as research resources for maternal and child health

Drawing on the expertise of our multidisciplinary study team (in health data science, environmental epidemiology, statistics,
geography, buildings engineering and clinical paediatrics), we will exploit the rich longitudinal clinical data for mothers and babies, detailed Census information on socio-economic position, novel linkages to small-area level data.

Our results will inform parents, national and local government, the National Health Service and voluntary sector organisations of the relative contribution of adverse housing conditions and air pollution to common but distressing hospital admissions in young children. The project will inform public health interventions, and empower stakeholders to take action to improve the environments in which children grow up. Our work will also lead to the establishment of national administrative data birth cohorts for England and Scotland, with rich socio-economic and environmental data, which will be
made available to other researchers.

Project.Title: lung megakaryocyte and platelet function in response to air pollution exposure
Project.Description: Blood clotting is needed to stop bleeding after injury. However, excessive clotting is harmful in many lung and heart diseases. Inhalation of pollutants increases blood clotting, and this is likely to play an important part in the high levels of heart disease and early death linked to air pollution. Platelets are blood cells that are made in the bone marrow and have a key role in blood clotting. Recently it has been shown that a large proportion of platelets are made in the lung. This study will investigate the role of platelets from the lung to see if these cells are responsible for the blood clotting associated with exposure to air pollution.

Project.Title: reduction of landfill gas and leachate pollution from solid waste landfill via implementation of 2-dimensional nanomaterial mixed matrix membranes (mmms) to foster a green and sustainable environment
Project.Description:
Industrialization, rapid urbanization and population explosion in recent decades have 
increased solid waste generation that creates substantial challenges on solid waste 
management. In India, only 43 metric tons of solid waste is collected annually out of 
which 27.9% waste are treated and 72% waste are dumped in landfill. Landfill gas (LFG) 
is generated owing to the decomposition of solid waste. LFG contains greenhouse 
gases (GHGs) and methane (CH4). LFG emission to the atmosphere without proper 
treatment could increase greenhouse gas emission and has a great impact on global 
climate change. Percolation of water via landfill generates leachate which contains 
complex organic and inorganic contaminants. Leachate treatment is needed for 
protecting subsurface and surface water resources from deterioration. In analogous, the 
effect of solid waste is interconnected with the air, water pollution and spreading of 
diseases.  
The concern on solid waste alone is not enough but focusing direction on LFG and 
leachate management would alleviate pollution that sound well in developing 
sustainable environment for mankind. Among numerous technologies, membrane 
technology is one of the most energy-efficient alternatives for separating LFG and 
leachate treatment. Membrane technology has smaller footprint, low energy 
consumption and eco-friendly than the conventional treatment. The idea of this project is 
to efficiently separate LFG (CO2 and CH4) and leachate using membrane technology. 
Joint collaboration (India and UK)  would aid in transferring skills and technology that 
would promote novel solutions to the existing problem, foster safe environment and 
anticipated outcome would meets the constraints of the scientific, engineering and 
community members. Further, managing LFG and leachate using membrane technology 
would render significance to various environmental developments such as promote 
energy (CO2 and CH4 separation), sustainable resources for mankind, reduce climate 
change finally reduces impact of solid waste disposed at landfill.

Project.Title: cleaning the ocean: understanding transport of plastic pollution by waves
Project.Description:
accumulated in the world’s oceans with harmful effects on marine wildlife and potentially to human health. Although the scale
of the problem is beginning to be recognized by governments and international organisations, effective policies have yet to be
established to restrict the inflow of plastic debris into the ocean. With plastic particles expected to decay over time scales of
hundreds or thousands of years, it is clear that plastic pollution of the oceans is a persistent, long-term global challenge (UN
Sustainable Development Goal 14.1). Ambitious, innovative engineering solutions to clean the oceans of their plastic pollution
are being proposed by organizations such as the Ocean Cleanup Foundation. Through a combination of offshore and
environmental engineering, fluid mechanics and physical oceanography, this research aims to determine the fundamental
mechanisms of transport and dispersion of plastic pollution in realistic, stochastic seas. Deliverables are simple analytical
expressions for transport and dispersion of particles as functions of the properties of the particle (i.e. size and density), the sea
state (i.e. significant wave height, wave period, spectral bandwidth and directional spreading) and other physical parameters (i.e.
background density stratification, local water depth and the Coriolis parameter). These analytical expressions will be derived
from the governing equations using asymptotic methods, and validated experimentally through collaboration with the
universities of Plymouth (UK) and Auckland (New Zealand), as well as other partners. The proposed research is unique in its
application of a combination of fundamental fluid mechanics, modelling of stochastic processes, identification of user-friendly
solutions using asymptotic methods and experimental validation to address a global challenge. Impact will be achieved through
collaboration with the International Marine Litter Research Unit (Plymouth), Edinburgh Designs Ltd (a UK SME) and the Ocean
Cleanup Foundation.

1 - Civil, Construction & Environmental

Ocean pollution, (micro-)plastic, mixing, pollutant dispersion, Stokes drift, ocean waves,

Project.Title: air infrastructures: sociotechnical connections and particulate pollution in latin america, asia, and europe
Project.Description:
This multiregional study analyses air as an infrastructure that connects pollutants, as well as bodies, institutions, and technologies, in ways that are saturated with local meanings and
national politics, but carry global consequences for economic, environmental, and public health. Air pollution combines with other aspects of the social and physical environment to
create a disproportionate disease burden in populations with minimal capacity to protect themselves and influence policy decisions.

Project.Title: synthesis and characterisation of novel porous materials for greenhouse gas capture
Project.Description: The focus of my project is to make the capture of the greenhouse gas CO2 more efficient. Aerogel made with the help of nanotechnology and supplemented with organic functional groups can interact with CO2 in dilute gases and attach to them. This way, the CO2 can be extracted from the air and would not be free-flowing. In the past, researchers have focused on a different type of aerogel, which is not regenerated as efficiently. The organic aerogel needs to be improved, as only the organic groups attached to the outside layer are attaching to CO2. I want to find a way of diffusing the CO2 into the aerogel so that the organic groups encapsulated in the gel can interact with the molecule and stop it from polluting the air.

Project.Title: greenland's marine terminating glaciers: ocean forcing of glacier retreat and sea level response
Project.Description:
Transfer of heat and water between the Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS) and ocean occurs through marine terminating glaciers, their fjord systems and the adjacent continental shelf. GrIS contribution to sea level is increasing due to greater surface and submarine melt and iceberg calving. Current understanding based on observations at several key locations around the GrIS underpins predicted decadal changes in the GrIS and the North Atlantic. However, there remain significant scientific challenges, particularly relating to the exchange of heat and freshwater through the fjords connecting the GrIS and ocean.
Two-way exchange is crucial to the workings of both these systems, and a poor understanding of this transfer and an inability to effectively incorporate it into Earth system models hinders our ability to project future sea level and climate scenarios. Green-MTG will: (1) obtain novel observations from the Gothåbsfjord system in southwest Greenland and the adjacent shelf; (2) develop a new universal ice/ocean fjordic transfer function for inclusion in climate models; (3) use this new universal transfer function to provide improved projections of changes in ice sheet mass loss, sea level and regional oceanic circulation.
The project comprises a program of seasonally resolved observations using autonomous ocean gliders, autonomous underwater vehicles, satellite remote sensing, and a field program using the UK polar research vessel RRS Sir David Attenborough, in coordination with partners in Greenland. It will also utilise databases containing historic data to augment and contextualise the contemporary observations. The project is built around three work packages addressing the marine terminating ice sheet, the fjord and the ocean.
WP1: "ice marginal processes and freshwater fluxes" will determine the volume and location of freshwater inputs to the fjords at the grounded submarine ice margin. These are crucial as they drive the fjord circulation which brings warm water from the ocean into the fjord, where it melts icebergs and the submarine ice margin. The rate of sediment deposition at the ice margin will be determined as this can, if sufficiently large, stabilise the ice margin.
WP2: "Fjordic exchanges and ice sheet loss" will develop a fjord model expressed as a simple transfer function with location-tuneable constants - modifying the inflow of warm ocean water and the outflow of glacial melt water and icebergs.
This will provide a unique bridge between ocean and ice sheet models. The functional development will draw on data from
a year-long glider mission to investigate the variability in ocean water at the entrance to Gothåbsfjord, and combine this with seasonally resolved observations by our Greenland partners and new observations in the fjord from the research cruise. A key aspect of the transfer function is that it links the freshwater inputs developed in WP1 with the ocean forcing investigated in WP3 thereby quantifying heat delivery to the ice margin via an efficient algorithm suitable for inclusion in climate models allowing projections of glacier retreat and ice sheet mass loss.
WP3: "Regional oceanographic connectivity and feedback" will determine the spatial variability in cross shelf exchange
(ocean-shelf-fjord) from Cape Farewell to Davis Strait along west Greenland. This knowledge provides the ocean forcing
for the transfer function in WP2 whereby heat enters the fjord. It will employ a multi-disciplinary approach using a 12-month
mission of two gliders, remote sensing of sea surface conditions, and wind patterns, to characterise water property modification between the shelf break and fjord mouth. These data will be used to ground-truth high resolution numerical modelling experiments which allow boundary currents, shelf edge exchange of water masses, iceberg drift and melt, and their combined effects on the heat and freshwater budgets to be resolved at meaningful spatial scales.

Project.Title: environmental storytelling and energy transitions
Project.Description: ‘Environmental Storytelling and Energy Transitions’ will be the first book to examine the relationship between British literary cultures and decarbonisation. Drawing on my experience as a literary scholar and as a regulatory analyst in the renewable energy sector, I will explore how writers are developing new forms and genres to make a range of potential energy transitions imaginatively tangible. I will conduct original research into how writers are using speculative fiction and narrative nonfiction, in particular, to track, imaginatively animate, and even influence energy transitions. I will also argue that critical analysis of literature and energy culture demands a multidisciplinary approach, using methodologies from the social sciences, as well as literary criticism. Combining literary analysis of my chosen texts with oral history research into energy transitions, I will place literary texts into conversation with a range of contemporary energy cultures, from industry to activism.

Project.Title: spatial and environmental medical humanities
Project.Description: The purpose of the Spatial and Environmental Medical Humanities Network is to identify methodologies, sources, and questions in order to illuminate the importance of physical spaces and environments involved in health/care, clinical encounters, and experiences of illness and treatment. The Network’s focus contributes to the impetus of the ‘second wave’ of critical medical humanities, with conscious focus on objects and non-human presences and the places and spaces containing or shaping health experiences.

Project.Title: environmental sustainability and economic cooperation in the longue duree: a comparative approach to locality, history and development
Project.Description:
In recent years there have been multiple challenges to the existing understandings of economic growth and the environment, and the difficulties in balancing economic, social, and environmental goals. There is growing awareness of the challenges posed by climate change and the depletion of natural resources, and the urgency of developing balanced approaches for future economic growth and environmental sustainability. At the same time, the uneven economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic and the lingering repercussions of the 2008 financial crisis continue to raise important questions regarding social and economic equality, how to manage access to financial resources, and how to protect the agency and opportunity of individuals within a globalized economic system dominated by large multinational corporations. This network seeks to explore and bridge these two issues of our times - sustainable development and economic inequality. In particular, we seek to explore diverse models of economic cooperation and sustainable resource management through comparative and interdisciplinary engagement with historians, anthropologists, political scientists, geographers, and sociologists, with the goal of developing future research agenda into sustainable growth that can incorporate a diverse range of economic, environmental, and social objectives.

Contemporary environmental and economic crises highlight the importance of incorporating a humanistic approach to growth and development that brings to the fore sustainable and equitable patterns of resource management. As such, this network brings together humanities and social science researchers in order to explore the historical and cultural contexts surrounding diverse models of economic cooperation and resource management. In this way, we seek to provoke new understandings of sustainable development, both past and present, while also fostering new collaborations across disciplines and regions in order to highlight the significance of the social and cultural context of sustainable growth. In particular, we seek to prompt new insights and comparative studies into sustainable growth through the example of the Korean kye - a type of organization that has been used to manage a wide range of resources throughout Korean history including forests, fishery rights, education, and financial resources, to name just a few. By bringing examples of Korean kye organizations over time into dialogue with comparative models of economic cooperation and sustainable development from other regions, we aim to generate new directions for future research into alternative models of growth and economic
activity.

Overall, this project will search for links between historically specific examples and contemporary case studies in order to develop a deeper understanding of the interrelations between environmentally sustainable growth and social and economic equality. We will create an environment for interdisciplinary conversations where researchers can learn from one another, while using discussions of kye as a vehicle to expand the understanding of sustainable development and create a foundation for future collaborative research. Throughout this process, we will foster strong ties between researchers in both South Korea and the United Kingdom by hosting a programme of visiting research fellowships and international workshops and conferences that will not only provide a valuable contribution to academic knowledge but also support researchers - especially early career researchers - to develop future research and international collaborations.

Project.Title: improving plant resistance to environmental stress by targeting deubiquitinases
Project.Description: Plants are essential to sustain life on earth, providing us with food, oxygen and consumer materials we use every day. Human activities have led to the current trend in global warming that seriously threatens plants around the world. Combined with a rapidly growing population, global food security is at risk in the coming decades. More extreme and unpredictable weather events are frequently exposing plants to a variety of stressful environments including fluctuating temperatures, drought, flooding and lack of nutrients. In order to survive it is critical that plants efficiently sense and respond to these damaging stresses. When plants detect stress, they quickly adjust the amount of proteins that are made or destroyed inside cells. This ensures that proteins involved in responding to the particular stress take priority to efficiently prepare the plant for damage limitation. Deubiquitinases are enzymes that control protein destruction and have gathered attention as potential drug targets due to their involvement in many human diseases and disorders. Despite intensive research in animals, our understanding of plant deubiquitinases remains relatively obscure. My previous work has discovered that certain deubiquitinases play important roles in plant responses to different stresses. However, identifying the complete repertoire of stress-responsive deubiquitinases is required if we are to fully harness the potential of these enzymes as targets to improve plant stress-resistance. My proposed research will address this and open doors to future methodologies for increasing crop resilience in the face of a rapidly changing climate.

Project.Title: rethinking reparations for african enslavement as cultural, spiritual and environmental repair
Project.Description:
This project is based on a series of meetings held in the UK and internationally with community-based, activist organisations and university-based researchers as part of an AHRC research networking project (2017-19) linked to the UN International Decade for People of African Descent (IDPAD, 2015-24) [Reparations for Slavery: From Theory to Praxis, AH/P007074/1]. In this project, we worked closely with two community-based organisations (Pan-Afrikan Reparations Coalition in Europe, UK, and Association Panafricaine pour une réparation globale de l'esclavage, Benin) to create an International Network of Scholars and Activists for Afrikan Reparations (INOSAAR). Our events concentrated on understanding the meaning of reparation and reparative justice from African community perspectives and on finding creative ways to heal the longstanding legacies of African enslavement. We highlighted a lack of research into models of reparation that seek to heal the crimes of the past through cultural, spiritual and environmental means. We noted, in particular, that existing reparative models tend to focus on top-down, state-led approaches that favour the use of the international law courts and monetary repayments. Conversely, we identified the equal importance of bottom-up, community-led models focused on repairing the loss of African culture and spirituality among African descended communities. 

From these findings, we identified two strategic areas for further development and funding, which have yet to receive the attention they deserve within global debates on reparations. The first relates to 'rematriation'; meaning the process by which the descendants of those who were forcibly displaced from Africa as a result of European-led enslavement return culturally and spiritually to the African continent. The second relates to 'planet repairs'; meaning the ways in which the struggle for reparative justice is linked to ongoing concerns with climate change and environmental justice.

Project.Title: isp19:environmental stress and telomere attrition; does an enriched post-natal environment have a protective effect on telomere length?
Project.Description:
Rapid or excessive telomere shortening during cell division is highly associated with both physiological and mental illness. Due to the role of inflammatory processes in diseases associated with telomere shortening, and correlations between adverse experience and telomere length, it is hypothesised that this is driven by a low level inflammatory feedback loop catalysed by an outside stressor1. 

Numerous studies have investigated the effects of early life stressors on telomere shortening, but little has been done on the effect of positive experiences on telomere dynamics; this study would be the first of its kind in pigs. In our previous work in pigs we have shown a reduced neuroinflammatory profile in juvenile pigs housed in an enriched environment compared to a standard commercial environment. We would suggest that if telomere shortening is related to inflammatory feedback, we will expect pigs housed in enriched environments to experience less telomere shortening relative to those in barren commercial conditions.

This project will focus on the effect of early life (pre weaning) environmental enrichment on telomere shortening in young male pigs (n=96). Associations with maternal factors (age/parity), growth rates and litter size will also be investigated. For a subset of animals (n=30), associations between telomere shortening, environmental enrichment and markers of neuroinflammation can also be examined. 

The data will add to the understanding of telomere dynamics in pigs, and has the potential to develop strategies to reduce excessive telomere shortening in captive animals, as well as being a potential biomarker of an individual’s cumulative experience of inflammatory stress.  This has implications both for animal health and welfare, and, given the pigs emerging importance as an animal model, for translational human health studies.

Project.Title: co-benefits of largescale organic farming on environmental and human health (bloom): a natural experiment in andhra pradesh, india
Project.Description:
The way that we produce food has changed profoundly, and, as a result, so too has our dietary intake. Whilst these changes have resulted in unprecedented declines in undernutrition, they have come with a cost in terms of environmental degradation and the rising tide of obesity. Today, 1 in 3 people around the world experience some form of malnutrition and dietary risks are the #1 behavioural risk factor for deaths and #2 behavioural risk factor for disability. Our food system is failing us. Transformational action is urgently needed. However, though many theoretical frameworks exist for sustainable food systems, there is very limited data from the field at scale. This is the gap the 'Co-Benefits of Largescale Organic Farming On HuMan Health' (BLOOM) project aims to fill.

The government of Andhra Pradesh in India recently issued an order to support the transition to organic farming across the state known as, 'Zero Budget Natural Farming' (ZBNF). There is currently no scientific evidence to support the effectiveness of the ZBNF programme in terms of improving the livelihoods and health of farmers, yet the state government of Andhra Pradesh is moving forward with implementation. The proposed scientific evaluation will fill this critical gap. The Fellow will conduct a natural experiment using population-based surveys of 2,000 rural households in Andhra Pradesh and in the neighbouring state of Telangana (serving as a control) in 2021 (baseline) with two annual follow-up visits (2022 and 2023). Telangana is a unique control given that until June 2, 2014 it was part of Andhra Pradesh. BLOOM will address the following aims: (i) to determine if organic farming has co-benefits on human nutrition and health, and (ii) to ascertain the role of crop yields, household economics, decent work, food security, and diet quality in the causal pathway between organic farming and these outcomes. Specific nutrition and health outcomes to be quantified include (i) urinary biomarkers of exposure to pesticides (20% random subsample of households with children

Project.Title: environmental influences on stillbirth: a population record linkage study in scotland
Project.Description:
Reducing stillbirth is a key priority for the NHS and health policy.  More than 50% of stillbirths are currently unexplained and further research is necessary to determine new risk factors for stillbirth and identity pregnancies at risk.  The purpose of this work is to determine how the environment a woman is exposed to during pregnancy affects the health of the mum and the baby.  In particular, we examine these environmental exposures that occur before the onset of labour in an otherwise normally formed baby.  The link between environmental factors such as sunlight exposure, high and low temperatures and air pollution and stillbirth has not yet been studied in depth in a UK population.  However, hostile environments are known to be associated with early (preterm) birth and growth problems in babies.  Data recently produced by our group has shown that sunlight exposure in the first trimester (up to 12 weeks) of pregnancy is actually associated with a lower risk of preterm birth.  In the past, it has been difficult to accurately measure these environmental factors due to difficulty in collecting the information however in this proposal we can link individual level postcode information from health records to corresponding geographical environmental records.   This has been performed successfully by our group previously.  By linking the routinely collected Scottish maternity record, the SMR02, to the baby record (SBR) and the environmental data we will create a database in which we can study the environmental effects on pregnancy outcome.  We can also obtain other key information from this approach about the pregnancy which may mask the relationship we are trying to study such as maternal age, height, weight and information about the baby including birthweight.  Importantly the Scottish birth databases are unique in the UK in that they also give us information on maternal smoking which is a key risk factor in stillbirth and can obscure the relationship between air pollution and stillbirth.  Taking these factors into account when performing the final analysis of the data gives us a more accurate estimate of the association between stillbirth and the environment.

We envisage that the results of this study will improve our understanding of possible risk factors for stillbirth and therefore public health guidance for pregnant women.  The database will also provide a unique opportunity to look at other pregnancy outcomes associated with environmental exposures.  If we find significant associations, the results can be used to carry out further definitive studies to understand these associations and if appropriate trial new treatments, for example in the form of UV light therapy.

The results of this study will be used to inform policymakers and clinicians by providing information on risk factors for stillbirth, identify pregnancies at high risk of stillbirth and providing guidance on optimal management to try to reduce fetal death and complications.

Project.Title: blood in the soil: an environmental history of american slavery
Project.Description: “Blood in the Soil” explores the relationship between slavery and the environment in the American South. It argues that between 1730 and 1860, the environment fundamentally shaped American slavery and that slavery remade the Southern landscape. Organized thematically, the project looks at the interaction between slavery and six aspects of the Southern environment: swamps, forests, rivers, soil, storms, and animals. Taken in isolation, each of these topics reveals a facet of the Southern ecosystem transformed by the institution of slavery; collectively they suggest an ecological collapse with its roots in black bondage. Once completed, this book project will be the first comprehensive environmental history of American slavery.
School: School of History, Classics and Archaeology
Sponsor.Name: royal society of edinburgh
Scheme.Name: small research grants
PI.Name: David Silkenat

Project.Title: dynamic- dynamic epidemiological modelling for environmental change: predicting lassa fever disease in west africa
Project.Description: Human infectious diseases are a significant threat to global human health and economies, disproportionately affecting developing countries. The majority of infectious diseases have an animal source (zoonotic), and the dynamics of their spread and diffusion into the human population is underpinned by a complex web of interactions. Computational modelling can play a significant role in prediction of potential threats and evaluation of intervention strategies, yet effective modelling of zoonotic diseases requires an interdisciplinary breadth that is seldom achieved. In this project, we bring together leading computational, epidemiological and ecological expertise to develop a new integrated framework of disease modelling for the important endemic Lassa fever disease in West Africa. Our ambition is to combine ecological models of animal reservoir, spillover and human disease spread in a single probabilistic modelling framework which will enable full uncertainty quantification and prediction. Importantly, our approach will leverage recent developments in the statistical computing community to retain a higher level of mechanistic detail than is currently possible within epidemiological models. This will enable us to provide model-based predictions of responses to a changing environment, and to evaluate the impact of intervention strategies in plausible future scenarios. We will work in close collaboration with the Institute of Global Health at UCL and partners at The Centre for Disease control for Nigeria and the west African hub of the African Union to embed our research into policy and priority setting within the stakeholder communities across west Africa.

Project.Title: data-driven intelligent energy management for environmentally sustainable energy access
Project.Description:
This project aims to develop an intelligent energy management
platform and key strategies for the successful transition to a lowcarbon
sustainable society. This will be achieved by integrating smart
technologies – Internet of Things (IoT), Information & Communication
Technologies (ICT), Distributed Energy Resources (DER) and digital
networks for energy infrastructure. The workplan is designed to
realise this through an innovative programme involving UK and Indian
partners with complementary skillsets, mutually enriching, benefiting
both countries.
Key project objectives:
1. A research program on data-driven software technology platforms
for intelligent energy management;
2. Internal and outreaching exchange and dissemination of skillsets
and knowledge

Energy security and sustainable low-carbon economies is the prime objective of climate change
mitigation strategy.India-UK partnership, through UKIERI project, aims to pursue multi-disciplinary
international collaborative research and develop capacity-building to deliver the reliable,
sustainable, affordable green energy society without compromising its economic and social
developments that India as well as UK need. This will also help to promote much greater
decentralised on-site clean energy production and more efficient consumption to satisfy the
potential demand from the two billion Indian people who still lack access to basic modern electric
energy.
The key objective of this UK-India joint research proposal is exchange of skillsets and knowledge
towards the development of a data-driven intelligent energy demand management platform to
accomplish the optimal penetration of low carbon energy-productive economic activity and
energy-efficient end use for sustainable society. The intellectual merit of the proposed research is
the development of a software technology platform -- comprising a set of common knowledge,
theoretical approaches, mathematical models and decision support via optimization and analytical
tools -- that will contribute in making possible the promising environmentally sustainable energy
access. This project proposal include the following objectives:
1) To develop key strategies, novel algorithms and models in order to define interactions of
smart technologies, distributed energy resources, digital networks to enable
environmentally sustainable energy access.
2) To integrate ICT and IoT devices for developing data-driven software tool for real-time
energy monitoring and management.
3) Real-time information management, knowledge-based systems and decision support
development for optimum operations and energy management under normal and missing
information
4) To carry out simulations and tests using laboratory-scaled platform, to test and validate
the most promising solution and provide project outcome.
Sponsor.Name: uk-india education and research initiative
Scheme.Name: general scheme
PI.Name: Aristides Kiprakis
Name_of_Call: DST - UKIERI CALL FOR RESEARCH PROPOSALS 2016

Project.Title: supporting capacity-building and multi-level governance of small scale gold mining: a collaborative project on mercury; deforestation and rural livelihoods in indonesia
Project.Description:
The main goal of the project is to assist the Indonesian government to optimize the implementation of its ASM‐relevant mercury policies to address its poverty reduction and environmental protection objectives. This project will support knowledge strengthening and institutional capacity‐building at district, provincial and national levels. The project ideas developed through a series of collaborations
(since 2005) among international experts in the project team, a local development foundation in Central Kalimantan (Yayasan Tambuhak Sinta ‐ YTS) and the national, provincial and district governments. The team has past experience in the region with the  UNIDO/UNDP/GEF Global Mercury Project. (See Appendix B for CV of Project Lead and brief bio of other team members.) A scoping
mission was conducted in November 2014 to design this project. Requests were made from the government to support the project. There are four main objectives:
1) Strengthen awareness of environmental and social dimensions of gold mining in 3 districts in Central Kalimantan (Katingan, Kapuas and Gunung Mass), engaging policymakers, larger companies and other stakeholders.
2) Develop strategies for collaboratively implementing the Minamata Convention on Mercury, identifying how treaty implementation could be a pathway for Indonesian authorities and communities organizations to address locally identified challenges (including pollution and deforestation) while strengthening rural livelihoods. (While the project will focus on implementation of the Minamata Convention on Mercury, attention will also be paid to REDD – see Appendix A for details of the relevance of this linkage.)
3) Implement and evaluate capacity‐building efforts led by Yayasan Tambuhak Sinta (YTS), to support the Indonesian National Action Plan for the Minamata Convention and promote community‐based development and risk mitigation in gold mining areas. (See Appendix C for description of YTS’s mission, partners and track record.)
4) Develop partnerships for longer‐term collaboration with Indonesian authorities on poverty reduction strategies and risk mitigation in the mining sector.

Project.Title: environmental storytelling and energy transitions
Project.Description: ‘Environmental Storytelling and Energy Transitions’ will be the first book to examine the relationship between British literary cultures and decarbonisation. Drawing on my experience as a literary scholar and as a regulatory analyst in the renewable energy sector, I will explore how writers are developing new forms and genres to make a range of potential energy transitions imaginatively tangible. I will conduct original research into how writers are using speculative fiction and narrative nonfiction, in particular, to track, imaginatively animate, and even influence energy transitions. I will also argue that critical analysis of literature and energy culture demands a multidisciplinary approach, using methodologies from the social sciences, as well as literary criticism. Combining literary analysis of my chosen texts with oral history research into energy transitions, I will place literary texts into conversation with a range of contemporary energy cultures, from industry to activism.

Project.Title: boomerang: a bio-based and compact technology to transform self-consumption of renewables in housing
Project.Description:
BOOMERANG sets the fundaments to develop a revolutionary new energy technology: the first highly compact, entirely biobased, zero-emission energy storage. The concept utilizes the crystallization enthalpy of purely nature-based esters and a
completely new and direct way of high power heat transfer. This reduces the storage to the absolute minimum of storage
material and tank and guarantees a future lowest cost system. To enable this disruptive development, a team of leading
European experts in the fields of latent thermal energy storage, crystallography, demulsification, surface modification and
multi-phase flows will work closely together. Social, environmental scientist and dissemination experts will ensure the
positive impact of this technology to all aspects of society and will create a fertile ground for its future uptake.
BOOMERANG aims to disrupt the decentralized energy storage field by setting the basis for a highly modular solution that
meets the strictest criteria of ecological sustainability, carbon neutrality and safety, while being ultra-compact ( five times
more compact than water) extremely stable (>20 years life-time), and of lowest cost.
Decarbonizing the residential heating and cooling sector is a key requirement to meet the goals of the energy strategy 2050
and to tackle climate change. New energy storages like the BOOMERANG concept will be game changing technologies in
this context. Together with photovoltaic and heat pumps thermal storages will provide the warmth to our future sustainable
houses.

Project.Title: satellite climate observation for offshore renewable energy cost reduction (score)
Project.Description: In order to drive down the cost of marine renewables further, much more effective use of data will be needed across the project lifecycle. Satellite-based measurement has long been identified as having a potential role in enabling this cost reduction, but applications have been largely limited to wind resource assessment and wake modelling. Satellite measurements have the potential to unlock unexplored synergies between data for resource assessment, operational activities, life extension and decommissioning. Taking a whole systems approach, this interdisciplinary project combines expertise at the University of Edinburgh (UoE) and Strathclyde University (UoS), institutions well-placed to connect and solve this problem, and is supported by an Industrial Advisory Board (IAB) with relevant members from the satellite and ORE sectors.

Project.Title: faraday exchanger for renewable generation integration
Project.Description:
The FERGI (Faraday Exchanger for Renewable Generation Integration) project aims to develop a full-scale demonstrator device with increased power capacity (typically 2-3MVA) to accommodate the requirements of renewable energy generation (Wind, Tidal and Solar) and determine its benefits to developers and the wider energy system. Within this remit, the project has five specific goals:
(i) design and engineer a Faraday Exchanger (FE) to industry requirements. The FE is a power-control device that has been created to solve the fundamental technical challenges of voltage, frequency and power-factor control. A small-scale prototype of the FE was launched in 2017 at the National Museum of Scotland and was rated at 3kVA but further work is necessary to develop a full-scale commercial device. 
(ii) test extensively the device based on international/national standards
(iii) demonstrate the functioning of the device in near representative operating conditions, including real-world operation at the Offshore Renewable Energy Catapult's test turbine, as well as including an evaluation of wider system impacts, including effects on renewable energy investment incentives, energy prices, and carbon emissions, using a newly constructed investment model based on models developed in previous projects by the academic and industrial partner. The University of Edinburgh contribution to the project focuses on this goal, as well as offering advice on work related to the other goals.
(iv) develop FE deployment/utilisation methodologies for the different renewable energy sources
(v) identify a commercialisation strategy for the FE

Project.Title: valuing renewable investment under uncertainty: a real options framework for kazakhstan
Project.Description:
Kazakhstan has one of the most energy-intensive economies in the world, and energy demand is still growing. Most of the energy comes from fossil fuels resulting in emissions. The Kazakhstan government adopted an action plan to significantly increase renewable development to meet growing energy demand, reduce fossil fuel use and increase energy security. Renewable energy projects are capital intensive and the returns on investments depend on many uncertain variables, such as energy demand and regulations. Policy makers and the private sector need robust but flexible decision tools to predict these investments. The currently used net present values (NPVs) approach assumes that future decisions are fixed at the start while in reality companies can modify the project according to the circumstances.

Real options (RO) analysis incorporates this flexibility and provides a more useful framework for strategic decision making. However, the RO models requires expert knowledge, the solution is mathematically and computationally challenging, and so NPV is usually used by policy makers and industry. We will develop an RO framework for sustainable energy projects in Kazakhstan, to increase returns on renewable investment and therefore investment levels, and to allow policy makers to more efficiently support the renewable sector. 

The main directions are: 1) understand the main sources of uncertainty for sustainable energy investment in Kazakhstan and formulate RO investment models that capture these; 2) develop methods to solve these types of problems; 3) implement these methods on parallel computers; 4) provide detailed analysis of the results to industry and policy makers. 
Both applicants have strong and complementary skills in probability theory and numerical methods needed to address these topics. Also, the UK applicants have expertise in modelling problems in the energy sector. Together, we will design an RO framework and tool that is relevant to the energy industry

Project.Title: novel composite materials and processes for offshore renewable energy
Project.Description:
The consortium behind the MARINCOMP IAPP – NUI Galway and University of Ulster; Toray Carbon Fibers Europe, a
company specialized in manufacture of carbon fibre; EireComposites, an SME with innovative composite manufacturing
technology; and Suzlon Blade Technology, a utility class wind turbine manufacturer – aims to reduce the cost of offshore wind
and tidal turbine blade structures and enable the drive toward lower cost per kilowatt renewable energy for both industries.
The specific objectives of MARINCOMP are to jointly develop and optimise carbon-fibre reinforced composite materials
which are tailored for long-term durability in the marine environment, and can be processed rapidly and cost-effectively.
New software tools such as a fatigue life design tool which incorporates the effect of immersion in seawater, and a
cost-performance model will be developed in the project. Through an objective-driven transfer of knowledge (ToK)
programme between industry and academia, MARINCOMP will couple state-of-the art scientific knowledge in composite
materials and processes with industrial knowledge in carbon fibres and large-scale composites processing to provide a step
change in the use of carbon fibre in large high volume composite structures. The ToK programme will also bring benefits
to the researchers in terms of greater opportunities for employment and training in the marine renewable energy market.
In addition the project will improve the quality of research undertaken by the commercial partners and will increase their
competitiveness in this emerging market. The project will improve the research network of the academic partners and
provide routes for commercialisation of their research. MARINCOMP’s consortium is uniquely placed to plan and implement
a long-term cooperation and knowledge transfer needed to push the envelope of the current state-of-the-art in composite
materials for the marine environment, in keeping with the objectives with the Marie Curie IAPP programme.
Sponsor.Name: european commission
Scheme.Name: fp7 - marie curie actions
PI.Name: Conchur O Bradaigh
Partners.Detail: University College Cork,Lead,HEI,IRELAND|EIRECOMPOSITES TEORANTA,Partner,Industry,IRELAND|University of Ulster,Partner,HEI,UNITED KINGDOM|SE BLADES TECHNOLOGY BV,Partner,Industry,NETHERLANDS

Project.Title: repscore ‐ renewable energy performance score
Project.Description:
Investment in renewable technologies will need to rapidly increase in order to meet the world's future energy supply. A
major barrier to growth in private investment in renewable energy technology is the lack of shared reliable data and tools to
assess and predict renewable energy project performance. This means investors have to estimate return on investment of
projects which is risky and leads to major investment uncertainty. This project seeks to assess the technical feasibility of
developing an automated process for renewable energy project pre-qualification via development of a weighted scoring
system 'REPSCORE' (Renewable Energy Performance Score). Through the collaboration of Enian, Trove Research and
the University of Edinburgh (UoE), this SME led Industrial Research project seeks to build on Enian's excel based model
(MVP) (TRL3) and assess the feasibility of transforming the MVP into a web-based, data driven application (TRL5) that can
be used to accurately predict the return profile of solar PV and wind power assets in any location, thus reducing upfront
costs of due diligence and allowing investors to rapidly and reliably make an informed investment decision. Significant
socio-economic and environmental impacts are foreseen due to an increased number of projects gaining investment. The
addition of REPSCORE to Enian's existing deal management and collaboration platform will add significant value to their
customers; provide the partners with market credibility, visibility and new IP adding immense value to their commercial
positions.
Sponsor.Name: innovate-uk
Scheme.Name: collaborative research and development (tr)
PI.Name: Daniel Friedrich

Project.Title: safety and reliability of offshore renewables – building expertise through innovative networking
Project.Description:
Civil engineering, maritime/hydraulic engineering, geotechni
Energy collection, conversion and storage, renewable ene
Materials engineering
Reliability, risk, uncertainty, offshore renewable energy, wind turbines, tidal energy converters,
wave energy converters, waves, probabilistic models, risk-based operation and maintenance
According the Energy Roadmap 2050 published by the European Commission the biggest share of energy supply by 2050
should come from renewables. The document specifically mentions offshore wind and ocean energy as renewable
technologies which require further development. Since these technologies are based offshore, in harsh environments,
devices for energy extraction that they use are to be subject to extreme environmental loads and face an increased risk of
failure. At the same time, maintenance and repair of these devices is costly due to their difficult accessibility. Thus, the
reliability of the devices is a critical factor for further development of offshore renewables and their penetration into energy
markets. A typical device of offshore renewables is a complex system consisting of a supporting structure and electrical and
mechanical subsystems. Its reliability depends on environmental loads, performance of its various components under these
loads, interactions between components of the same subsystem as well as different subsystems and interactions between
individual devices within larger arrays. The difficult accessibility of such devices increases the importance of remote
monitoring of their performance. Data collected through the monitoring process needs to be analysed and then used for
updating the reliability assessment of the devices and managing their maintenance and repair activities. These activities
require multidisciplinary knowledge and expertise. Currently, very limited expertise is available in the area of the reliability of
offshore renewables. Building such expertise is an urgent but challenging task. The main aim of the proposed Innovative
Training Network (ITN) is to train a new generation of creative and highly-skilled researchers in the area of the reliability of
offshore renewables, who will contribute to the development of new more reliable devices and the improvement of availability
of operating individual devices and their arrays.
