Project.Title: community grids for resilient, reliable and renewable electricity demand & supply
Project.Description:
Developing countries all over the world have long identified the causal link between social and economic progress and the
ensuing improvement of quality of life on one side, with ubiquitous access to electricity on the other. In such countries
large proportions of the population live in remote rural areas with no, or limited connectivity to a power grid. For instance,
in India alone over 230 million people live in non-electrified settlements, while in Nigeria some 95 million people do not
have access to electricity (19% and 55% of the total country population respectively). For these people the dominant
energy source is burning of biomass, providing heat for space and water heating, cooking and lighting in a very inefficient
and environmentally unsustainable way. Essential electrical loads such as refrigerators, irrigation pumps and even
telecommunications, from cellular base stations down to mobile phone chargers are powered by expensive and unsustainable diesel generators. Additionally, moving away from metropolitan areas and towards the remote rural
locations in developing countries, access to knowledge and information via the internet, television and radio broadcasting is
becoming increasingly scarce, which on its own is a major hurdle for the social and economic progress in these areas.
Governments are taking measures towards 100% electrification of their population; India is currently implementing an
ambitious plan for widespread development of solar energy for rural electrification and other countries follow the same
route. However, to maximise their effect, deployment of renewables must be matched with careful planning of
infrastructure and optimal management of demand.
The C-GR3IDS group will work towards addressing the Energy Trilemma in developing countries by designing systems and
processes that will allow sustainable, reliable, and economically viable access to electricity, for both on- and off-grid remote
communities. We will achieve this by using tested, reliable and low-cost system infrastructure, augmented by intelligence
comprising digital technologies informed by real-time and historical data of demand, supply and environmental conditions.
This proposal is aiming to help tackling global challenges through engineering research in sustainable infrastructure
development, and through digital technology research in use of data for vital services. While, due to severity of the
challenge (and therefore the magnitude of the expected impact) in the country, the application of the research will focus on
India, we will strive to ensure that the results are generalised and transferable to other countries in the OECD DAC list with
similar challenges.

Project.Title: htsfcl: enable broad integration of renewable electricity with high temperature superconducting fault current limiter
Project.Description:
Developing renewable electricity is crucial for diversifying UK energy supply from imported fossil fuels, and meeting UK carbon emission reduction targets. Electricity accounts for 25% of UK energy consumption, and corresponding emissions. To keep UK on track to achieve 80% cut in emissions by 2050, 29 GW (35% of total UK capacity) of renewable electricity has been planned for installation by 2020. However, as more renewable energy sources are connected to the UK distribution system as distributed generation, fault current levels increase significantly and become a major barrier to renewable energy integration. According to DECC, up to 45% of planned renewable electricity will be at risk when connected to the existing UK distribution system.

Faults within electrical power systems are inevitable. Typical causes include equipment failure, external damage and severe weather conditions. Very high electrical currents can flow into the fault location, leading to high electrical, thermal and mechanical stresses on distribution system equipment. A power network may run without faults for years, however, once a fault occurs it causes crucial damage and loss not only to equipment, but also to our society and economy. The USA/Canada blackout in 2003 due to equipment failure affected 50 million people and caused economic losses of USD $6bn.

Using an interdisciplinary conceptual framework, out team of electrical engineers, material scientists and physicists will work together to develop a fault current limiter with high temperature superconductors (HTSFCL) to ensure network security when faults occur. This project's main goal is to minimise the usage of superconducting material to (1) reduce cost and simplify cooling system to (2) realise easy maintenance. For example, more than 15 km of superconductor is required for a 35 kV superconducting FCL. Estimated by our pilot research, the new HTSFCL only requires 1/10 of the superconductor.

We will carry out an initial physics study focuses on modelling of the HTS material, which is closely related to the performance of HTSFCL. The reaction of HTS to applied magnetic fields stronger than its critical field will be explored. Based on modelling, a prototype will be designed and fabricated with optimised geometries to minimise the usage of superconducting material while maintaining the current limiting level. Type testing will be carried out to verify its performance and results will be used to validate and improve the numerical model.

This project will complete an ambitious study of ageing and long term behaviour through 200 fault tests, which are equivalent to 10 years of service life. For the first time, ageing and long term behaviour of superconducting FCLs will be able to be analysed in great detail across a large number of tests. The analysis results will be used to identify future technical and material developments, and provide advice on manufacturing improvements.

If we can demonstrate that this technology is effective in limiting fault currents with low cost and easy maintenance, this could be the stimulus for industry to provide mass production, which would enable large-scale roll out of these interventions without government investment. Then we expect that power network operators will start to use it to integrate more renewable electricity and keep the electricity costs down. This will greatly support the reform of the UK electricity market and wean the UK away from imported fossil fuels. This also provides opportunities for low-carbon generators, stabilises the electricity price, and contributes to the challenge of meeting UK 2050 carbon emission targets.

Project.Title: marinet2: marine renewable infrastructure network for enhancing technologies 2
Project.Description:
Knowledge infrastructure

Offshore renewable energy, wave tidal wind, transnational access, training, networking,
education, standards, joint research

Integrating activities planned under MaRINET 2 build upon the achievements of the advanced community created in
MaRINET FP7. MaRINET 2 will ensure the continued integration and enhancement of all leading European research
infrastructure and facilities specialising in research, development and testing of offshore renewable energy systems including
electrical sub systems and grid integration through a range of TRLs (1-7). MaRINET FP7 proved the added value of uniting
these facilities, and substantially improving their capability as a community of practice to deliver consistent testing services
ensuring, quantifiable, stepwise innovation and progress in the development of devices and key components, and identifying
critical areas for further technical investigation and enhancement. Whilst activities proposed under MaRINET 2 will follow the
same formula, balancing networking/ joint research/ and transnational access, the consortium and scope of work is
expanded to include xx partners in xx countries with xx facilities. The e-infrastructure programme fills a strategic gap. Taking
stock of existing capacities for data management/sharing; it addresses user requirements and demonstrates the operation of
a new system based on standards and tools adapted from the SeaDataNet infrastructure. The European Commission and
member states recognise offshore renewable energy as an important source of clean energy that can: generate economic
growth and employment; increase energy security; and boost competitiveness and technological innovation. The realisation
of this potential depends on the accelerated development, deployment and grid integration of reliable, efficient technologies
for harvesting offshore renewable energy, which in turn requires robust and exhaustive testing in dedicated facilities
operated by practitioners with specialised expertise. MaRINET 2 provides this ecosystem, and is pre-eminently suited to
fostering the next generation of offshore renewable energy devices.

Project.Title: centre for advanced materials for renewable energy generation
Project.Description:
Renewable and lower-carbon energy sources need to become more competitive in the commercial market if the world is to meet the carbon emissions targets agreed in COP21. The CAMREG Centre brings together cutting edge materials researchers who will work together across discipline boundaries to increase renewable energy technology durability, reliability, utility, performance and energy yield. The aim of the Centre would be to combine activity, know-how and facilities from across a wide range of existing fundamental and applied materials science capacity to address the known and emerging challenges in renewable energy generation, including on- and off-shore wind, wave, tidal, conventional and next-generation solar photovoltaics (PV) and energy storage. CAMREG is intended to support and hasten the establishment or expansion of viable and sustainable renewable energy industries in the UK.
The proposed virtual centre offers a wide breadth and considerable depth of materials research capability and capacity in many areas of renewable energy, and is aimed at reducing the overall levelised cost of energy to the consumer. Research areas include: more efficient materials for PV solar and energy storage; materials giving increased power density in electrical generators, improved design and testing of composite blades for wind and tidal turbines; smart materials and optical coatings that can detect early damage in wind blades; smart coatings to minimise erosion and corrosion on blades and offshore support towers; improved lighter-weight design of structural steels; large-scale structural testing of components; better materials fatigue and failure management; lower-maintenance materials with improved resistance to combined wear and corrosion; superconducting materials to transfer power over long distances with less losses; high temperature ceramics and molten salt for energy storage; electrically responsive artificial muscles that can morph the
shapes of wind turbine blades to ensure better energy yields, and can provide better mooring and station keeping for wave
and tidal energy devices.
CAMREG is a partnership of 3 research-intensive universities, Edinburgh, Cranfield and Strathclyde, which would gather and network the interests, capacity and networks of many of the RCUK investments in energy research and training, and accruing over 200 industry connections: through 3 SuperGen Hubs, Marine UKCMER, Wind and Power Networks; 4 EPSRC Centres for Doctoral Training - Wind Energy Systems, Wind & Marine Energy Systems, Offshore Renewable Energy Marine Structures and Integrative Sensing and Measurement; the EPSRC Industrial Doctorate Centre in Offshore Renewable Energy (IDCORE) and the DECC SLIC (Offshore Wind Structural Lifecycle) Joint Industry Project - the largest industry-funded offshore renewables related materials and structures research project worldwide, involving Certification Authorities (DNV-GL and LR) and 10 of Europe's largest energy utility companies. The Centre will also respond to the needs and experience of device developers, project planners, legislators and consenting bodies, and academic partners across CAMREG will continue to work closely with key UK policy stakeholders.
CAMREG will underpin the efforts at existing recognised centres of renewable energy and materials science research, and will encourage those centres to link with new research groups working in complementary areas and to link centres into a coordinated national network. This will have the following national impacts: environmental benefits, through increasing the potential to displace fossil fuels; economic benefit through the expansion of employment and human capacity transfer from the existing offshore energy industries; increased diversity, security and resilience of electricity supply through reduction in dependence upon imported fuel and as indigenous coal oil and gas production declines.

Project.Title: two phase pumped heat energy storage
Project.Description:
Two Phase Pumped Heat Storage (PHS) stores electricity at times when there is over supply of wind or solar at a project cost an order of magnitude cheaper than batteries. PHS differs from previous pumped heat approaches in using unpressurised heat stores, and a two-phase closed-cycle Joule-Brayton machine as the interface between electricity and heat.  Compared with previous PHS, this significantly improves power density whilst reducing cost. The depth of storage can be chosen independently of the power rating, and PHS stores degrade slowly, meeting diurnal or week-long storage needs.  
The applicants propose final storage units circa 100MW with integrated open cycle Gas Turbine peaking and backup plant fitting at the electricity Distribution Network (DNO) level. Facilities would be compatible with siting requirements at existing sub-stations. The materials used in constructing the PHS are non-strategic and fully recyclable with the target cost of rated power at £500/kW, assuming a 10 hour output.
The PHS project will demonstrate and optimize all aspects of the functionality of the PHS in its first 15 months and will build an 80kW prototype unit validating the overall system in the second half of the project. The work program finishes in June 2019, after the demonstration of an operating pilot plant to a target group of customers as part of securing a future business relationship. All elements of Intellectual Property (IP) will be managed and secured as the project progresses
Sponsor.Name: department for business, energy & industrial strategy

Project.Title: micro-scale energy storage for super-efficient wet appliances
Project.Description:
In this project we will develop a novel technology to achieve 50% energy saving in dishwashers and washer-dryers
compared to the conventional appliances by using energy and water storage in porous materials. Although these
household units may seem an unlikely source of substantial environmental impact, their omnipresence makes them an
important target for further energy optimization and carbon footprint reduction. In fact, the adoption of the proposed
technology on global scale would enable mitigation of the equivalent CO2 emitted by 2.5 large coal power stations. This
project not only offers an opportunity to test emerging classes of porous materials in the context of novel applications, and
understand fundamental issues associated with their application, but also to initiate actual technological deployment of the
outcomes by inviting key international industrial partners.
Nowadays, adsorption materials are produced in massive quantities only when the economy of scale, combined with the
technology readiness level, make profitable their industrial production. This happens only for few specific applications.
However, the dishwasher and washer-dryer appliance sector has the necessary scale to make synthesis and investment in
new efficient materials worthwhile, giving momentum also to material science research.

Project.Title: plastic debris impact on fish health, an issue for food security and food safety: focus on digestive, cardiovascular and reproductive abnormalities using molecular and microscopic studies
Project.Description:
Water pollution by plastic debris has been found worldwide, but most
prominently in Asia.
Plastic debris can directly affect marine animal health, subsequently
causing a decline in aquatic animal numbers and threatening food security. Contamination of plastics in aquatic animals has further impact on human health due to the toxicity of plastic as well as the accumulation of heavy metals and pathogenic bacteria by plastic.
In this study we will focus on the adverse effects of micro and nanoplastics on cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and reproductive systems in fishes. We will focus on Asian seabass, one of the most important economic fish stocks in Thailand and popular worldwide. In the UK, we will use zebrafish as a developmental model for other fishes.
We will observe abnormalities in fishes using microscopic and molecular studies. Molecular studies will be done in collaboration with theThai National Omics Centre. There will be staff exchange between the two research groups and seminars or workshops will be organised in both the UK and Thailand.
Dr Sari Pennings is an expert in molecular techniques and developmental epigenetics mechanisms in disease. Asst Prof Tuempong Wongtawan is currently Head of the Centre for Marine Animal Research and Rescue, and an expert in animal anatomy and physiology. Both have experience from working together to study vertebrate cardiovascular and reproductive systems. This project will also collaborate with fish experts from the University of Stirling (UK), Chulalongkorn University (Thailand), and Mahidol University (Thailand).
The project aims to identify fish health problems, underlying mechanisms, and use in disease modelling, to raise awareness of the danger of plastic debris to the world and human health, to promote collaborative research and development between two countries, to strengthen science and research knowledge, and to propose ways to improve food security and food safety.

Project.Title: literary responses to reconstruction in post-war west germany: the cultural connotations of buildings, building styles and building materials after national socialism
Project.Description: The houses, streets and cities represented in German literature from the 1950s to the 1970s are the focus of this project, in which literary representations of the built environment are explored as a form of cultural memory. Our attitude towards past events determines our relationship with the built environment because the way we respond to certain buildings, styles and materials is significantly influenced by that building's, style's or material's historical associations. This project proposes that, if this is the case, we can accordingly read responses we encounter in post-war literature to building, styles and materials seen as typical of National Socialism or at odds with it, as a gauge of an author's, narrator's or character's attitude towards the Nazi past. Reading the literature of the period in this way thus promises to yield a more differentiated understanding of evolving attitudes towards the Nazi past in post-war West German society.

Project.Title: missing matter: a digital project of transatlantic feminist historical recovery
Project.Description: The aim of this pilot project is to initiate a documented "biographical panorama" of women's lives, which have hitherto been hidden from history-aptly described by Robert Proctor has as 'missing matter, knowledge not yet known' (Agnotology, 2008).  Drawing on the expertise of Gina Luria Walker's New Historia project at the New School, New York, and on the fruitful exchanges arising from Séverine Genieys-Kirk's symposium in 2016, 'Recovering Women's Past', this project will forge a network comprised off our key stakeholder groups: Curators, Creatives, Academics and Educators to explore new ways of investigating and drawing out the lives of women which have been hidden or omitted by official narratives. Curators are important caretakers of under-utilised sources of information. Creatives serve as a key connector to popular memory and culture. Educators are a vital force to enact the change that we seek to ensure that the stories of women's lives are being told and that their voices will be heard by the next generation. Our intention is to draw together stake-holders (curators and academics) who hold or produce useful information on women's history along with creatives who have innovative means of bringing this information to life, encouraging educators to reconfigure curricula to incorporate 'missing matter', and influencing policy makers in the education and heritage sectors. Even in recent times, women continue to be largely absent in the historical narrative; and the knowledge gained by feminist recovery has hardly permeated beyond the walls of universities.

Project.Title: temporal, aspectual and modal representations in second language acquisition
Project.Description:
The conference planned and hosted by the School of Literatures, Languages and Cultures at The University of Edinburgh responds to a widely recognized need for an updated knowledge base and innovative methodological tools in the study of temporal and modal representations in a second language (L2). 

The acquisition of tense, aspect and modality is a central area in Second Language Acquisition research, and a subject of hundreds of papers and dozens of edited volumes, monographies and special issues. This conference will provide researchers, L2 academics and practitioners not only with keynote presentations from leading experts on the field from Edinburgh, the USA, Spain and Italy, but also with an overview of contemporary research and current practice undertaking nationally and internationally. 

This conference aims to discuss Tense, Aspect and Modality in L2, with an emphasis on (a) aspectual representations in L2; (b) pedagogical applications of TAML2 research findings; (c); futurity and modality and (d) theory building.

Project.Title: can [18f]lw223, a superior tspo pet radiotracer, become a clinical breakthrough for detection of regional tissue inflammation?
Project.Description: Inflammation plays a key role in the development and progression of various cardiovascular diseases, including coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction and myocarditis. Currently most clinical cardiovascular inflammatory biomarkers rely on the quantification of proteins and enzymes in blood. An imaging biomarker capable of identifying and quantifying arterial and myocardial cellular inflammation and cardiokine-induced multi-organ inflammation in vivo would provide an important imaging tool with major diagnostic and prognostic applications. We propose to address this need by characterising and validating 18F-LW223, a specific PET radiotracer targeting the 18 kDa translocator protein (TSPO) in humans.

Project.Title: environmental sustainability and economic cooperation in the longue duree: a comparative approach to locality, history and development
Project.Description:
In recent years there have been multiple challenges to the existing understandings of economic growth and the environment, and the difficulties in balancing economic, social, and environmental goals. There is growing awareness of the challenges posed by climate change and the depletion of natural resources, and the urgency of developing balanced approaches for future economic growth and environmental sustainability. At the same time, the uneven economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic and the lingering repercussions of the 2008 financial crisis continue to raise important questions regarding social and economic equality, how to manage access to financial resources, and how to protect the agency and opportunity of individuals within a globalized economic system dominated by large multinational corporations. This network seeks to explore and bridge these two issues of our times - sustainable development and economic inequality. In particular, we seek to explore diverse models of economic cooperation and sustainable resource management through comparative and interdisciplinary engagement with historians, anthropologists, political scientists, geographers, and sociologists, with the goal of developing future research agenda into sustainable growth that can incorporate a diverse range of economic, environmental, and social objectives.

Contemporary environmental and economic crises highlight the importance of incorporating a humanistic approach to growth and development that brings to the fore sustainable and equitable patterns of resource management. As such, this network brings together humanities and social science researchers in order to explore the historical and cultural contexts surrounding diverse models of economic cooperation and resource management. In this way, we seek to provoke new understandings of sustainable development, both past and present, while also fostering new collaborations across disciplines and regions in order to highlight the significance of the social and cultural context of sustainable growth. In particular, we seek to prompt new insights and comparative studies into sustainable growth through the example of the Korean kye - a type of organization that has been used to manage a wide range of resources throughout Korean history including forests, fishery rights, education, and financial resources, to name just a few. By bringing examples of Korean kye organizations over time into dialogue with comparative models of economic cooperation and sustainable development from other regions, we aim to generate new directions for future research into alternative models of growth and economic
activity.

Overall, this project will search for links between historically specific examples and contemporary case studies in order to develop a deeper understanding of the interrelations between environmentally sustainable growth and social and economic equality. We will create an environment for interdisciplinary conversations where researchers can learn from one another, while using discussions of kye as a vehicle to expand the understanding of sustainable development and create a foundation for future collaborative research. Throughout this process, we will foster strong ties between researchers in both South Korea and the United Kingdom by hosting a programme of visiting research fellowships and international workshops and conferences that will not only provide a valuable contribution to academic knowledge but also support researchers - especially early career researchers - to develop future research and international collaborations.

Project.Title: towards explainable and verifiable goal recognition for trustworthy autonomous systems
Project.Description: Towards realising explainable AI for trustworthy autonomous systems, we here focus on a key ability in AI systems: the ability to recognise the goals (or intentions) of other agents based on limited observations of their past actions. Project.Title: reconstructing chinese intellectual history: doctrinal assumptions and exegetical strategies in he xiu’s gongyang commentary
Project.Description:
The Gongyang zhuan, a third or second century BCE commentary to the Spring and Autumn Annals (Chunqiu, a court chronicle of the state of Lu covering the years 722-481 BCE), has been generally considered the most political- philosophical-oriented canonical text among all Confucian Classics.  In the history of imperial China, HE Xiu’s (129-182) classical annotations to the Gongyang zhuan, a subcommentary titled Chunqiu Gongyang jingzhuan jiegu, has played a dominant role in the exegetical tradition of the Gongyang zhuan until today. Although the orthodoxy and significance of HE Xiu’s 
subcommentary have been widely approved, it has not been examined exhaustively using modern methodologies.

This project will investigate the Chunqiu Gongyang jingzhuan jiegu from several perspectives and attempt to reveal its exegetical characteristics in multiple aspects. At first, a reliable edition of the Gongyang zhuan with HE’s annotations is going to be produced by comparing various xylographic editions of the text and referring to multiple works in the field of traditional textual criticism. On this basis, the exegetical strategies of HE’s commentary can be disserted in multiple aspects. To be specific, HE’s commentary comprises general doctrinal assumptions about the text and develops particular explanations for each textual unit of the Chunqiu forming a systematic hermeneutical approach to the text. By analysing the interaction and connection between the integrated (and sometimes implied) doctrines and the individual explanations, the interpretative strategies of HE’s commentary can be presented, which can be regarded as a quintessential characteristic in early Chinese text interpetation. Besides, the structural idiosyncrasies of HE’s annotations reflect HE’s understanding and redefinition of the structural arrangement of the original textual units of the Spring and Autumn Annals, which will be examined in detail.  Furthermore, the exegetical strategy of repetitions and citations in HE’s annotations will be explored by using the theory of intertextuality. Finally, some of the politically and historically most influential concepts from HE’s commentary, such as the three-generation-theory and the notion of great unification, will be examined in detail within their original context.

In summary, this project is an important attempt to revisit the exegetical tradition of early Chinese text production, reconsider the significance of some central concepts in Chinese intellectual history, and reconstruct a new understanding of the discursive logic of Confucian classical scholarship in the contemporary era.

Project.Title: the works of john day: recovered, revived, reconceived
Project.Description:
With as many as forty plays, several short poems, an allegorical verse dialogue and a satirical prose treatise to his name, John Day ranks among the most industrious playwrights of the English Renaissance. Day's literary output rivals -- if not eclipses -- those of his more familiar contemporaries, including William Shakespeare, Ben Jonson, Christopher Marlowe, John Ford, and John Webster. Day was also no stranger to scandal: he was expelled from Cambridge for stealing a book, murdered a fellow playwright, and so offended the court with one of his satires that the acting company lost its royal patronage. And yet, Day's life and works are little known today even among specialist scholars.

As a much-needed corrective, this ambitious project seeks to recover Day's corpus, to revive those works through performance and by producing the first modern critical edition of them (Day's collected works were last edited in 1881, and that edition falls woefully short of modern standards of scholarly rigour), and to critically reconceive Day's relationship to his literary and theatrical contexts as well as the historical and cultural significance of his life and works, then and now. To achieve these aims, the project will combine innovative techniques of computational stylistics with traditional bibliographical methods for authorship attribution to determine the limits of Day's canon with greater certainty than hitherto possible; conduct a detailed and comprehensive bibliographical analysis of Day's works that survive in early print and manuscript sources; produce the first critical edition of Day's collected works according to modern methods of textual, critical, and historical analysis; mount performances of Day's works, in whole and part, in partnership with acting companies to explore how Day's plays work as texts for the theatre; and produce new scholarship to consolidate, update, and extend criticism on Day, to re-evaluate his works on page and stage, and to offer new models and appraisals of his canon and creative legacy.

Project.Title: black ecologies: race and the long anthropocene
Project.Description:
My project reads literature at the intersection of race and the environment, repositioning late nineteenth and early twentieth-century Black writers such as Frederick Douglass and Pauline Hopkins alongside contemporary Black authors including Alexis Pauline Gumbs and Marlon James, to demonstrate that many of the problems that define contemporary ecology have always been present in writing about chattel slavery and its afterlives. I ask how Black writing, from the nineteenth-century onwards, reframes the epoch we now know as the Anthropocene, arguing that literature allows us to understand the animating relationship between race and the environment while also providing space to imagine a world outside the joint violence of anti-Black racism and environmental destruction.

I am particularly excited about undertaking this work as it bridges the gap between three disparate conversations occurring in the environmental humanities, Black Studies, and literary criticism. Working at this intersection, my work uses literature as a way to both imagine and build a more sustainable and equitable future. That is, alongside tracing how the same political and economic forces have largely been responsible been responsible for both anti-Black violence and environmental destruction from the inception of chattel slavery to the present, I also look at how literature provides us with the opportunity to imagine a world outside of these twinned cycles. The goal of this research is to not only build a literary archive, but to translate this work into practice, arguing for the importance of literature in constructing alternate futures.

Project.Title: decoding hidden heritages in gaelic traditional narrative with text-mining and phylogenetics
Project.Description:
This project will fuse deep, qualitative analysis with cutting-edge computational methods to decode, interpret and curate the hidden heritages of Gaelic traditional narrative. We will provide the most detailed account to date of similarities and differences in the countries' narrative traditions and, by extension, a novel understanding of their joint cultural history. Using recent advances in language technology, we will digitise, convert and make available a vast collection of folklore manuscripts in Irish and Scottish Gaelic. In turn, this new digital resource will catalyse ongoing research into Gaelic speech technology.

The main question that this project poses is: What can a large, digital collection of traditional narrative tell us about historical cultural exchanges between Scotland and Ireland? While we will examine different kinds of traditional narrative, we will concentrate upon International Tales in Irish and Scottish Gaelic. International Tales are folk narratives that are widely scattered across the world, such as Cinderella or Snow White. Some are amongst the oldest known facets of human oral culture, dating back 5000 years or more. Due to their age and their tendency to vary geographically, they can tell us a lot about relationships between different settlements of people. In this study, we use them as a vehicle for understanding early communication networks between Scotland and Ireland, as well as those that existed within each country.     

Through an approach known as text-mining, we will use artificial intelligence to search the tales for similar topics, phrases and other linguistic patterns. The matches that we find between texts will be correlated with what we know about the texts themselves. Using another approach, known as phylogenetic network analysis, we will comb relationships between the texts' themes and the people who produced them: for example, their genders, where they lived and what they did for work. In the end, we will combine the two approaches towards a unified account of Scottish and Irish oral narrative. This work will transform our understanding about Gaelic oral culture and disseminate unique archival material online to a diverse set of end-users. Finally, it will positively impact the sustainability of Gaelic-speaking communities through the creation and further stimulation of important language technologies (e.g. handwriting recognition, machine translation and automatic speech recognition).

Project.Title: new strategies for downstream processing of recombinant proteins
Project.Description: The use of proteins as therapeutics is ever more prevalent. Examples include coagulation factors (such as Factor IIX for haemophilia), enzymes, cytokines and antibodies. There are many advantages to producing these proteins ‘recombinantly’ - introducing the DNA that encodes them into cells or microbes - rather than extracting the proteins from original sources. To produce recombinant therapeutic proteins, they must be purified away from all other cellular proteins. We propose to develop a new tag-based affinity purification strategy, which is readily applicable to proteins produced recombinantly. This new purification strategy will be ideal for downstream processing of protein therapeutics produced by biologicals contract development and manufacturing organizations (CDMO), such as Fuji Film Diosynth Biotechnologies UK (FDBK). This work was initiated following consultations with FDBK regarding their needs, and will proceed in close consultation with them. A successful new purification strategy will significantly decrease the manufacturing costs associated with producing recombinant therapeutics. It has the potential to be applied to the purification of many different recombinant proteins.
Sponsor.Name: fujifilm diosynth biotechnologies, scottish funding council
Scheme.Name: fujifilm diosynth biotechnologies default scheme, industrial biotechnology (ibioic) (tr)
PI.Name: Lynne Regan

Project.Title: extracellular vesicles are critical for promoting rhinovirus infection in copd macrophages leading to secondary bacterial infection
Project.Description:
The devastating disease called chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) stops the lungs working properly, damages their structure and leads to repeated lung infections. My research focusses on a special white blood cell called the macrophage that protects the lungs against infection by destroying the different microbes that invade. These microbes make COPD patients very sick and include bacteria and viruses. My project will focus on finding new ways to target the effects of the common cold virus which makes COPD patients very unwell and lets bacteria invade their lungs. 

Why this virus targets COPD patients, and how it infects COPD macrophages assisting bacteria in invading their lungs, is unknown and the aim of my project. I will study macrophages to identify what is different about them in COPD that leads to more virus infection. I will also examine whether lung lining (epithelial) cells which the virus always infects, pass the virus to macrophages in structures that make the virus an even more effective invader. Finally, I will ask what the virus changes inside a COPD macrophage after infection that makes it struggle to fight bacteria. 

My project can change the future for COPD patients by answering these questions to help find new treatment targets for virus infection in COPD.
Sponsor.Name: medical research council
Scheme.Name: career development award
PI.Name: Jamil Jubrail
Name_of_Call: Career Development Award (CDA): Transition to independence

Project.Title: informing recovery of  african health systems post the covid19 pandemic peak with case studies in zimbabwe and ghana
Project.Description: Most African countries have less resilient health systems compared to western countries, meaning the impact of the SAR-CoV-2 pandemic has been more pervasive in Africa. Hundreds of thousands of African children are at risk of dying from preventable infections due to interrupted vaccination programs. Furthermore, there is a growing unwillingness of people to seek required medical interventions due to fear and lack of trust, e.g. the WHO reports that mental health patients are avoiding seeking services in hospitals for fear of contracting coronavirus. Therefore, there is a current urgent need for i) recovery of core health system functions in African countries and ii) building confidence in the population for resumption of health-seeking for non COVID-19- related conditions. This requires informed strategies. The aim of this study is therefore, to generate information from affected populations to inform these strategies through a combination of desk research and field research in Ghana and Zimbabwe.

Scheme.Name: knowledge frontiers: international interdisciplinary research projects
PI.Name: Francisca Mutapi

Project.Title: the evolution of sexual dimorphism in recombination rates
Project.Description:
When animals and plants produce eggs or sperm, chromosome pairs swap large chunks of DNA in a process called crossing-over. This creates chromosomes that are a mosaic of DNA from both parents which are passed on to offspring. Crossing-over creates new combinations of gene-copies that can be favoured by natural selection. This helps populations adapt faster to new diseases, changing environments and artificial selection. However, too many crossovers can break up good combinations of gene-copies and cause harmful mutations; too few crossovers are a leading cause of infertility. Trade-offs between costs and benefits were thought to tightly constrain crossover rates to a narrow range, yet they show huge variation in nature. Little is known about how and why this variation has evolved.

Sex is strongly associated with crossover rate, with large variation in the direction and degree of sex- differences within and between chromosomes. Hypotheses to explain the evolutionary causes of this variation include sex-differences in selection, selfish genetic elements, sperm competition and mechanistic differences between egg and sperm production, but this question remains unsolved due to a lack of data. My research will use data from 11 wild bird species to measure sex-differences in crossover rates and identify the genes that underlie this variation. I will compare patterns across species to see if they are associated with particular genomic or life-history features and if sex-differences in crossovers evolve slowly or rapidly. This will help us understand if sex-differences are due to selection and/or driven by mechanistic differences between the sexes.

Project.Title: demographic, multi-morbidity and genetic impact on myocardial involvement and its recovery from covid-19: the covid-heart study
Project.Description: COVID-HEART is a large UK multi-centre consortium committed to work together to answer a set of unique and important clinical questions. The bid is backed by the major UK professional cardiovascular societies and the NIHR-BHF Cardiovascular Partnership have designated it as a “COVID-19 Cardiovascular Disease UK Flagship Project” (see attached letter). Whilst up to 20% of hospitalised COVID-19 patients may have cardiac injury based on serum troponin (and associated with high mortality), this is non-specific and can relate to pericarditis, myocarditis, acute coronary syndromes, acute heart failure, arrhythmias, or simply hypoxia/sepsis/shock. Cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) can make a specific diagnosis and is recommended in European Society of Cardiology practice guidelines. We will use CMR to determine 1) the UK prevalence of acute myocardial injury/myocarditis secondary to COVID-19 and the severity of presentation; 2) how clinical outcomes associate with recognised risk factors for mortality such as age, sex, ethnicity and comorbidities (diabetes, hypertension, heart failure, and coronary/peripheral vascular disease; 3) if there are differences in myocardial recovery at 6 months dependent on demographics, genetics and comorbidities, and how this impacts on patient quality of life and functional capacity; 4) if we can improve the ECG diagnosis of myocarditis minimising the requirement for invasive cardiac investigations. Ethics approval has been granted for clinical CMR scans enabling us to start quickly, and if funded we would extend this approval to include the additional research scans, other investigations, patient reported outcome measures and follow-up as described below.

Project.Title: developing automatic speech recognition for scottish gaelic
Project.Description:
Although Gaelic now has at least nascent representation in several language processing fields and resources,  two cornerstones of modern language technology remain to be developed: a general language model (LM) and an automatic speech recognition system (ASR). If developed, these tools would enhance computer-assisted language learning (CALL), broaden communicative domains (e.g. via interaction with smart devices) and facilitate automatic transcription and translation, addressing multiple desiderata across current research, media and government agendas. 

Our proposal is for a collaborative, 10-month project between researchers at the University of Edinburgh, Quorate Technology Limited and the University of the Highlands and Islands. Once finalised, the Gaelic LM and ASR models will be made freely available on the web, and the study will be documented in blogs and a peer-reviewed publication. 

This project is part of an iterative research programme devoted to developing language technology tools for Scottish Gaelic. It will significantly advance the state-of-the-art, building upon resources and techniques developed in two prior funded projects at Edinburgh University: the Gaelic Part-of-Speech Tagging Project  and the Gaelic Handwriting Recognition Project , and also incorporating two recent spoken language ethnographic recording projects conducted under UHI/Soillse auspices (Saoghal Thormoid and Stòras Beò nan Gàidheal). It is also foundational for an ambitious future research programme, which will develop further novel language technologies for Scottish Gaelic (e.g. geoparsing and sentiment analysis) and innovative ways of understanding traditional narrative through these technologies.  It is envisaged as an initial investigation of an evolving research theme that aims to make vernacular and ethnographic material readily available and analysable for future generations who wish to gain a developed understanding of vernacular speech, vernacular narratives, and vernacular perceptions of their social and cultural condition. Thus, it relies on a strong legacy of innovative research, and will establish its own impactful legacy in subsequent projects.

Project.Title: iunctio: a digital humanities tool for recording and connecting historical people. the example of twelfth-century byzantium
Project.Description: The aim of this project is to connect, exploit and enrich existing collections of historical person data. The objective is to create a package of digital tools – Iunctio – that allows to readily connect and visualise data in the form of social networks, activity maps and graphs of social structure. The development relies on advances made in Iunctio’s pilot project, the Database of Byzantine Literati and the expansion of data included in the BAfunded Prosopography of the Byzantine World (an important but static historical resource). We intend to demonstrate how Iunctio can allow recording people in context and can deploy rich data in different analysis and visualisation strategies. The focus is on the twelfth century, a well documented period; concluding the project we expect to have a deeper prosopographical and network understanding of this complex period and a set of tools and protocols applicable to material from other periods.

Project.Title: optimising fertility in cancer survivors through novel approaches to assessment, prediction and recovery from germ cell and gonadal damage
Project.Description: The loss of fertility is one of the most important concerns of young people facing a new cancer diagnosis. The field of 'fertility preservation' has developed over recent years, with improvements in egg storage, and freezing of ovarian tissue is now possible. These treatments are however mostly complex, and not all patients either need or can have them. There remain big gaps in our ability to predict accurately who needs to preserve their fertility. Cancer treatments are changing and improving, and we know very little about factors that determine individual's susceptibility to loss of fertility. Our understanding of the effect of cancer treatments on the different cell types that make up the ovary and testis is also limited: improvements in this would allow the development of approaches to prevent damage from happening, and promote recovery after treatment. In this programme we will study the effects of current and new cancer treatments on the reproductive function of teenage and young adult (TYA) males and females who are facing a new cancer diagnosis, recruited from TYA cancer centres across the UK. We will include all diagnoses, allowing us to gather information on the less common as well as more common conditions. We will collect clinical information (including details of treatment received), and blood samples to measure hormones that reflect the function of the ovaries and testes. Importantly, we will start collecting these samples before treatment starts, then again at the end of treatment and at intervals thereafter. This will allow us to determine which treatments do and do not affect reproductive function in both males and females and what pretreatment factors are important in determining this. Over the longer term we will link this to key reproductive eventspregnancy and paternity, and in females, time to potentially early menopause. We will also undertake laboratory-based studies to investigate the effects of cancer treatment on the ovary in much more detail than has previously been performed, using samples we collected from patients exposed to cancer treatment and from laboratory-based exposure of tissue in culture. We anticipate that this will reveal novel pathways of cellular function and communication that are affected by cancer treatment, and this will raise opportunities to identify pathways that could be used for protection of the ovary. We have also developed a unique multi-step method for growing human ovarian follicles and the eggs they contain all the way from the non-growing stage to final maturity in the laboratory. This is a huge opportunity to understand how human eggs grow and mature in detail, never before possible. This method could also potentially be used to grow eggs from ovarian tissue taken from cancer patients before treatment, but where there may be cancer cells within the ovary thus preventing its reimplantation. We need to refine this complex technique, and assess the normality of the eggs we generate from it. We can also use this approach to assess whether normal eggs can be obtained after anti-cancer treatments, or whether there would be concerns about using such eggs. Finally, several labs including ourselves have identified that the adult human ovary contains cells called oogonial stem cells (OSCs) that may have the potential to form new follicles and eggs, under certain conditions. We will explore this by investigating in detail the characteristics of OSCs and the cells that surround them within the ovary, as we think their immediate environment is critical in determining whether they can mature. We have some evidence that one specific form of chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma can activate these cells, but that this is only possible in younger women: we will explore these aspects to understand how and when activation of OSCs may be a way to promote recovery of the ovary after cancer treatment.

Project.Title: using private sector data to deliver rapid, timely, granular economic insights into the impact on sme's and consumers to support uk covid-19 policy
Project.Description:
The UK does not have an Economic Observatory holding granular financial data. Traditional economic data sources have significant latency and coarse granularity making them ineffective for Government use in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. These gaps in economic insight urgently need to be filled. Financial services data sources offer significant potential to deliver timely and highly granular insights of current and future economic impacts.
However these "new" data sources need to be rapidly mobilised, safely and securely stored in a way that respects privacy, and subsequently analysed to deliver suitable reports for Government that can then be iteratively refined. Impact pathways will include BEIS, HM Treasury, Bank of England, FCA who are already engaged. This is our raison d'etre.
The project, working with UK Government and data suppliers, has already specified an initial time series of metrics that usefully and robustly reflect the levels of financial health of SME's and consumers across the UK. These metrics will, over the course of the project, be refined to deliver a series of economic, social, environmental and (potentially) health related insights to Government on a more timely basis enabling widespread data-driven, evidence-based interventions.
The project will continue to orchestrate data supply and information demand to maximise impact and optimise interventions in order to pro-actively support economic recovery. The project team hosted at the University of Edinburgh will deliver the insights, comprised of highly experienced professionals from industry and academia including the data supply sector, data scientists, and individual sector experts.
To support long term research we will actively work towards providing longitudinal economic data to approved University researchers which otherwise would not be available.

Project.Title: economic theory and the  management of  fish and whale stocks since 1945.
Project.Description: This economic history research project examines the management of fish and whale stocks since 1945. Addressing the persistence of over-fishing and the near hunting to extinction of some species of whales, this research asks why, despite all of the modelling of sustainable catches and the establishment of property rights at sea in the Law of the Sea Conferences, the effective management of fish and whale stocks proved to be so difficult. The research focusses on over-investment in technologically advanced boats and uses company, industry, government and international archives to examine the information and incentives facing companies when making investment decisions.

Project.Title: understanding multimorbidity in women: clustering of reproductive health with other morbidities across the lifecourse and underlying mechanisms
Project.Description:
There is increasing interest that women's reproductive health problems may be an important, but largely unrecognised, contributor to other physical and mental health problems that women experience across their life. Reproductive health problems are common and include conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome, infertility, endometriosis, miscarriage, heavy menstrual bleeding as examples, but we also know that changes at key time points in a woman's life, such as pregnancy and menopause, contribute to their health. There have not been major advances in understanding how reproductive health problems co-exist with other conditions as reproductive health issues are often not talked about - or are even ignored. This means that no one thinks to connect women's reproductive health problems with other diseases. The situation is made worse as women's health care in the reproductive years is delivered in silos (for example in general practice, sexual health services, gynaecology clinics, maternity care), meaning there are missed opportunities to fully address all health problems that women experience. We believe there are multiple opportunities in a woman's life to prevent other health problems and to empower women with information to take positive steps towards health.

In this proposal we aim to understand the link between women's reproductive health problems and other physical and mental health problems and to explore underlying mechanisms. We propose that inflammation is a key candidate mechanism as there is evidence from the literature that inflammatory pathways underpin some of the common reproductive health disorders and these pathways are also thought to be important in the development of mental health disorders and physical health problems such as heart disease.

In this 6 month piece of work we aim to gather key preliminary data to support our proposal.

To do this we will use existing datasets that contain relevant information about women. These include a large dataset of >600,000 women living in the East Region of Scotland. Their health and social care records have been linked up and anonymised and are held securely. We will use this dataset to identify new 'clusters' of diseases which include reproductive health problems - for example when a woman has more than one reproductive health problem, or when a woman has a reproductive health problem which co-exists with a physical or mental health problem. To find out if inflammation is an important underlying mechanism we will use a large and well characterised study, "Generation Scotland". In this study women completed questionnaires about their reproductive health, have had inflammation markers measured in their blood and data about their health and social care has been linked into the main dataset.

During the project we also aim to identify any other new partners who may want to join us to conduct a bigger study in this field. We will also identify other datasets that are available for us to use to answer our research questions.

We have already engaged key members of the public who have an interest in this field in putting together this application. During the project we plan to extend this work. We plan to carry out public engagement activities to get input from women about the topic of our study and what is important to them, and to inform women about our findings.

We will use all this information to prepare and submit a more detailed application to answer the research questions at the end of the project.

Ultimately we hope that our project will pave the way for novel, better targeted, more tailored and effective strategies for disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment for women with two or more health problems and new optimised care pathways to improve women's health.

Project.Title: antiplatelet secondary prevention international randomised trial after intracerebral haemorrhage
Project.Description: ASPIRING will be a prospective, randomised, open-label, assessor-blind, parallel-group trial at ≥151 hospital sites in the UK and Europe, which will recruit ≥4,542 participants aged ≥18 years who survive ≥24 hours after stroke due to ICH and have not started antiplatelet or anticoagulant drug therapy after ICH. Computerised randomisation will allocate participants (1:1) to start antiplatelet monotherapy that is available in standard clinical practice, or avoid it. All randomised participants will be followed for the primary composite outcome of all major vascular events (non-fatal stroke, non-fatal myocardial infarction, or death of a vascular cause) for at least one year.

Project.Title: crafting myanmar. the role of the youth in the sustainable creative economy
Project.Description:
The story of Myanmar's transformation has typically been told from the top-down, with a clear emphasis on the importance of military and/or charismatic leadership . Exceptions are rare, especially when it comes to capturing the role, challenges and aspirations of local youth. The project seeks to address this gap in research and scholarship by generating knowledge on Myanmar's youth (one in two people is below the age of 30). Integrating insights from the sociology of youth, urban studies and political economy , this project seeks to provide a nuanced understanding of Myanmar's youth, its aspirations, challenges and potential. Focusing on the cases of Yangon, Mandalay, and Lashio, it uses the creative economy as a vantage point to generate knowledge on this issue and arts and practice-methods to empower and amplify the voices and skills
of local youth and integrate them in the process of knowledge production and dissemination.

Project.Title: flagg: finance, labour, and the aggregate economy
Project.Description:
In the aftermath of the recent global financial crisis, there is widespread acknowledgement that the prevailing macroeconomic models performed poorly, though little agreement on what alternative paradigm should be pursued. But the crisis has served as a kind of “laboratory” which exposes critical features of the economy that are harder to identify in more normal times. By bringing together leading researchers across fields, our project aims to re-examine the foundations of macroeconomics, with particular emphasis on financial and labour markets. Our ambition is bold: we think Europe should beat the forefront of the reconstruction of macroeconomics, and we want to be a key part of that endeavour. In terms of the wider public, we want the fruits of our research to inform and improve the quality of macroeconomic policy.

Financial and labour markets should arguably be the most prominent components of any macroeconomic framework, given that, when things go wrong in the economy, it is the apparent malfunctioning of these markets that stands out most – be it a financial crisis, a rise in unemployment, or both. Behind this research proposal lies the belief that financial and labour markets are connected in ways that economists have yet to appreciate fully. Financial and labour market transactions are most often long-term, and so rely on some form of contract, either explicit or implicit. By looking at both markets through a common lens, by delving into their common contractual foundations, we expect that deeper connections will be discovered that will feed into better macroeconomic models.

To succeed, we need to work across boundaries, to exploit synergies: between macroeconomists and microeconomists, between theorists and empiricists, between experts in finance and experts in labour. We need a broad scope: from small models to big data sets. And we need to embrace wider relevant issues: demography and migration, health and inequality, institutions and regulation.

Project.Title: empire by association: the re-organization of the rural economy in modern korea
Project.Description: My project explores the intersections of empire, science and capitalism in modern Korea from the perspective of everyday life. Using a combination of farmers' diaries, organizational records, and government publications, I question how the extension of new commercial networks and government projects to promote scientific agriculture combined to reshape agricultural production from the late nineteenth century. Through the mundane details of farmers’ daily lives—the cultivation of cotton over barley, or the provision of loans for fertilizer—I challenge state-centric accounts of the colonial rural economy to understand Korean responses to forms of empire and capitalism from the bottom up.

Project.Title: landscapes (france) as carbon sinks co-design phase - land ecosystem in france - climate kic 19
Project.Description:
Landscape Ecosystem in France
Deep Demonstrations are intended to offer a showcase of a zero-net emissions, a resilient future and highlight the ways that innovation across whole systems can unlock the change we now so desperately need. We want to move toward unleashing exponential change through a systems approach.
The work of INRA, WUR, AgriCircle, the University of Edinburgh and ONFI will be responsible for collecting and curating the learnings and insights from across the different areas in an aggregated way and will be responsible for co-designing the Deep Demonstration "Turning Landscapes from Carbon Sources to Carbon Sinks" together with EIT Climate-KIC community. Specifically, the below described tasks and activities will aim to help on co-ordination, implementation and embed the tightly designed and iterative first stage of a four-stage process developed for Deep Demonstrations; namely the Intent with a view to understand the next phase of Frame. Learnings from the co-design approach will be used to roll out systems innovation as-a-service.
INTENT
is the set-up phase of the Deep Demonstrations process. It is designed to establish directionality, to scope needs, vision and objectives for systemic change and ultimately to agree to work together on a Deep Demonstration innovation portfolio focused on catalysing radical transformation of systems.
The key ac􀆟vi􀆟es in this part of the workplan are to:
• Agree who we will work with, on what and why
• Build a shared understanding of innovation as a point of difference that is non-linear, focused on accelerating learning and designed to surface opportunities for catalysing change in systems
• Explore, identify and agree the systems to work on and a vision of structural change to work towards
• Arrive at a joint understanding and agreement as to shared objectives, outcomes, needs, 􀆟me frames and ways of working.
FRAME
is about defining the field for innovation action, building understanding about how innovation might achieve the vision for transformation. This phase is made up of iterative steps that articulate why we want to deploy innovation, where, what to leverage and where to position ourselves to test for emerging, breakthrough
possibilities as well as scaling potential. A portfolio brief that emerges from this stage provides a frame of reference for learning and generating intelligence from innovation.
The key activities as part of this workplan include:
• Articulate where to direct innovation effort and w hy - in relation to what - what to leverage, how and why
• Identify cause and effect relationships, dependencies and opportunities to look for breakthrough possibilities
• Look beyond edges of known to usual actors, outliers, positive deviants and generating opportunities to move beyond defaults, core assumptions and biases
• Identify who could do it, why and where is appropriate
• Framing a portfolio hypothesis described in terms of inn ovation positions.
OBJECTIVES
The main objective of this co-design work is to i) engage highly motivated (a) problem owner(s); ii) identify an initial diverse portfolio of positions, in order to work
thereafter on bold and uncommon experiments; iii) learn lessons from embedding this process which can be used to catalyse further transformation.  Overaching objectives, specific to the needs of the French landscape ecosystem, will be to change organic carbon management in rural landscapes, by exploring with
possibly Planet A as a problem-owner how to increase carbon storage.

Project.Title: niche specialisation and ecological plasticity in the rumen microbiome
Project.Description:
We hypothesise that functional redundancy in the rumen microbiome has evolved to enable resilience and adaptation to
stress in changing environments. Uniquely, we propose to use a whole-microbiome approach i.e. study all microbial groups
to understand the fundamental principles that govern the microbial ecology of the rumen. We will ask the question does
ecological plasticity aid niche specialisation and resilience to changing environments? In order to assess the level of
microbial redundancy and resilience across ruminant species we will use metaomic and computational methods to analyse
the rumen microbiome of a range of wild and domestic herbivores. To assess the hypothesis that the rumen microbiome
shows niche specialisation and plasticity, we will analyse the rumen microbiome of farmed ruminants over multiple
generations and diets. We will seek to understand the role of enzyme haplotypes (enzyme family isoforms) in adaptation,
resilience and stress. We will also unravel the functional complexity of the rumen microbiome, by using long-read
sequencing to finish the assembly of rumen bacteria and archaeal genomes and develop algorithms for assembling
microbial eukaryotic genomes directly from metagenomic sequences. To further improve knowledge of the rumen
microbiome we will culture missing elements of the rumen microbiota, using state of the art culturomic technologies,
coupled with comprehensive characterisation of isolates.
Sponsor.Name: biotechnology and biological sciences research council
Scheme.Name: standard outlines
PI.Name: Michael Watson

Project.Title: border crossings: charity and voluntarism in britain's mixed economy of health care since 1948
Project.Description:
Whilst perceived as a centralised, statist service, the NHS allows scope for voluntary financial
support of its institutions, and for private provision of services outside the NHS. This has taken
several forms: teaching hospital endowments; pooled endowment funds for non-teaching hospitals;
and voluntary fundraising for individual institutions. Voluntary sector provision of health care has
also continued: several voluntary hospitals disclaimed by the state in 1948 continued in existence,
and a number of NHS hospitals have transferred back into charitable ownership.
These contributions to a public health service are little-known and our research is concerned with
the distinctive contribution they make and the challenges they pose for policy. We therefore chart
the scale, distribution and growth of these initiatives, as well as the niches which they occupy. We
analyse how policy has been framed with reference to them – in other words how the balance
between voluntary initiative and central planning has evolved over time – and we explore their role
in innovation in the delivery of health and care, and their importance in engaging the public in
supporting their local services. Overall this research programme provides novel insights into the
debatable borderlands between statutory and voluntary initiative.

Project.Title: which artificial intelligence models should we trust when mining free-text medical records?
Project.Description:
A significant amount of medical information (arguably 80-90%) resides in free-text medical records such as
progress notes and discharge summaries. It is therefore essential to interrogate free-text data both
clinically for delivering good healthcare services; and scientifically for generating new knowledge about
diseases and medicine. However, manually extracting key medical information is very time-consuming and
costly. Artificial intelligence (AI) technologies are therefore extensively used to ‘mine’ clinical notes – a
process where a machine ‘reads’ the records and automatically generate structured data. Dozens of AI
algorithms and thousands of free tools are available for mining free-text medical records. However,
choosing the right algorithms/tools and using them confidently to answer a clinical question require AI
expertise and substantial efforts in a trial and error manner. This creates a big barrier to use AI in clinical
settings efficiently and widely.
I will address this broad issue by tackling three specific problems: (1) how to ‘smartly’ reuse an AI tool that
was developed for and excels in a similar task without substantial efforts? (2) how to automatically choose
and combine potentially best-performing AI algorithms/tools to create an effective solution for a clinical
task? (3) how to generate accurate suggestions for clinicians about when to trust and when NOT to trust an
AI (and explain WHY) in clinical decision making?
To answer these questions, I will (a) conduct a theoretical study on what data characteristics associate with
AI performances; (b) create a large-scale across-UK health data testbed; (c) collect a wide-range of AI tools
and investigate their performances on 3 national high-impact case studies within the above testbed. To
empower myself with necessary competence and capacity to deliver this, I will exploit supports and facilities
provided by this Turing Fellowship to build up a word-class research team and foster my research
leadership

Project.Title: gaelic in canada: the archival record
Project.Description: As a result of mass migration from the Scottish Highlands from the second half of the eighteenth century, significant Gaelic communities were established in North America, the most important of these being in the Canadian province of Nova Scotia. These emigrant communities produced a significant amount of Gaelic print. One objective of this research is to provide the first comprehensive account of the Gaelic material in Nova Scotia English-language newspapers. A related objective is to provide a better understanding of the work of Nova Scotian Gaels who played a key role in these publishing initiatives. A third objective is to explore the archival holdings at Harvard University of Professor Charles Dunn, formerly Professor of Celtic at Harvard University, one of the most significant scholars of Gaelic in Nova Scotia The fourth objective is to provide a comprehensive account of the Gaelic Society of Toronto one of the oldest diasporic Gaelic societies and one which is still active. All four of these objectives will contribute to a wider project which I propose to undertake starting in 2021, namely a social and cultural history of Gaelic in Canada.

Project.Title: using atmospheric observation data to quantify carbon dioxide emissions from the mosaic of urban and land ecosystems within megacities
Project.Description:
Over 3.5 billion people live in urban areas. Consequently, emissions of CO2 are spatially skewed towards cities. Given the important role that cities play in carbon budgets it is crucial we develop our existing
measurement capabilities so that we have data to confidently inform the Paris Agreement global stock takes from 2023. In this proposal we will use ground-based and space-borne sensors to develop data-driven emissions of CO2 from Tokyo and London.

Quantifying city carbon budgets is extremely challenging by virtue of mosaics of CO2 fluxes from anthropogenic sectors (e.g. transportation) and natural ecosystems (e.g. parks). Care must therefore be taken to separate the natural and anthropogenic contributions to city CO2 emissions.

Tokyo is home to more than 13 million people with a population density of just over 6,300 people/km2. London has a population just shy of 9 million people but with a density of approximately 5,700 people/km2, comparable with Tokyo. Both cities are comprised of unique mosaics of anthropogenic and natural fluxes of CO2, with London having more green space than Tokyo.

We will take advantage of the recent installation of ground-based in situ and remote sensing sensors that measure atmospheric CO2 and other related trace gases over London and Tokyo. We will also use new space-borne sensors available from NASA and the Japanese space agency that have city-observing modes.

Our project is a key step towards demonstrating how to report data-driven CO2 emissions from cities.

Project.Title: harnessing genomics, pathology tissues and e-health records for earlier detection of cancer and precision medicine
Project.Description:
Background: Molecular profiling and digital images from breast pathology specimens of benign and tumour tissues are a rich data resource to identify biomarkers that might improve risk prediction models for early detection of cancer, reduce overtreatment, and define those who might most benefit from targeted treatments. Yet in order to achieve the maximum potential and benefits of such data, population-based studies are needed. 
Aims: Through this fellowship I would aim to develop a retrospective cohort of digital pathology images of benign and tumour tissue samples linked to electronic health records including hospital records, prescription data, screening mammography and cancer treatment to: 1. Identify biomarkers from benign breast disease tissues that are associated with breast cancer risk to allow early detection of cancer 2. Determine if cancer therapy effectiveness (recurrence and mortality) varies by molecular subtypes of breast cancer based on mRNA expression profiling data 3. Define the populations with poorest survival and identify biomarkers that predict survival and treatment effectiveness 
Methods: Harnessing Scotland’s rich tissue biobank resource network and longitudinal population based datasets, we have shown clearly that incidence and mortality trends differ by tumour hormone receptor expression based on 72,217 breast cancer cases diagnosed from 1997- 2016 in Scotland. We have also shown through a proof-of-principle study in NHS Lothian that 80% of breast cancer cases have a tissue sample available through the biorepository from the year 2000 on (where over 650 breast cancers are diagnosed annually). Here we would build a unique retrospective cohort of molecular pathology studies embedded in NHS Lothian. 
How this research will be used: The UK has higher number of cancer cases diagnosed per million of population and deathrates compared to other European countries: strategies to improve these statistics are needed. Cumulatively, this work would provide the data needed to determine how epidemiologic and biomarker data might define those populations at highest risk to improve survival outcomes in the UK and abroad.

Project.Title: eco-evolutionary consequences of individual heterogeneity in density dependence
Project.Description: Individuals in a population that are better suited to their environment have more offspring, contributing beneficial genetic variation to future generations. This natural selection allows populations to adapt to changing conditions over time. One important aspect of an individual’s environment is the amount of competition they face for access to resources. If individuals vary in their ability to cope with different levels of competition and this variation has a genetic basis, then the population can adapt to changing levels of competition. However, since the level of competition is a characteristic of the population itself, this generates a feedback loop. This is an example of an ‘eco-evolutionary feedback’ that affects our ability to successfully predict whether populations will increase or decline, and how they will adapt to threats such as climate change and habitat destruction. Despite their importance, we have very little idea how common these feedbacks are in nature because they are difficult to study – they require detailed studies of individuals followed over many decades, along with information on how much genetic material those individuals share. My proposal uses new approaches to study whether individuals vary in their response to population density. I will do this using data from long-term studies of 18 different populations of birds, mammals and invertebrates that have been monitored for up to 73 years. I will test for the presence of eco-evolutionary feedbacks in different species, which will help us to understand how animal populations will cope with changing environments.
