Project.Title: read: recognition and enrichment of archival documents
Project.Description: The overall objective of READ is to implement a Virtual Research Environment where archivists, humanities scholars, computer scientists and volunteers are collaborating with the ultimate goal of boosting research, innovation, development and usage of cutting edge technology for the automated recognition, transcription, indexing and enrichment of handwritten archival documents. This Virtual Research Environment will not be built from the ground up, but will benefit from research, tools, data and resources generated in multiple national and EU funded research and development projects and provide a basis for sustaining the network and the technology in the future. This ICT based e-infrastructure will address the Societal Challenge mentioned in Europe in a Changing World namely the "transmission of European cultural heritage" and the "uses of the past" as one of the core requirements of a reflective society. Based on research and innovation enabled by the READ Virtual Research Environment we will be able to explore and access hundreds of kilometres of archival documents via fulltext search and therefore be able to open up one of the last hidden treasures of Europe's rich cultural hertitage.

Project.Title: an economic history of victorian scotch whisky, 1860-1916
Project.Description: This project aims at a comprehensive economic history of the Scotch Whisky industry for the period starting with the relaxation of the Excise regime in 1860 and ending with the introduction of wartime restrictions on the distillation of cereals in 1916. The book will cover aspects of both production and consumption, draw upon a wealth of previously unpublished primary sources resident in private collections, and create a price-maturity database for Scotch and Irish Whisky for this period. It will analyse the processes by which the Scotch Whisky industry developed from a small-scale, batch, “artisanal” activity mostly catering to local consumption, into an increasingly sophisticated industrial and commercial operation that targeted export markets for its continuing growth with elaborate marketing and branding techniques. The reported bubble and crash of 1898-99, with the collapse of Leith blender Pattisons Ltd as its centrepiece, forms a pivotal point of this analysis.

Project.Title: the organization of economic life in modern korea: rethinking empire, development, and capitalism in the twentieth century
Project.Description:
Economic change in twentieth-century Korea has been highly politicised, occurring under extremes of
Japanese imperialism, communist autarky, and authoritarian capitalist development. Yet, viewed from the
perspective of everyday life, such political extremes frequently played out through mundane details: the
cultivation of cotton over barley, or the provision of loans for fertiliser. This project examines the Korean
economy from the bottom up, to question how ordinary Koreans understood their place in a turbulent
economic order, as well as the various impacts of, and responses to, empire, capitalism, and development in
everyday life. I trace the activities of three economic and social organizations—colonial-era agricultural
organizations, traditional community organizations (kye), and cooperatives—to examine the material extension
of government policy through various regulations and organizations. Overall, I challenge state-centric accounts
of Korean development, highlighting also the role of organizations in shaping the scope and possibilities of
economic life in the twentieth century.

Project.Title: linkage of national primary and secondary care data to determine rate, causes and risk factors for epilepsy-related death in adults
Project.Description: BACKGROUND: Epilepsy is an important condition globally, affecting 70 million people worldwide. Although people with epilepsy are subject to the same causes of death as everyone else, they are actually more likely to die because of their epilepsy itself, e.g. when seizures cause accidents in cars or drowning in pools. All such deaths linked to epilepsy are called epilepsy-related deaths. It is thought that many epilepsy-related deaths may be avoidable through, for example, reducing the number of seizures a person has to zero by using medications. This is important because it would mean a person with epilepsy is then no more likely to die than anyone else. Epilepsy-related deaths are therefore the focus of this current project. AIMS: I aim to figure out how many epilepsy-related deaths occur per year, what things cause or make them more likely to occur. METHODS: The study is to be conducted in Scotland and will be enabled by us obtaining information about people's epilepsy and why they died from it from what are called "administrative health databases". These are electronic records containing information collected about NHS users, for the purposes of improving NHS care. Researchers like myself can access the information, with a view to learning lessons about disease from it. We have to follow very strict data safety procedures to be allowed to access the information, and great care is taken to ensure confidential information isn't revealed to us. I will obtain information about people who have died with epilepsy from several administrative databases, and combine that with information obtained from their medical records and death certificates. That way, I will build up a more in-depth picture of what may have been the issues that lead to death and what could have been done to stop it. I will use these sources to figure out whether or not death was caused by epilepsy. This will allow me to count up the number of epilepsy-related deaths that have occurred over a seven year period (2009 to 2016) and describe what caused them. In order to figure out what things will have made them more likely to occur, I will compare information from medical records of people who died of epilepsy-related death to information from the medical records of people alive with epilepsy, of a similar age to the deceased when they died. The information from medical records of both groups will be provided to me by the hospital consultants looking after epilepsy. Comparing information about those who died with epilepsy to those who are still alive may highlight important differences, eg differences in how they were looked after. This may teach us important lessons about future epilepsy care. IMPACT: Overall, the study will give researchers a better understanding of how frequently epilepsy-related deaths occur, and what things cause or make them more likely to occur. This information could be used to help set policies to help reduce epilepsy-related deaths in future. The method used (of linking several administrative databases to death certificates and medical records) is unique and could be a helpful method for other researchers to use. The data we have provided could be used by other researchers after obtaining the same data safety training as we have, and therefore the study would help make other people's research easier to conduct.

PI.Name: Richard Chin

Project.Title: pig stem cell-derived macrophages as a novel experimental and translational platform for combating economically important pig viruses
Project.Description:
Domesticated pigs are a leading source of animal protein for the humans across the world, and accordingly securing the
productivity of pig farming is a global imperative. Currently, commercial pig farming faces severe threats from two highly
transmissible viral diseases, African Swine Fever Virus (ASFV) and Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus
(PRRSV). ASFV causes a haemorrhagic fever that has a mortality rate of 90-100%, is highly contagious and can be
transmitted directly by contact with infected pigs or pig meat. There is no effective vaccine against ASFV, and the only
assured methods for controlling its spread are strict containment and culling of infected herds; a strategy that has severe welfare implications and very high economic costs. Interestingly, ASFV is endemic to Sub-Saharan Africa where it is
carried by the native wild pig species including the warthog and Red River Hog, animals that tolerate ASFV and act as a
natural reservoir and potent source of virus infection for local domestic pigs. An ASFV outbreak in Georgia in 2007 has
since spread across Europe and Asia, threatening commercial pig production across these continents. Clearly,
understanding the interaction between ASFV and its hosts and experimental systems to test effective counter-measures,
such as vaccines, are urgently required to control the spread of ASFV.
In comparison with ASFV, PRRSV is less virulent, but is widespread in commercial pig herds causing abortions in pregnant
sows, high morbidity and mortality in piglets, and is currently the most economically important virus pathogen in pig farming
- costing > 1 billion Euros annually in Europe. Combating PRRSV infection is therefore a critical issue for commercial pig
farming.
The preferred cellular host for ASFV and PRRSV is the pig macrophage, a white blood cell that is the first line defence
against infections. Existing culture systems for studying ASFV or PRRSV rely either on primary macrophage cultures
prepared from pigs or immortalised cell lines - both of which have significant limitations. We have recently developed a
novel pig cell culture model in which we convert pig stem cell lines into normal macrophages. These pig stem cells can be
propagated in large numbers, can be genetically modified, and can be induced as needed into cultures that produce
macrophages for 6-8 weeks. These cultured macrophages exhibit the key characteristics of the equivalent cells isolated
from pigs, including expression of macrophage specific genes, ingestion of bacterial particles and infection by macrophage
pathogens. In parallel we have generated stem cell lines from the ASFV tolerant Red River Hog - and also produced
macrophages from this wild pig. Importantly, our initial experiments indicate that macrophages from the African pig exhibit
greater tolerance to ASFV, compared with the cells derived from the domestic pig, mirroring the response in the two types
of pigs.
In this proposal we will characterise this unique new cell culture system, directly comparing ASFV and PRRSV infection in
the macrophages of domestic and the Red River Hog. The proposal has two main objectives: 1) To investigate the
molecular basis of why Red River Hogs are resilient to ASFV, by comparing how domestic pig and Red River Hog cultured
macrophages respond to ASFV (and PRRSV) infection; and 2) To develop cultured macrophage production for larger
scale, high through-put assays and vaccine propagation.
The development of this novel cell culture system has potential relevance for devising strategies for combating the spread
of ASFV and PRRSV in commercial pig herds, in particular the development and propagation of effective vaccines. The
approach also has a broader relevance and applications in livestock research for improving farming efficiency generally,
has implications for livestock welfare and is clearly in accordance with 3R objectives to reduce, refine and replace animals
in research.

Project.Title: effect and interaction of mutation and recombination in the dynamics of genetic variation in modern chickens
Project.Description:
Resolving how genetic variation is maintained in closed populations under directional selection is one of the fundamental,
yet still open questions in quantitative genetics. Addressing this question has also vital implications for the sustainability of
genetic improvement programmes that underpin global staple food production systems. Considerable research effort has
focused on studying how selection reduces genetic variation and how its footprint can be identified in the genome. Little
effort has been placed to study how genetic variation is de-novo created and shuffled across generations. The reason is
that until now, it was not feasible to track mutation, the evolutionary force creating new genetic variation, on the large-scale
that analysis required, due to technological and economic constraints. The only option available to geneticists was to rely
on low precision estimates for the mutation rate, since they mostly arose from small scale studies in experimental populations. These parameters then would be used in models aiming to describe the dynamics of genetic variation, which
were based on many theoretical assumptions due to lack of data on the observed rate of mutation. The uncertainty of the
parameters used, combined with our limited understanding of the interplay of forces on standing variation, reduce the
power of our current models to capture the underlying processes and therefore, explain why "there is still no clear
resolution on the evolutionary forces responsible for the maintenance of variation", as one of the gold standard textbooks in
Quantitative Genetics (Lynch and Walsh, 2018) emphatically states.
The main hypothesis of this proposal is that the rate of creation and shuffling of genetic variation is sufficient to
counterbalance the effect of selection, genetic drift and inbreeding in finite closed populations. Our goal is to take a datadriven approach to quantify with unprecedented accuracy the mutation and recombination processes that could explain
how genetic variation appears to be maintained in closed populations that are under intense directional selection. To
achieve this aim, we will use a unique genomic repository consisting of hundreds of thousands of birds (either sequenced
in high-depth or genotyped with SNP arrays) extending over 25 generations with full pedigree and phenotypic information
to study how genetic variation is maintained over time. This dataset gives us the required power to precisely estimate
important parameters, such as how many mutational events occur per generation, where they tend to occur across the
genome, and how the new genetic variation due to mutation balances its removal. As our data extend over many
generations, we will have the power to track both mutations and haplotypes through the pedigree in order to remove false
positive observations that can inflate estimates. Our study will also focus on quantifying recombination, as the force
shuffling genetic variation, and we will explore its interplay with mutation. Finally, we will apply our more precise estimates
to update theoretical expectations on where selection limits may lay aiming to reconcile theoretical predictions and
observations. Beyond the potential to address the key question of how genetic variation is maintained, our findings could
be directly applicable across animal and plant breeding organisations to improve the resilience and sustainability of their
genetic improvement programmes.

Project.Title: environmental influences on stillbirth: a population record linkage study in scotland
Project.Description:
Reducing stillbirth is a key priority for the NHS and health policy.  More than 50% of stillbirths are currently unexplained and further research is necessary to determine new risk factors for stillbirth and identity pregnancies at risk.  The purpose of this work is to determine how the environment a woman is exposed to during pregnancy affects the health of the mum and the baby.  In particular, we examine these environmental exposures that occur before the onset of labour in an otherwise normally formed baby.  The link between environmental factors such as sunlight exposure, high and low temperatures and air pollution and stillbirth has not yet been studied in depth in a UK population.  However, hostile environments are known to be associated with early (preterm) birth and growth problems in babies.  Data recently produced by our group has shown that sunlight exposure in the first trimester (up to 12 weeks) of pregnancy is actually associated with a lower risk of preterm birth.  In the past, it has been difficult to accurately measure these environmental factors due to difficulty in collecting the information however in this proposal we can link individual level postcode information from health records to corresponding geographical environmental records.   This has been performed successfully by our group previously.  By linking the routinely collected Scottish maternity record, the SMR02, to the baby record (SBR) and the environmental data we will create a database in which we can study the environmental effects on pregnancy outcome.  We can also obtain other key information from this approach about the pregnancy which may mask the relationship we are trying to study such as maternal age, height, weight and information about the baby including birthweight.  Importantly the Scottish birth databases are unique in the UK in that they also give us information on maternal smoking which is a key risk factor in stillbirth and can obscure the relationship between air pollution and stillbirth.  Taking these factors into account when performing the final analysis of the data gives us a more accurate estimate of the association between stillbirth and the environment.

We envisage that the results of this study will improve our understanding of possible risk factors for stillbirth and therefore public health guidance for pregnant women.  The database will also provide a unique opportunity to look at other pregnancy outcomes associated with environmental exposures.  If we find significant associations, the results can be used to carry out further definitive studies to understand these associations and if appropriate trial new treatments, for example in the form of UV light therapy.

The results of this study will be used to inform policymakers and clinicians by providing information on risk factors for stillbirth, identify pregnancies at high risk of stillbirth and providing guidance on optimal management to try to reduce fetal death and complications.

Project.Title: the impact of primary and secondary epithelial senescence on renal function and fibrosis
Project.Description:
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) affects over 850 million people worldwide. It is a disease process which occurs in the kidneys after injury and causes the kidneys to become scarred; a term we call 'fibrosis'.  Injuries can range from simple things; like short periods of infection and low blood pressure to more complicated and rarer diseases which affect the kidney tissue itself. Regardless of the initial injury and regardless of this initial injury going away completely, we believe that the kidney is permanently damaged. Often we don't measure this in blood or urine tests; these become normal again. But we know from observational data that having even one such episode, even if brief and completely resolved, puts a person at significantly higher risk of developing CKD.  CKD is often progressive; meaning that it gets worse over time. At present, we don't have any treatments to stop or slow this progression and this can ultimately lead to complete kidney failure and the requirement for regular dialysis or kidney transplantation.  We also know that in individuals with CKD, although the scarring is in the kidneys, their chance of heart disease, and death from heart disease is significantly increased.

There are certain processes and cellular changes which occur in response to these injuries (not just in a kidney, but in other organs too) which we believe contribute to this progressive scarring.  If they can be targeted and blocked it could prevent this inevitable scar formation. 

This PhD will focus on one such pathway, and a group of cells; called 'senescent cells'. These are cells which are damaged but do not die in a normal programmed way. Furthermore, we know that these cells communicate with other cells in the body to promote scarring. We find senescent cells in human kidneys in lots of different kidney diseases, we find them in older kidneys and we find them around the time of kidney injury. So far; we know that we can treat and remove these cells safely in a mouse then that mouse lives a longer and healthier life. If we can study these cells and their signalling pathways in greater detail we believe this would be a potentially very successful treatment and would impact significantly on human kidney disease.

Project.Title: ecoclim: ecological responses to climate warming across biomes - ecological stability as community thermophilization linked to species thermal traits
Project.Description:
Climate change is impacting biodiversity across the planet in the largest and fastest environmental shift in recent geological history. In this proposal, we aim to determine how species traits (primarily thermal traits) promote community stability in the face of this unprecedented change. Understanding the consequences of these changes, including effects on biotic interactions, demands an understanding of mechanisms at species level. We propose to use a combination of data synthesis and field case studies to analyse warming-related long-term changes in community structure. Such changes, due to range shifts and the decline in cold-affinity species and increase in warm-affinity ones, are here termed 'thermophilization'.

We aim to compare rates of thermophilization in ecological communities across multiple biomes at large scales addressing four hypotheses. 1. Communities comprised of species with wide temperature ranges will change less than those composed of narrow-ranged ones; 2. Communities made up of species with contrasting thermal affinities will change faster than those with similar ones; 3. Communities whose species have affinities to environments cooler than the location considered will be more susceptible to warming. 4. Species traits, including body size, dispersal and longevity, will influence thermophilization rates beyond expectations 1-3. Our consortium consists of marine and terrestrial ecologists aiming for general rules applicable across biomes and those specific to example ecosystems: North Atlantic fish, plankton and coastal biota, Arctic tundra, Great Barrier Reef coral reefs and communities studied by project partners. Species thermal ranges from distribution models using global data in biodiversity databases (such as OBIS and GBIF) will be used to calculate weighted-mean thermal affinities (Community Temperature Index, CTI) for measuring thermophilization rates. Expectations for hypotheses 1-4 will be developed using community simulation models based on species thermal performance curves for abundance. Effects on ecosystems will be assessed by scaling up from species traits to novel estimates of functioning, from productivity in plant communities through trophic structure on coral reefs and biogeochemical fluxes in North Sea benthos.

PI Mike Burrows (SAMS) will extract thermal traits using species distribution models combining climate measures and habitat information. Co-Is Maria Dornelas and Anne Magurran (St Andrews) will use the BIOTIME database of community time series to examine global patterns of biodiversity change, and will lead the field case study of community re-assembly following the recent mass thermal disturbance among reef corals. Co-I Isla Myers-Smith (Edinburgh) will address how the principles apply to Arctic tundra communities, and Co-I Martin Edwards (MBA) will do the same for North Atlantic plankton.
Subcontractors John Pinnegar, Bryony Townhill and Clement Garcia (Cefas) will examine change in European shellfish and invertebrate communities to incorporate findings into different management scenarios. Finally, our network of international project partners will test our primary hypotheses and models in a range of contrasting ecosystems.
The proposal will deliver operational metrics of the response of ecological communities to climate change across multiple ecosystems, evidence for the strength of response to changing climate so far, and a solid theoretical and analytical framework for projecting expected shifts in community composition and structure under future climate change. We will extend these responses to ecosystem scales by scaling up through species functional traits and altered interactions to novel estimates of functioning.

Project.Title: improving the wellbeing of mothers through early recognition and treatment of bleeding after childbirth: obstetric bleeding study 3 (obs3) a cluster randomised trial
Project.Description:
WHAT IS THE HEALTH CARE NEED? Unusually heavy bleeding after childbirth affects about 40000 women a year in the UK and is called postpartum haemorrhage. For 5000 of these women the bleeding can be very serious leading to about 320 women having a hysterectomy and 700 admissions to intensive care each year. As a result about 18000 women suffer symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder every year.
SUPPORTING RESEARCH Heavy bleeding after childbirth is caused by obstetric complications but may be worsened by blood clotting problems. We have shown that a clotting factor called fibrinogen is crucial for controlling bleeding after childbirth. Women who start bleeding and have a low level of fibrinogen are more likely to go on to very severe bleeding. A major problem when treating bleeding after childbirth is that results of standard blood clotting tests take more than an hour to become available. To address this we looked at whether bedside clotting tests, which give results in 10 mins, could be used to guide treatment with fibrinogen and prevent unnecessary transfusion of blood products. During our research the number of very severe bleeds at our hospital fell from a UK average of 6 per 1000 births to 2 per 1000 births. To share learning, we started an All Wales Quality Improvement project called OBS Cymru. This is a package of care that includes accurately measuring the amount of bleeding and early bedside clotting tests. The package of care is designed to recognise abnormal bleeding early and to prevent small bleeds becoming very severe bleeds through early treatment of both the underlying cause of bleeding and any blood clotting problems. As a result, blood transfusion and severe bleeding after child birth has fallen by 25% across Wales. Although results of OBS Cymru are very encouraging, our confidence in them is limited by the lack of a comparison group or cost analysis. At present bedside clotting tests are only recommended in research settings and they will only be recommended in national guidelines if good clinical trial evidence shows their benefit. Rigorous testing is needed to see whether bedside clotting testing, within a holistic care pathway, reduces severe bleeding and is value for money. 
PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT Local patient groups have told us that avoiding a blood transfusion is important to them. They have also said that post-traumatic stress disorder caused by severe bleeding is a major issue and so looking into this will be an important part of the study. 
STUDY DESIGN We will allocate maternity units to either the OBS Cymru package of care or standard NHS care. The units will be allocated randomly to make sure the two groups are similar and can be compared. The package of care includes: 
-	Accurate measurement of blood loss to ensure early recognition of bleeding so senior clinicians can treat the cause of the bleeding
-	Standardised paperwork to help make sure that treatment follows guidelines
-	Early diagnosis and treatment of abnormal clotting guided by bedside tests
-	Units will be audited every 3 months so they know how well they are doing and to help make the package of care part of routine practice 
MAIN OUTCOME We will measure the number of women with severe bleeding defined by one or more of the following: death, hysterectomy, blood transfusion or admission to intensive care. We will also study psychological impact and cost effectiveness. 
AIM Our aim is to reduce severe bleeding after childbirth

Project.Title: reconciling volcanic forcing and climate records throughout the last millennium (vol-clim)
Project.Description:
Volcanic eruptions are an important driver of climate variability and climate change, yet climate model simulations do not agree with data on the magnitude of temperature changes caused by large-magnitude volcanic eruptions. The Vol-Clim project will resolve this discrepancy by deriving new and improved estimates of volcanic forcing using a state-of-the-art Earth System Model developed in the UK (UKESM1), which will allow us to quantify and better understand how large explosive volcanic eruptions affected the climate system since 1250 CE. The model explicitly accounts for the interaction of chemical, dynamical and aerosol microphysical processes during volcanic eruptions, all of which affect the magnitude of the climate response. However, these processes have not been taken into account in previous assessments of climate change and natural climate variability caused by volcanic eruptions since 1250 CE.

In detail, at least 60 volcanic eruptions have been detected based on volcanic deposits in polar ice-cores since 1250 CE.
Large-magnitude eruptions emit sulphur dioxide high into the stratosphere where it is oxidized to form sulphuric acid
vapour, which nucleates and condenses to form sulphate aerosol particles. These aerosol particles scatter and absorb energy from the Sun thereby cooling the Earth's surface. In terms of the magnitude of this surface cooling, tree-rings (and other data) appear to show a smaller hemispheric temperature response (of up to 1 degree Celsius) to volcanic eruptions than simulated by current climate models. This mismatch means that at present we do not fully understand how the climate system including clouds responds after volcanic eruptions. We also do not fully understand how tree growth and subsequently tree-rings respond as a consequence of the cooling induced by a volcanic eruption. Overall, these uncertainties affect our ability to use climate models to simulate past, present and future changes of climate.

Current climate models have simple implementations of volcanic effects, ignoring many key chemical and physical
processes relevant after volcanic eruptions. Using UKESM1 we will be able to simulate the evolution of volcanic aerosol
particles with unprecedented sophistication, which has the potential to greatly improve the fidelity of predicted climatic
effects and reconcile model-simulated and observational records of climate change after volcanic eruptions. Our
simulations in UKESM1 will cover the period 1250 CE to present, which will enable us to characterize and evaluate annual to centennial-scale effects on global and hemispheric surface temperatures, climate variability and impacts on surface ocean temperatures for eruptions of different frequencies and intensities. 

Vol-Clim is an ambitious project that aligns closely with international initiatives and NERC's main goals. Quantifying the contribution of volcanic eruptions to climate variability over the past millennium is key to understanding present day and future decadal-scale climate variability; this is in line with NERC's main goal 'to understand and predict how the planet works'. Vol-Clim will also help prepare society for the effects of future eruptions. Vol-Clim is also strongly aligned to international activities such as the new Past Global Changes (PAGES) working group "Volcanic Impacts on Climate and Society (VICS)" and the PMIP (Paleoclimate Modelling Intercomparison Project) and CMIP (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project) communities. We will generate a volcanic aerosol forcing time-series (1250 CE to present) for use in those models that do not account for the chemical and physical aerosol processes in the stratosphere. These deliverables are relevant for CMIP6-endorsed activities such as VolMIP (Model Inter-comparison Project on the Climatic Response to Volcanic Forcing) and RFMIP (Radiative Forcing Model Inter-comparison Project), and also the IPCC.

Project.Title: entirely out of character?: secondary dynamics of nonlinear waves
Project.Description:
Waves often exhibit changes in their form during evolution, owing to nonlinear processes. This behaviour is
shown to be tied to properties of the original wave - namely, the conservation laws it satisfies (such as
preserving its mass) and quantities known as characteristics. Following the wave in a frame moving with a
speed equal to a characteristic unearths these nonlinear effects, which are determined by properties of this
characteristic. This understanding is used to investigate several important wave problems including
wave resonances, wave-current interactions and rogue wave formation, providing insights into the mechanisms
leading to the forms and events observed.

Project.Title: socio-ecological dynamics of infectious disease at the livestock-human-wildlife interface.
Project.Description:
Wildlife diseases affect livestock, hunting, and conservation interests and involve
anthropogenic decisions that affect and are affected by disease transmission and associated risks. These
coupled systems generally involve multiple hosts distributed over geographically and socioeconomically
heterogeneous landscapes. These complexities create many challenges for resource managers tasked with
constructing coherent, cost-effective and workable disease control strategies. Our proposed research is
designed to address these challenges by investigating the overarching research question "How do the
spatio-temporal dynamics of infectious disease transmission interact with human risk responses to
influence risk-management decisions for complex disease networks that bridge natural and managed
landscapes?".Specifically, our cross-disciplinary team will investigate: (i) how animal and land use
management decisions over geographically and socioeconomically heterogeneous landscapes create or
mitigate disease risks to wildlife and livestock, and how these effects and associated risk-management
opportunities differ across landscapes and from those in aspatial settings; (ii) the natural cross-system
"communities" that influence decision-making and control; (iii) the important socioeconomic-ecological
tradeoffs for managing disease risks in complex spatial networks with different characteristics, and how
targeted management strategies might be developed to reflect these tradeoffs. Conceptually, we will
develop a spatial, "multiscale socioeconomic-ecological multi-layer network" framework to understand
the epidemiological, population, and behavioral dynamic interactive feedbacks among the economic and
ecological subsystems. Using bioeconomic modeling and adaptive management approaches, we will
examine cost-effective management in this complex setting. Further insights will be gained via two case
studies: (a) bovine tuberculosis in Michigan deer and cattle; (b) brucellosis in Greater Yellowstone Area
(GYA) elk and cattle along with potential chronic wasting disease in GYA elk

Project.Title: reconstructing residence patterns in neolithic scotland
Project.Description: The transition to farming Europe is frequently thought of as being accompanied by a decline in residential mobility, with farmers becoming sedentary to enable the cultivation of crops. In turn, a settled farming life is often assumed to have formed the basis for agricultural intensification and for the development of increasingly complex societies. Recently, however, the application of new scientific techniques has started to challenge this viewpoint. Strontium and sulphur isotope analysis help us to evaluate where an individual obtained their childhood diet. Use of these techniques has begun to provide evidence for cultural diversity in settlement patterns during the Neolithic in different regions of Europe. Scotland has, however, remained under-represented in the application of such techniques. By undertaking analysis on assemblages dating from the start of agriculture to the later Neolithic in this region, from the 4th to the 3rd millennium BC, this project will provide direct evidence for the nature of land use and mobility patterns during the Neolithic in Scotland.

Project.Title: reconciling the mystical body: louisiana catholics and desegregation, 1945-1976
Project.Description: The study examines why, how and to what extent Louisiana Catholic institutions desegregated, and how Catholics responded to secular desegregation in the South's most Catholic state. It challenges sociological conceptions of Catholic hierarchy and analyses the complex response of clergy, nuns, and laity, whether integrationist, segregationist, white, mixed race, or African American. The Archdiocese of New Orleans contained the South's largest Catholic population, the Diocese of Lafayette the most African American Catholics in the nation, and the Diocese of Alexandria lay in often hostile and overwhelmingly Protestant, northern Louisiana, yet there is no monograph about Catholic desegregation in Louisiana.

Project.Title: retrospective cohort study of prescription of medication for mental health conditions in epilepsy and seizure frequency, health care resource utilisation and mortality: innovative and cost-efficient use of routinely collected data with health economics assessment
Project.Description: Epilepsy, one of the most common neurological conditions, affects 50 million people of all ages worldwide. People with epilepsy (PWE) often have comorbid mental health conditions including psychoses (in 6%), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) (in 20-50%) and depression (in 35%). Yet PWE with these mental health conditions often receive no medication for them because of concerns they may worsen seizure control, increase health care utilization (General Practice consultations, referral to hospital epilepsy specialists, hospital attendances) (HCRU), and cause premature death. There is insufficient information available to clarify whether concerns are justified. Good quality studies on the subject are urgently needed. This study will be the first to provide accurate estimates of changes in seizure frequency, HCRU or death risk in PWE after being prescribed medication for psychoses, ADHD and or depression. Study results will help patients and clinicians make better-informed decisions on pros and cons of using medications for psychoses, ADHD and or depression in PWE. All patients and members of the public we consulted thought our proposal important. We will take an innovative cost-efficient approach of using and analysing existing "Big Data" from general practices and national data sources, rather than carrying out a randomised controlled trial. Whilst often considered the "gold standard" in medical research, trials often exclude patients because they have several co-occurring medical conditions. "Big Data" on the other hand are obtained on almost everyone in natural, routine clinical practice. Compared to trials, "Big Data" can provide findings more relevant to everyday clinical practice, potentially offer much larger patient numbers, and include a wider patient group with a number of different conditions. We have an experienced team and will build on earlier work that shows proof of concept that we can do this study. We will obtain and use anonymised data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD), linked with hospital attendance information from the national Hospital Episode Statistics and death records from the Office of National Statistics. CPRD is one of the world's largest holders of computerised electronic health records from general practitioners. It provides regular quality checks on each surgery to ensure their practice data are up-to-standard for research. It provides a representative sample of the UK population so study results will be generalisable to the entire UK. The latest set of linked CPRD data includes more than 10 million patients from more than 400 practices. A statutory trusted third party will carry out data linkage, and only anonymised data to protect patient confidentiality will be transferred safely and securely to the research team. We will assess the seizure frequency, HCRU and risk of death in a) ALL PWE and b) PWE with mental ill health prior to prescription of medication for psychoses,ADHD and or depression and compare with after they have received prescriptions. To check whether observations are specific to PWE, we will repeat analyses in patients without epilepsy and assess their HCRU and death risk before and after prescriptions. We will consider potential factors that may affect or provide alternative explanations for findings. HCRU cost before and after prescriptions will be determined. Results will be applicable for patient care within 24 months of study completion

Project.Title: international: integrating globally-recognised sustainability metrics for tropical perennial crops in a one-stop shop cool farm tool
Project.Description:
We will develop a fully integrated environmental decision support tool for tropical perennial crops and deliver a full technical specification for inclusion into the online, and freely available Cool Farm Tool. The Cool Farm Tool is owned by the Cool Farm Alliance (CFA) who will partner on this project. It is a business-led initiative to assess and improve the sustainability of agriculture-based supply chains. It is funded via a membership model, with membership consisting of over 50 companies including for example major multinationals such as Unilever, PepsiCo, Heineken, Danone, Nestle, Marks and Spencer, and Tesco. Members pay to maintain the tool and deploy at scale in their supply chains but it is a core principle of the Alliance that the tool is and will always be free-to-use for farmers.
The CFT itself is a science-based decision support tool designed for use by farmers at farm scale. It has benefitted from significant NERC Discovery and Innovation funding in the past and as a result includes a growing suite of metrics for crop and livestock systems in an expanding set of geographic locations (over 100 countries). Several case studies have shown the impact that has been derived using the tool, for example PepsiCo's "50-in-5" (http://pepsico.co.uk/live/story/celebrating-sustainable-farming) and egg production in North America resulting in a 25% reduction in the carbon footprint from primary production (Vetter et al 2018).
Tropical perennial crops are of huge importance to global food supply chains and typically have high dependence on smallholder farmers in DAC countries where decision-support has been hindered less scientific evidence and the focus of researchers in temperate regions. This project build on numerous previous NERC and Wellcome Trust outputs and exploits established successful relationships between the project partners to ensure delivery. We will develop modules based around the existing CFT methods to allow a one-stop shop assessment tool for carbon and water footprinting and biodiversity impacts of farm practice in tropical perennials. Through partnership with the Cool Farm Alliance and the £5.4M Wellcome Trust funded SHEFS project we will ensure delivery of a tool which has practical value to farmers and supply chains. This business-led, science-based, and farmer-focused project will thereby provide robust metrics which will allow farmers to engage and demonstrate their positive actions for sustainability into international supply chains, and the businesses to identify good practices to embed in their sustainable sourcing strategies. The possibility to combine, in a single decision support tool, the multiple impacts of farm practices is attractive for many reasons, not least being that it will reduce the current burden on farmers to conduct multiple assessments of dubious value on multiple impacts for multiple buyers.

Project.Title: arrest-tb: accurate, rapid, robust and economical diagnostic technologies for tuberculosis
Project.Description:
Infectious diseases
Tuberculosis diagnostics, TB, Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, MTBC, Mycobacterium
tuberculosis, MTB, Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis, MDR TB, Triage tests, Molecular method for TB,
microRNA,

This visionary project addresses the key needs of patients, clinicians and the World Health Organisations stated
deliverables of affordable, reliable and point-of-care molecular TB diagnostics, with the vision of removing the need for
centralised facilities and offering remote primary care diagnosis coupled with telemetry for “cloud based” notification to
ensure public health and surveillance interventions. The core technology deliverables will include: Rapid screening of TB
infection (within 30 mins): We will develop low-cost portable optical devices and chemical molecular probes for accurate and
rapid ‘triage tests’ to allow ‘no-wash’ detection of Mycobacteria ‘in-field’ in sputum at costs comparable with or lower than
existing microscopy-based methods. This technology has the aim of replacing current sputum-based microscopy methods.
Rapid molecular identification of drug resistance (within 2 hours): We will develop novel low-cost assays based on molecular
methods that will allow accurate and rapid screening for the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex in sputum and drugresistant
tuberculosis, thus providing rapid screening of at risk groups for TB as well as identification of drug resistance
profiles. Biomarkers for early diagnosis and assessing treatment response: A higher risk element is the development of
point-of-care diagnostics for quantification of microRNAs (that are known to be modulated during progression from latent to
active TB and during treatment progression), directly from small blood samples. We will ensure that the technologies are
economically viable in the context of resource poor settings – indeed the whole project will be driven by practical need and
local resourcing constraints – NOT imposition. Thus it will requiring negligible initial costs for implementation, minimal
training and expertise, with the running costs less than 1/10 th of current detection technologies, thereby addressing a key
objective of the work program.

Project.Title: iatlantic: integrated assessment of atlantic marine ecosystems in space and time
Project.Description:
iAtlantic will take an interdisciplinary scientific approach to unifying stakeholder efforts to better inform sustainable
management and enhance human and observational capacity throughout the Atlantic. The integration of ecosystem data
with major circulation pathways connecting the North and South linked with climatic data and forecasts provides a systematic
approach to jointly assess and tackle policy challenges. Ocean physics and ecosystem connectivity will enable highresolution
oceanographic hindcasts and forecasts of future circulation together with ground-truthing genomic data. Advances
in eDNA genomics, machine learning and autonomous underwater robotics will be combined with existing data to provide a
step-changes in predictive habitat mapping approaches to expand species and biodiversity observations from local to basinscales.
Ecological timeseries, including innovative palaeoceanographic and genomic reconstructions, will provide an
unprecedented view of the impacts of climate change on Atlantic ecosystems. Assessment of the impact of multiple
stressors will identify key drivers of ecosystem change and tipping points. New data will come from 12 carefully selected
regions in the deep sea and open ocean that are of international conservation significance and of interest to Blue Economy
and Blue Growth sectors. Innovative and efficient data handling and data publishing approaches will establish a better
integrated Atlantic Ocean observation data community. Capacity and cooperation between science, industry and
policymakers bordering the Atlantic will be boosted by joint multi-disciplinary research cruises, enhanced S Atlantic
monitoring arrays, scientific training events, iAtlantic Fellowships and industry focussed workshops. Results will be used to
stimulate dialogue with stakeholders and critically assess current ocean governance frameworks generating increased
capacity for Marine Spatial Planning and enabling Blue Growth scenarios to be rapidly evaluated.

Project.Title: socioeconomic-based metrics in disaster management to put vulnerable people first
Project.Description:
Natural disasters and the vulnerability of a population go hand in hand. We cannot understand the level of a disaster without grasping the extent of people’s vulnerability.
But how can we ensure that our assessment of vulnerability is both accurate and just?
In this project we propose to examine socioeconomic indicators, such as gender, age, race, and income to evaluate the overall vulnerability of a given community or geographical area. Equipped with the results of this assessment, we will build quantitative models to help policymakers and disaster managers to justify the selective targeting of specific communities over others. In doing so we hope to develop a tool with which to improve several logistics activities in complex humanitarian crises characterised by socioeconomically inequitable environments towards a more objective decision-making, avoiding decisions solely based on political biases.

Project.Title: social inequalities in the creative economy over time and place: connecting workforce, programming and consumption
Project.Description:
The creative economy is often celebrated for its contribution to the economy, in the form of job creation, the night-time
economy, cultural tourism, and intellectual property. It contributes to policy and practice in terms of urban regeneration, education, and soft power diplomacy, as well as quality of life and life satisfaction. It is feted as being a driver for social mobility, and for the progressiveness and belief in meritocracy of the workforce. However, research has also revealed the significant exclusions from this picture: the creative workforce demonstrates substantial inequalities in terms of social class origin, gender and ethnicity. Moreover, existing research has demonstrated the low chances people from working class origins have of entering the creative economy workforce did not change significantly between 1981 and 2011, despite huge changes in the social structure of English society. Cultural  consumption too is strongly stratified according to social class and ethnic group. The lack of representativeness amongst those that that create and commission of culture is the subject of sustained debate in public, policy and industry circles. There are also important inequalities in the geographical distribution of cultural investments.
This research builds on recent AHRC-funded projects to explore each of these dimensions of exclusions from the creative economy in turn, in three linked work packages.

Project.Title: assessing the accessibility of universities in city region ecosystems
Project.Description:
The aim of this Policy Expo is to examine the accessibility of universities within city region ecosystems, from the perspective of firms (public, private, and third sectors), policymakers, and academics. This will allow a thorough examination of the extent of their networks, with a focus on their structure and spatial reach. Thus, factors that both facilitate and block the formation of collaborative links will be examined from the perspectives of all actors involved. 

Based on a case study of four city regions in the UK and Sweden, this proposal speaks to the contemporary city region agenda, aiming to advance the state of our knowledge about the regional economic development role of universities through examining: how accessible they are to other organisations; policies towards promoting their embeddedness; extra-city region links; and the validity of a city region approach to promoting university interaction.

Project.Title: joining fin with tech: the relationships between regional and sectorial entrepreneurial ecosystems
Project.Description:
The 2018 Frontiers of Entrepreneurship Research conference identified the disconnect in research on regional entrepreneurial ecosystems and sectoral entrepreneurial ecosystems as a notable weakness in the emerging literature. Because of this gap, we do not know if region has a single ecosystem encompassing all of its high-growth entrepreneurial community or if it has multiple, nested ecosystems based around particular sectors. This distinction is particularly important when studying the FinTech sector, which requires cutting-edge technological know-how combined with deep insights into the finance industry to capitalize on new opportunities. This leads to the basic research question: do regions have a single entrepreneurial ecosystem or are they divided into multiple, nested ecosystems? This unanswered question makes it difficult to craft effective public policies to support FinTech high-growth entrepreneurship. To address this issue, this project will conduct a mixedmethods study on the overlap between finance and technology communities in British ecosystems. A quantitative study will examine the backgrounds of the founding and advising teams of FinTech startups and scale-ups in four British ecosystems: the City of London, East London (Silicon Roundabout), Edinburgh, and Leeds. This analysis will be followed up with a qualitative study of knowledge flow between finance and technology communities in Edinburgh, Scotland. This approach will provide rigorous and robust evidence for the relationship between regional entrepreneurial and sectoral ecosystems. This will in turn help researchers to develop better approaches to studying ecosystems as well as help us understand the role of cross-sectorial knowledge sharing in supporting high-growth
entrepreneurship.

Project.Title: how does cellular reaf/rprd2 recognise hiv nucleic acids to restrict viral infection?
Project.Description:
HIV is an important biomedical problem, 39 million people have died from infection and 39 million people remain infected. Therapy, though useful, is best by problems of resistance, affordability and toxic side effects, while vaccine and cure remain distant prospects. 

Identifying new ways to block the virus are needed. Our lab has defined a block that occurs when HIV tries to infect certain immune cells caused by a cellular protein REAF/RPRD2. We now wish to define the mechanism that underpins this block to know if it may be feasibly exploited.

For HIV to infect a cell it must convert its own RNA genome into DNA and place into the host's genome, and then it can make more copies of itself. This unique process is only carried out by viruses such as HIV, and so we propose that REAF/RPRD2 is specialised to detect this process to block the infection and signal to the cell that a virus is present. 

In our study we will identify the virus RNA and DNA structures that are sensed and blocked by cellular REAF/RPRD2 using microscopy based approaches. Next we will map the signalling pathways that REAF/RPRD2 triggers if HIV, or RNA and DNA that resembles virus, is present. By defining what REAF/RPRD2 senses to block virus and send warnin messages to the cell, we will in future be able to devise new therapeutic strategies aimed at improving and enhancing this immune response leading to a HIV control infected individuals.

Project.Title: system-science informed public health and economic research for non-communicable disease prevention (the sipher consortium)
Project.Description:
SIPHER PRIORITISED OBJECTIVES
Our overarching objective is to co-develop, with our policy partners, new systems science economic evaluation methods
that are used to inform the design, implementation and iterative, intelligence-led refinement of non-health sector policies
that prevent non-communicable disease and health inequalities.
ESSENTIAL OBJECTIVES - necessary for SIPHER to produce the intended policy and methodological innovations
WS1 Co-produce system maps of the four policy areas with policy partners
WS1 Identify core policy questions and evidence needs in each focus area
WS1 Elicit policy partner narratives to understand changes in policy contexts, including aims, targets, delivery mechanisms,
evidence use, beliefs and assumptions, synergies and tensions, as well as shifts in cause-and-consequence thinking
WS1 Identify and track evidence user and policy responses to SIPHER activities and outputs
WS2 Develop an evidence review methods framework to support complex systems modelling
WS2 Undertake evidence reviews of policy benefits, costs and health inequality impacts in SIPHER's policy areas to
provide inputs for models
WS3 Undertake a data audit for each focus area and identify data required for the project
WS3 Use existing Leeds infrastructure to securely house and curate data
WS3 Combine partner data with public datasets to create synthetic populations
WS4 Develop whole-systems policy macromodelling
WS4 Undertake population-level modelling to perform policy appraisal across target health and non-health outcomes
WS5 Develop a dynamic microsimulation tool populated with synthetic population data
WS5 Undertake micro-level modelling to perform policy appraisals
WS6 Elicit public and policy maker preferences for income, health and non-health outcomes and improving averages vs reducing inequalities in policy outcomes
WS7 Build a whole-systems policy appraisal tool for governments, including a comprehensive set of economic costs and
benefits to support cross-sectoral decision-making
WS7 Enable policymakers and their analytical teams to interactively explore the conflicts, synergies and interactions
between the estimated impacts of different policy options
WS7 Identify best-buy policies that maximise benefits across health and other sectors' priorities
WS8 Evaluate partner organisations' "healthy public policy" efforts in the focus policy areas, and SIPHER's contributions to
these
IMPACT Develop a strategic and expanding programme to transfer SIPHER data, models and decision support tools to
additional policy sectors and jurisdictions, and to ensure uptake by research groups in the UK and elsewhere independently
of SIPHER.
HIGHLY DESIRABLE OBJECTIVES - these allow SIPHER to provide estimates with greater policy-relevance and
credibility
WS1 Understand differences and similarities between our three policy partners' implementation systems and the
implications for SIPHER activities/outputs
WS2 Confirm and/or revise system map links through evidence review
WS3 Create a dynamic data infrastructure permitting routine updating of datasets and inclusion of newly available data
WS5 Model the differential impact of alternative policy scenarios on sub-populations and spatial areas to understand
distributional effects
WS5 Assess patterns by which the costs and benefits for key policies accrue over time
WS7 Identify and shape adaptive policy options where net benefit estimates are robust to environmental and
implementation uncertainties
WS8 Continuous monitoring of activities, outputs and impact
IMPACT Scale-up our support of local, national and international chronic disease and health inequality-relevant policy
applications
IMPACT Win funding for further systems science research relating to public health policy
IMPACT Co-design methods guidance and toolkits for complex systems policy appraisal and evaluation with knowledge
transfer partners and research funders 

THE PROBLEM
There is strong evidence that the social and economic conditions in which we grow, live, work and age determine our
health to a much larger degree than lifestyle choices. These social determinants of health, such as income, good quality
homes, education or work, are not distributed equally in society, which leads to health inequalities. However, we know very
little about how specific policies influence the social conditions to prevent ill health and reduce health inequalities. Also,
most social determinants of health are the responsibility of policy sectors other than "health", which means policymakers
need to promote health in ALL their policies if they are to have a big impact on health. SIPHER will provide new scientific
evidence and methods to support such a shift from "health policy" to "healthy public policy".
OUR POLICY FOCUS
We will work with three policy partners at local, regional and national level to tackle their above-average chronic disease
burden and persistent health inequalities: Sheffield City Council, Greater Manchester Combined Authority and Scottish
Government. We will focus on four jointly agreed policy priorities for good health:
- Creating a fairer economy
- Promoting mental wellbeing
- Providing affordable, good quality housing
- Preventing long-term effects of difficult childhoods.
OUR COMPLEX SYSTEMS SCIENCE APPROACH
Each of the above policy areas is a complex political system with many competing priorities, where policy choices in one
sector (e.g. housing) can have large unintended effects in others (e.g. poverty). There is often no "correct" solution
because compromises between different outcomes require value judgements. This means that to assess the true benefits
and costs of a policy in relation to health, policy effects and their interdependencies need to be assessed across a wide
range of possible outcomes. However, no policymaker has knowledge of the whole system and future economic and
political developments are uncertain. Ongoing monitoring of expected and unexpected effects of policies and other system
changes is crucial so failing policies can be revised or dropped.
We propose to use complex systems modelling, which has been developed to understand and make projections of what
might happen in complex systems given different plausible assumptions about future developments. Our models will be
underpinned by the best available data and prior research in each policy area. Our new evidence about likely policy effects
across a wide range of outcomes will help policy partners decide between alternative policies, depending on how important
different outcomes are to them (e.g. improving health or economic growth). We will develop support tools that can visualise
the forecasts, identify policies that achieve the desired balance between competing outcomes and update
recommendations when new information emerges. Whilst new to public health policy, these methods are well-established
in engineering and climate science.
We will
1. Work with policy partners to understand the policy systems and evidence needs
2. Bring together existing data and evidence on each policy system (e.g. links between policies and outcomes,
interdependencies between outcomes)
3. Explore citizens' preferences for prioritising when not all outcomes can be achieved
4. Link policies and their health and non-health effects in computer models to analyse benefits and costs over time
5. Build an interactive tool to help policy decision-making, inform advocacy action and support political debate.
SIPHER's MAIN OUTCOME
We will provide policymakers with a new methodology that allows them to estimate the health-related costs and benefits of
policies that are implemented outside the health sector. This will be useful to our partners, and others, who want to assess
how scarce public sector resources can be spent to maximise the health and wellbeing benefits from all their activities.

BACKGROUND: Systems science reframes public policies as active components of a complex, dynamic, policy system
that includes mechanisms such as feedback between interrelated effects, effect delay and system adaptation. In public
health, systems science has challenged and helped to change infectious disease policy, including vaccination strategies for
poliomyelitis and measles. However, it has not yet realised its potential impact on non-communicable disease (NCD) policy,
in part due to a lack of compatible methods to appraise policy effectiveness and cost-effectiveness.
VISION: SIPHER will be a world-leading centre of excellence for innovative, public health and health economics focused
systems science. During UKPRP, it will catalyse a shift from health policies to whole-systems, healthy public policy.
THEORY OF CHANGE: SIPHER's policy partners seek to reduce NCDs and health inequalities (HI) by incorporating health
considerations into non-health sectors. Academic and policy partners will co-produce complex systems decision modelling
and evaluate its effectiveness in supporting policy design in four focus areas: inclusive economic growth; housing; adverse
childhood experiences; and mental health.
RESEARCH: Eight interwoven workstrands will investigate: how policymakers think about and use evidence; iterative
evidence synthesis; working securely with sensitive data and building simulated populations; individual- and populationlevel dynamic models; values and preferences for equitable outcomes; identification of win-wins, best-buys, and adaptable
policies across sectors; process evaluation.
USER ENGAGEMENT: Co-production across local, regional and national government and knowledge transfer support by
influential partners.
BENEFITS: SIPHER will deliver scalable and transferable methods and tools to design, target, advocate for, implement
and monitor policy strategies that maximise NCD prevention and health inequality reductions.

Project.Title: digital livelihoods? the online gig economy and the future of decent refugee work in cities
Project.Description:
This project aims to explore the contribution of digitally mediated labour to the provision of decent work and livelihoods among displaced persons in cities, with a focus on Berlin and Beirut. Both these cities are leading hubs for digital innovation and have recently absorbed large numbers of refugees, prompting a growth in digital work initiatives. These emerged against the backdrop of a growing online 'gig economy' around the world amid an increasingly urban and 'connected' displaced population: more than 60 percent of the world's refugees now live in cities. These combined factors of urbanised refugee economies and the digitalisation of work demand urgent research into the relationship between the online gig economy and displaced populations. Yet despite a growing body of research on digital economies in development contexts, it is poorly understood how the online gig economy reshapes the world of work among displaced persons. Aiming to fill this knowledge gap in partnership with the International Labour Organization (ILO), the
Oxford Internet Institute (OII), and hosted by the University of Edinburgh, this project pursues three research objectives:
a) Generate empirical evidence about the digitally mediated work lives of refugees through fieldwork in Berlin and Beirut;
b) Gain insights through research of selected digital platforms that offer digital work opportunities and employment trainings;
c) Establish a new methodological framework that links ethnography with multidisciplinary methods in the social sciences of the digital, and develop new research skills through trainings.
In fulfilment of these research objectives, the project follows two overarching questions:
1) How does digitally mediated labour reshape refugees' access to decent work and sustainable livelihoods?
2) What implications do these transformations have for the rights and policies that govern urban refugee economies, and for the way displacement is conceptualised in the social sciences?
These overarching questions are complemented by three empirical sub-questions that correspond directly to the research objectives and three methodological dimensions:
a) What types of digitally mediated work do refugees do, how do they get access to it, and what impact does it have on their social and economic lives?
b) How do digital work platforms relate to the specific situation of displaced populations, and what impact do they pursue in comparison to the actual experiences of refugee workers?
c) What new combinations of qualitative ethnographic research and digital research methods allow us to grasp how digital economies and refugees' working practices intersect and overlap?
In line with the New Investigator Grant's aims, the project pursues additional objectives on two levels: skills development and impact.
Skills development objectives include completion of a leadership programme at the host institution; the development of new
approaches and methods during a three-months visit to the Oxford Internet Institute (OII); and the learning of effective user
engagement by collaborating with the ILO and providers of digital work opportunities in the third sector and the private sector.
The knowledge exchange and impact objectives include convening a workshop and an international conference with key users at the host institution; production of high-quality research outputs, including an ILO Working Paper, with impact on both users and academic beneficiaries; the creation of a project website and a Briefing for policy makers and platform developers titled 'A Just Gig Economy for Refugees'.
The newly gained skills, networks and knowledge throughout this project will facilitate the creation of sustainable research capacity at the host institution through follow-up funding applications with a clear long-term aim in mind: the formation of a research cluster on 'Digital Development' at Edinburgh's School of Social and Political Science.

Project.Title: optimisation of recovery of valuable metals from waste printed circuit boards (wpcbs) through modified hydrometallurgical route
Project.Description:
The proposed work intends to maximize the recovery of valuable metals from waste
printed circuit boards which are a great emerging source for various metals. Both
research groups have separate, yet complimentary expertise and have exemplified their
expertise their respective domains through numerous research projects and published
research papers in reputed journals. The Indian partners are able to separate metallic
and non-metallic components of waste printed circuit boards whereas the recovery of
gold from mobile phone PCBs is well studied by the group of the UK partner. The
combination of these expertise would facilitate the development of a new process to
recycle waste PCBs. The process described in this proposal is expected to be
eco-friendly as it obviates the emission of hazardous fumes and toxic gases by current
pyrolysis and high temperature methods adopted by recyclers. Also, solvent extraction
techniques for the separation of metals can be applied at the site of collection of waste
electronics, so benefiting the local economy and limiting transport of materials. Being
cost effective, it would be applicable to a large number of prospective users in Asian
countries.

Project.Title: tech for food? digital economies and the future of decent refugee work in cities
Project.Description: This project studies the contribution of digital labour to decent work and livelihoods among displaced persons in cities, focusing on Berlin and Beirut. As an increasingly urbanised refugee population remains excluded from labour markets, a global digital labour is spreading rapidly and gradually incorporates them. But this newly emerging relationship between digital economies and displacement remains poorly understood at a time when the ILO celebrates its centenary with a ‘Future of Work’ Initiative. With in-depth research and the establishment of new methodologies, this project will fill this gap and lead towards a ground-breaking new monograph on digital refugee labour.

Project.Title: mirror upon mirror: reconceiving reflexivity in cinematic art
Project.Description: The proposed research project is a monograph in film studies drawing upon the philosophy of art and film in the continental and analytic traditions, literary theory, and art theory. The first book-length, English-language exploration of the ramified topic of (self-)reflexivity in cinema in over three decades, it fundamentally reconceives reflexivity and related topics (metacinema, direct address, metalepsis, narrative ‘excess’), from a contemporary, trans-disciplinary standpoint.

Project.Title: mirror upon mirror: reconceiving reflexivity in cinematic art
Project.Description: The proposed research project is a monograph in film studies substantially drawing upon the philosophy of art, mind, and language, together with contemporary film, art, and literary theory (e.g. narratology; fictional worlds theory). The first book-length, English-language study of the ramified topic of (self-) reflexivity in cinema in over three decades (since Robert Stam’s Reflexivity in Film and Literature, 1985), it fundamentally reconceives reflexivity and related topics of meta-cinema, direct address, metalepsis, intertextuality, and fictional and artistic world-hood in film, from a twenty-first century, trans-disciplinary standpoint.

Project.Title: socioeconomic assessment for heat decisions
Project.Description:
Decarbonising heat is, in the UK Government's words, "our most difficult policy and technology challenge to meet our carbon targets," (2017 Clean Growth Strategy p. 75). This is not because of a lack of low carbon heat technologies, but because it is difficult to identify which technologies should be used in which buildings, when changes to buildings should be made, and how the costs of transition should be paid for. The Energy Research Partnership has called for a 'new decision making framework' for heat, and the Committee on Climate Change argues that critical decisions on heat need to be taken in the early 2020s. This research explores one technique likely to be central to any such decision making framework: socioeconomic assessment (SEA). 

SEAs weigh up the costs and benefits of different outcomes, but seek to do so from a neutral 'society-wide' perspective, accounting for more than just financial costs and benefits (e.g. incorporating pollution costs and health benefits) thereby expressing a conception of the 'common good'. This is important to decision making for heat decarbonisation as the transition faces three challenges, each of which implies increased government intervention: the aggregate financial costs of decarbonised heat in the UK are projected to be higher than the incumbent system, meaning non-financial benefits are critical to justifying interventions; some technologies (particularly district heating) depend on area-wide characteristics rather than individual buildings, and so require new public planning for heat; and recognition is growing that policy 'tweaks' to financial incentives are insufficient to drive change, creating pressure for more interventionist policies that restrict individual choice (such as regulating minimum energy standards for existing buildings, a policy already adopted for the private rented sector).

However, using SEA for heat decision making is not simply a matter of reading the 'common good' off a fixed set of calculations. SEAs can be conducted in different ways, and different approaches can lead to radically different outcomes. For example, the socially cost effective potential for district heating in the UK has been estimated in one official study to range from 3% to 40%, depending on how financing costs are treated. Different methods of SEA can lead to different decisions. For these decisions to be accepted as securing the 'common good', the methods used must be considered to be appropriate by different stakeholders. Have the right issues been taken into account? Is the process sufficiently transparent? Are the organisations responsible for defining and executing assessments trusted? Failing against these questions is likely to undermine the legitimacy and robustness of policies, leading to reluctance to implement or comply with them and hence negative consequences for progress in heat decarbonisation.

This study explores the use of SEA for heat in the UK, the Netherlands, Denmark and Germany to understand the conditions under which these assessments are effective in establishing the legitimacy and robustness of public authorities' decisions. Three separate sites are investigated:
1.	Guiding national heat policy. What are the main differences in the organisation and content of SEA used to inform heat policies? What are the consequences of these differences for decisions between technologies?
2.	Guiding local heat planning. How can SEA support local heat planning? Can SEA be an effective approach to resolving local controversies about heat strategies? How do local and national SEAs relate to each other?
3.	Guiding commercial decisions. How can public SEAs help guide businesses' investment decisions and develop innovative heat supply business models?

The project will produce best-practice guidance for effective use of SEA for heat. This will help national, devolved and local government develop new decision making processes to achieve heat decarbonisation.

Project.Title: ecologies of domestication: animal health impacts of the transition to farming
Project.Description:
The shift from hunting and gathering wild resources to the control and husbandry of domestic animals and plants had fundamental and far-reaching repercussions, particularly for human and animal health. Previous research has identified domestic animal origins in time and space and theories on the domestication process. There
remain, however, significant gaps in understanding and evidence for how animal husbandry evolved and how this affected animal and human health, especially in relation to the origins of zoonoses. This research will address these issues through a study of the evolution of goat husbandry as it emerged in the natural habitat of the wild goat in the Zagros Mountains of Iran and Iraq, spread, and was adapted to new environments in the wider region (c.10,000-5,000 BC). A suite of interdisciplinary scientific methodologies will be applied to excavated archaeological remains to identify how goat ecology changed through the domestication process and how this impacted animal and human health. This project investigates the health consequences of ecosystem engineering, an acceleration of which occurred with the transition to farming, and contributes long-term
perspectives to current concerns as animal management evolves to ensure food security for the ever-growing
global human population.
