Project.Title: the eu's changing role in gender equality: entrenching intersectional inequalities through economic governance? (rosalind cavaghan)
Project.Description:
The EU has long lauded gender equality as a core value of the EU, but this global leadership in equalities has suddenly disappeared. Critics argue that the EU has U-turned on gender equality since the financial crisis, prioritising narrowly defined economic aims, implemented through new policy mechanisms such as the European Semester. Negative impacts of these policies on women, particularly Black minority ethnic and migrant women are well-documented. Yet, EU strategic policy has not acknowledged or tackled these problems, despite unaltered legal frameworks promoting gender equality and Gender Mainstreaming, and activists’ attempts to highlight problems. Understandings the EU’s dramatically altered influence on equalities, thus requires innovative methodologies to directly study the implications of new implementation processes involved in new European economic governance. 
	This project operationalises Feminist Economists’ assertions, that concepts and measurements routinely used in economic policy formulation and assessment, normalise and instrumentalise gender and racial inequalities, monopolising the production of economic knowledge and marginalising alternative, intersectional perspectives. Using a novel methodology drawing on the Sociology of Knowledge this project traces policy processes involved in EU economic co-ordination and surveillance, in 4 Eurozone Member States to analyse: whether and how EU economic governance coordinates Member States to implement gender blind and gender biased economic policy; how feminist civil society has sought to influence these policies/been excluded and; variation between States.
	Findings open the ‘black box’ of EU economic policy implementation unpacking the new mechanisms through which the EU is now entrenching and normalising intersectional gender inequalities in Member States and marginalising dissenting voices, in turn revealing opportunities for activists to contest this decisive shift in the EU’s impact on equalities.

Project.Title: reconciling the mystical body: louisiana catholics and desegregation, 1945-1976
Project.Description:
The study examines why, how and to what extent Louisiana Catholic institutions desegregated, and how Catholics responded to secular desegregation in the South's most Catholic state. It challenges sociological conceptions of Catholic hierarchy and analyses the complex response of clergy, nuns, and laity, whether
integrationist, segregationist, white, mixed race, or African American. The Archdiocese of New Orleans contained the South's largest Catholic population, the Diocese of Lafayette the most African American Catholics in the nation, and the Diocese of Alexandria lay in often hostile and overwhelmingly Protestant, northern Louisiana, yet there is no monograph about Catholic desegregation in Louisiana.

Project.Title: psi-borg - psychophysical analysis and physiologically-based recognition of computer generated characters
Project.Description:
This main objective divides into three major pillars, which combine scientific understanding with practical benefits:
1. PERCEPTION: Understand how the identity and emotional expressions of hyper-realistic CG faces and voices are perceived by the human brain.
2. CREATION: Explore the edges of lifelike character creation, pushing the limits of current computer graphics by exploiting knowledge about how real humans perceive CG imitations.
3. DETECTION: Develop and advance new techniques for automatic detection of CG faces and speech, providing essential tools to regain trust in online content and computer-mediated communication, as well as confidence in facial- and speech based authentication.

Project.Title: the political economy of military transitions in south korea and myanmar
Project.Description: The project investigates the political economy of military transition in Asia, with a particular focus on Myanmar and South Korea. Myanmar serves as the project’s empirical entry point to explore why, how and under what circumstances the armed forces leave politics and countries embark on political transition. It also provides a prism to investigate the military’s control of key economic assets and the extent to which the armed forces relinquish not just political but also economic control. Next, the project seeks to draw some lessons from South Korea's democratization in the late 1980s in order to tease out the mechanisms that led to a successful outcome in Korea and identify the key challenges confronting Myanmar. This is especially important in light of Korea's rising economic clout in the country and the deepening political relationship between the two.

Project.Title: intra-household allocation of resources and economic development: the birth order effect paradox
Project.Description:
Early-life conditions and investments are key for adult economic outcomes, with an increasing number of public policies targeting childhood years. In this context, parents play a decisive role on passing and allocating resources to children. The so-called "birth order effect" – differences among children of the same family by order of birth – provides evidence of the relevant role of parents, as older children have been shown to perform substantially better in terms of completed education, wages or employment. This is the case in a wide array of developed countries (UK, US or Norway, among others), but interestingly developing countries such as Ecuador or the Philippines show the opposite relationship, suggesting that economic development may affect how resources are allocated within the household.
This project aims to shed light on the role of economic  development on the birth order effect and, in general, distribution of available resources within the household. We will use a myriad of historical data sources from the U.S. and the Netherlands over the 19th and early 20th century to study how the birth order effect changes as societies become richer, and experience other changes associated with economic development, such as the decrease in the number of children per family or the decline of the agricultural sector. We will compare siblings over a long period of time to assess how differences among siblings changes as countries develop and families face different economic circumstances.

Project.Title: all over again? a mixed-methods, spatial, and temporal study of the economic livelihoods of the burundian repeat refugees in north-western tanzania
Project.Description:
Refugees are often primarily seen as beneficiaries of aid and protection, neglecting the fact that they are also economic actors. This research explores the livelihoods of refugees, looking at one group for whom maintaining economic networks is particularly vital: repeat refugees, those who are forcibly displaced multiple times because of protracted and repeated crises. The project focuses on the 'new' caseload of repeat Burundian refugees in Tanzania. Through a mixed-methods approach comparing different groups of refugees across time and space, the project aims to systematically further the academic debate on and understanding of the survival strategies of repeat refugees through time and space (e.g.
international aid, casual labour, retail shops, trans-border trade, etc.). More broadly, the project has the ambition to influence assistance to refugees and economic development strategies in host and home countries in Sub-Saharan Africa and beyond.
First, the project seeks to consolidate the development of a new, critical perspective in the study of refugees that looks at the livelihoods of repeat refugees and considers them as economic agents who develop self-reliance strategies, often engage in formal or informal work, and make use of aid programmes. It understands the concept of livelihood as rooted not only in the economy but also in time, space, and society. Through examining the evolution of refugee livelihoods through different episodes of forced migration using insights from economics and history, the research will lead to re-examining assumptions about refugees beyond the framework of protection.
In line with this, the second aim is to contribute to developing a methodological toolbox. The mixed-methods approach will integrate and combine instruments from development economics (survey and behavioural games), history (life histories), and participatory methods from arts and social sciences. Building on its skills and experience, the research team will work on adapting these methods, and their combination, to the study of refugee livelihoods and economies. This will be within the framework of an international collaboration with Burundian and Tanzanian researchers and the refugees themselves, thereby contributing to the building of research capacities in both the UK and the African Great Lakes Region.
Third, the project will generate new empirical data about the lives of repeat refugees and focus on issues seldom researched, such as the way refugees perceive their economic situation, mobilise, and act upon it through time and space.
Empirical data is crucial to drawing a rigorous and fine-grained analysis that will interest both (1) the growing community of researchers and practitioners working on refugee economies and their interactions with livelihoods and identities; and (2) the researchers and organisations who seek to understand the dynamics of the current crisis in Burundi and the Great Lakes region.
Fourth, the project seeks a deep practical relevance for refugee policy and programmes. The change of perspective mentioned above aims to produce evidence that encourages policy-makers to design more durable solutions for repeat refugees and host communities. Comparing groups of repeat refugees (inside and outside camps, with and without aid) will enrich the growing debate on refugee economies and contribute to broadening the horizons of approaches such as the new United Nation's Global Compacts on Refugees and Migrants.
The project will be a stepping stone in the PI's career, allowing him to lead a unique collaboration and consolidating his expertise in the region and access to basic social services. Through the project and strong mentorship, he will acquire new skills in participatory methods, develop his research leadership and network, and build solid foundations and collaborations for a large research programme on refugee livelihoods.

Project.Title: finsbury park culturecoin
Project.Description: This experiment visualises and reveals the hidden value of culture in an urban park by integrating a prototype geolocated cryptocurrency into the OrganiCity environment. CultureCoin responds to London’s high levels of segregation and isolation (see European quality of life survey), a priority issue for Finsbury Park’s community. Our experiment will empower Finsbury Park communities to make visible their own values through the medium of digital money to explore the potential impact of cryptocurrencies and other digital developments in communal and public spaces.This will inform future cultural programmes, investment and development within the park setting - including plans for free open public wifi currently being planned by the local authority - to improve quality of life for local people from diverse cultural backgrounds.

Project.Title: tools for adaptive re-use of heritage assets for sustainability and economic growth
Project.Description:
Adaptive re-use of cultural heritage has emerged as a promising solution to the widening gap in what is publicly available in terms of resources and what is necessary in order to adequately preserve and sustain Europe’s rich diversity of cultural heritage assets. Our rationale in this proposal is that fully understanding and making constructive use of the latent potential embodied in the idea of adaptive re-use for placemaking, job creation and economic growth demands a novel approach; in
our case, a targeted, iterative design strategy, engaging a critical mass of multi-stakeholder participants into a comprehensive and extended innovating process centered on the four pillars of preservation, financing, business models and integrated governance. We carry out case studies in Edinburgh, Zagreb and three adaptive re-use intervention locations in Portugal, to build a knowledge base and decision support capability to enable creation of successful adaptive re-use blueprints with high replicability and up-scaling potential.

Project.Title: economics on the edge: an intellectual history of economics and economists in the people’s republic of china from 1949 to the present day
Project.Description:
My second book is an intellectual history of economics and economists in the People’s Republic of China since 1949. It combines a discussion of key economic concepts with intellectual and political biographies of Chinese economists. My research demonstrates that Western economics did not enter the PRC only in 1978, as many economists have argued, and that Chinese economics are an
intellectual tradition in their own right rather than being a local inflection of a global trend. A study of economic ideas is also always a history of the people practising and living these ideas in a complex, diverse, and continually shifting political environment. Therefore, this book is also a history of ideas, professional careers
in Chinese socialist academia, and the way in which individuals navigated political challenges and forces beyond their control.

Project.Title: the dark side of financial innovation? estimating the costs and real economy effects of algorithmic trading, market  fragmentation and dark trading
Project.Description: We aim to estimate the impact of financial market innovations/structural changes over the past two decades on the UK's real economy. Members of the public stand to benefit given the potential of the research to impact policy, which could help improve market quality and fairness. It is vital that financial markets are fair because they reflect on everyday financial products such as ISAs, pensions, direct debits, credit cards, investments, loans etc. Indeed the entire UK economy revolves around financial markets; hence, the markets play critical roles in the lives of every UK resident. The market innovation phenomena we will investigate are high frequency (algorithmic) trading, market fragmentation and dark trading.

Project.Title: law carbon practicies: mapping and transforming practices in food, energy and construction towards a sustainable economy.
Project.Description:
Energy and food production and consumption make about half of the global emissions that must be reduced to achieve a liveable planet. Practice theory offers a method for identifying the limits and possibilities of change and practical implications for transformative low-carbon governance. Our objectives are to :
•	using practice theory, identify points for leveraging transformative change in people’s values and practices in contrasting case studies 
•	Conduct research in dialogue with key stakeholders who can take change forward..
•	Create documentation of the research process, stakeholder dialogue and lessons from comparative analysis that will inspire scaling up similar activities elsewhere.
. Our cases involve 1) legal interventions attempting to reduce emissions, 2) life-stage transition as an opportunity of fostering consumption practices change, 3) attempted lower-carbon food production in a deprived community, 4) transformative empowerment potential of off-grid and renewable energy and 5) a site of contradictory change in meat consumption practices. These cases offer contrasting constellations of non-academic partner interests and levels of power that make success in reducing carbon emissions more or less difficult. Teams from the Netherlands, Norway, the UK and India, working in high, upper- and lower-middle income contexts, will share insights developed from these practical examples on how to transform towards more sustainable societies, and map transferable principles for wider change. We will create impact through relationships with non-academic partners, their networks introducing the practice approach to policy and practitioner work and networks of academics with mutually productive research interests.

Project.Title: rs newton international fellowship for alfredo martinez: the reconciliation between freedom and determination:agency, responsibility and brain in leibniz
Project.Description: What or who is the cause of our actions? Ourselves? Our brain? Apparently the more we get to know our own brain functions, the more the idea of freedom becomes blurred. This is mainly because many of the concepts of freedom we frequently use require a certain degree of indetermination, that is, require the idea that my actions are completely under my control. It is precisely this idea of control what clashes with the ways in which our brains produce or regulate our actions. I propose to explore the possibility of a concept of freedom that does not require indetermination and that, therefore, it can coexist without conflict with decisionrelated functions of the brain. For this purpose I will use, as a context, the thought of G. W. Leibniz, especially his Essais de Theodicée. From this concept I will try to shed some light on the issues of agency and responsibility, which are traditionally considered to be closely related to indetermination.

Project.Title: mrc-fapesp - "sophie" and the brain for hand motor impairment recovery in stroke survivors
Project.Description:
This proposal builds upon recent advances in neuroengineering and soft robotics to progress in the development,
calibration and test of "SOPHIE", a SOft Physiotherapy Hand Interactive Exoskeleton. SOPHIE is a portable rehabilitation
device aimed to address hand motor impairment (HMI) recovery after stroke. HMI accounts for around 60% of post stroke
disability that currently affects 3.5 million people both in the UK and Brazil. In the UK, every year an estimated 130,000
people have a stroke and the NHS costs are £8.9billion a year (5.5% of the total NHS expenditure) [1].
Currently, there are several robotic devices available for post stroke hand rehabilitation but their use has been limited either
by their very high cost, size, targeted hand movement (closing of the hand only), and/or lack of adaptability. The SOPHIE
device is portable, affordable, adaptable, aesthetically friendly, and it will help patients to recover the opening (in addition to
closing) movement of their hand after a stroke. The system will integrate a soft orthotic device developed by the UK
partners with a Brain-Machine Interface (BMI) system plus electromyography (EMG) sensors, devised by the Brazilian
applicants. Machine learning methods will be used to control device resistance and adaptability. Clinical trials will be
conducted both in the UK and Brazil.
SOPHIE will allow rehabilitation not only in the major rehabilitation centres but also in the outpatient department and
potentially at home. SOPHIE will require very little input by the trained therapist, once the patient is trained to use the
device. The same approach could be further extended in the future to aid in the recovery of lower limbs. With its combined
compact design and relatively low cost, SOPHIE has potential to revolutionise rehabilitation after stroke by increasing the
amount of therapy available, and thus has a real potential to transform lives.

Project.Title: recording and analysis of simultaneous intracranial eeg and nirs for the detection of interictal epileptiform discharges
Project.Description:
The scalp electroencephalogram (EEG) is one of the most used methods that aid in the diagnosis of epilepsy. However, only 55% of awake and 80% of sleep EEGs recorded from patients with epilepsy detect one of the most widely used biomarkers of epilepsy; interictal epileptiform discharges (IEDs). In this project we will record and analyse recordings of NIRS in patients who will be anyway and routinely scheduled for intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG). The aims are twofold; establish the NIRS IED characteristics as compared to the gold standard of iEEG recordings and develop automatic IED detection algorithms on the NIRS recordings. The results of this project will establish the ability of NIRS being a reliable biomarker for epilepsy

Investigation of near-infrared spectroscopy as a biomarker acquisition method for epilepsy with the aid of invasive electroencephalography.

The diagnostic process in epilepsy has been aided by the use of biomarkers. One of them, interictal epileptiform discharges is a useful marker, but it is not always seen in patients with epilepsy. Near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), a non-invasive technique, has also been recently investigated as a possible method for detecting epileptiform discharges.

In this project we will record and analyse recordings of NIRS in patients who will anyway undergo intracranial electroencephalography (electrodes inside the skull, iEEG) for the localization of abnormal brain areas. Our aim is the creation and analysis, for the first time in humans, of a joint NIRS-iEEG dataset to further the development of NIRS as a biomarker for epilepsy. 
 
The relation between the electrical (iEEG) and the haemodynamic (NIRS) signatures of the discharges will be established in a robust way with extensive practical applications. Due to the ease of use of a NIRS device, the methodology will enable and encourage similar and extended studies in the future further enhancing its utility.

NIRS is a non-invasive and portable device which can be promptly incorporated as a diagnostic tool. Within 12 months of the end of the project the conclusions would be helpful to clinicians.

Project.Title: econometric identification of viable candidate molecules for continuous pharmaceutical manufacturing
Project.Description:
How can we confidently determine the most important pharmaceuticals whose
continuous production will ensure wider and cheaper global availability, and more
affordable healthcare to growing underprivileged populations who suffer from
devastating diseases? How can we insightfully identify the approved therapeutic
molecules which are most efficiently amenable to continuous manufacturing, so as
to then design optimal production plants with maximised productivity and
minimised environmental impact, for the notoriously wasteful pharmaceutical
industry?

Continuous Pharmaceutical Manufacturing is a rapidly expanding technology
pursued already by many multinational companies, but the selection of the most
suitable substances, or Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) to be produced
in continuous plants is arbitrary and circumstantial. The applicant, Dr Dimitrios
Gerogiorgis, has many years of experience and leadership in process modelling,
simulation and optimisation of continuous pharma plants, and is an expert in
performing conclusive technoeconomic analyses which quantitatively establish the
extent of capital and operating cost advantages of such plants, as well as the
most promising solvents for API separation and their relative environmental
impact, for a given API. The question is: Which APIs should we be studying?

This interdisciplinary research project bridges a gap between Chemical Process
Systems Engineering and Econometrics, proposing the use of Data Analytics and
Statistical Modelling in order to analyse UK and EU demand, cost and price
trends, from reputable agency (ONR, ABPI, EMEA) pharmaceutical production
and trade databases, and thereby develop a systematic methodology
(collaborating with Dr Martin-Barragan) to identify strong business opportunities
for societally critical APIs and products, whose Smart Continuous Manufacturing
will have a profound effect on eradicating diseases and ensuring vibrant growth at
much lower financial and environmental cost.

Project.Title: high peak, perishable energy recovery – foundation phase (fp)
Project.Description:
Discipline: Environmental engineering
Subdiscipline: Energy, fuels and petroleum engineering
Descriptor: Energy systems (production, distribution, application)
Discipline: Environmental engineering
Subdiscipline: Energy, fuels and petroleum engineering
Descriptor: Energy collection, conversion and storage, renewable energy
Discipline: Environmental engineering
Subdiscipline: Energy, fuels and petroleum engineering
Descriptor: Sustainable energy policy
Discipline: Social sciences
Subdiscipline: Psychology
Descriptor: Social psychology
Hurricane Energy Harvesting

Energy consumption has increased considerably during the last few decades, with studies that suggest that this trend will
double around the world in the next 20 years. In parallel, renewable technologies are still suffering low efficiency rates or
considerable intermittency, whilst use of new, unconventional fossil fuels keeps increasing GHGs that will unlikely be
reduced to the pre-industrial era. This over-exploitation of fossil resources has produced a considerable addition of CO2 to
the atmosphere, warming up the planet and producing more frequent climatic phenomena such as floods, hurricanes, ice
melting, etc. As it is unlikely that civilization will mitigate both CO2 production in the short term and climate change with the
current increase of temperature, humanity needs to learn how to cope with the new climatic events that are about to come.
Therefore, it is necessary that the use of new technology leads us to the creation of devices that can produce renewable
energy in vast quantities to support global consumption, while keeping a green, zero CO2 scenario that uses these more
frequent climatic events for our advantage. In that line, High Peak, Perishable Energy (HPPE) is a concept that can
potentially change the way that we see climate change and its associated phenomena, not to stop working towards its
mitigation, but to use as much as possible of these new events to produce energy that can sustain entire communities for
months while avoiding CO2 production. In particular to this proposal, the study focuses on developing the concepts to
recover energy from hurricanes. Thus, HPPE looks into the development of concepts that can be also applied to the heat
transfer industry whilst being supported by experimentalist, legals and social researchers to create the foundations for the
development of socially ethical systems.

Project.Title: efficient, reliable and safe biomass handling, pretreatment and processing for a sustainable eu bio-based economy
Project.Description:
Production technology, process engineering
Forestry, biomass production (e.g. for biofuels)
Agroindustry
Biomass, agriculture, forestry, pretreatment, handling, conveying, silos, dust explosions, bulk
solids, particulate solids, pelletization, discrete element method

This decade’s major challenge for the EU economy is to decouple its growth from the use of resource-input or the
environmental impact-output. The use of biomass is the main opportunity for this decoupling. For this ‘third industrial
revolution’ the industry needs a group of highly skilled staff with scientific, technological, managerial and entrepreneurial
competences for the multi-disciplinary field of biomass handling and processing The efficient and safe use of biomass
becomes a fundamental concept of this revolution, given the limited and fragmented availability of the biomass feedstock.
Often the lack of knowledge and use of innovative and specific techniques for biomass characterisation, equipment and
systems design and safety causes biomass transformation plant stoppage and thus substantial losses in terms of resources,
time and money. The innovative training network “Efficient, reliable and safe biomass handling, pretreatment and processing
for a sustainable EU bio-based economy (BIOHAPPBY)” is part of the solution. By joining forces of many sectors relevant to
biomass handling, pretreatment and processing, i.e. universities and research centers, software houses, densification
equipment suppliers, storage equipment designers, safety systems providers, plant constructors, bioenergy producers and
biorefineries, BIOHAPPBY proposes the training of highly skilled, interdisciplinary experts on an international research
programme. It will provide significant advances in the scientific understanding of the physical phenomena controlling the
biomass solids behaviour in handling systems and support groundbreaking technologies for the biomass pre-treatement,
storage, handling and safety. Industry- close development and market uptake on those technologies will ensure reliable,
economical, efficient, sustainable and safe handling and feeding processes for biomass valorisation plants.

Project.Title: architecture and homecoming: can architecture support transitions out of homelessness?
Project.Description:
Accommodation' is not tantamount to 'home'. As 'home' is an active moment in creating individual and social identities (Short 1999), offering a stable home rather than temporary accommodation has been defended as the most successful way to end the "degrading and dehumanising" experience of homelessness (BBC 2016, The Guardian 2016). As recently presented at the Scottish Churches Housing Action event (BBC Scotland 2016), policies aimed at reducing homelessness, rather than managing it, should offer homeless people a place that they can call home, as in the Housing First model. However, current research highlights that evidence on how accommodation for transitions can help homeless people rebuild their social identity and help stabilise ontological security is yet limited and inconclusive (Quilgars and Pleace 2016). This project will assess how architecture can support transitions out of homelessness or homecoming by applying a novel cross-disciplinary methodology that we have developed from interpretative phenomenological analysis (IPA) and architectural methods and combines theory-driven explorations from architecture with those of the social sciences. Our novel approach follows a philosophical reading of homelessness as lacking a sense of belonging, and with it a sound sense of identity, together with a sense of estrangement and loneliness. As the accommodation offered to single homeless individuals plays a key role in successful homecoming, our inter-disciplinary team (architect, sociologist, psychotherapist) will examine how single homeless people re-build their self and social identities in place in order to belong to mainstream housed society. The proposed research takes the following theoretical assumptions:
a)	Homecoming equals the philosophical state of belonging, meaning and purpose.
b)	Architecture enables belonging through place-making.
c)	The ontological passage from homelessness to homecoming involves negotiating estrangement (Strand A), stigma (Strand B) and loneliness (Strand C) in place.

The research identifies three interlinked strands that frame the over-arching research question on architecture supporting transitions: from estrangement to dwelling (A), from stigma to a sound sense of self-identity (B) and from loneliness to a new social-identity (C). By means of a novel in-depth longitudinal elicitation of how single homeless participants in transition negotiate estrangement, stigma and loneliness in place, the proposed research will bring forth the role of architecture supporting homecoming and inform architectural theories of place-making. Dissemination beyond the research community will share the novel multifaceted account of transitions in place through a dedicated project experiential exhibition and symposium titled 'Architecture and homecoming'

Project.Title: the effectiveness of "walk150" walking programme to improve physical performance for people with mild/moderate long-term musculoskeletal conditions: a randomised controlled trial with health economic analyses
Project.Description:
This research aims to help the 10 million people who have a long lasting musculoskeletal condition (LTMC) (such as back pain, fibromyalgia or osteoarthritis) to improve their ability to do functional activities (such as standing up, walking, balance), to improve the amount of physical activity they do each week and improve their quality of life. Activity guidelines include the advice that adults do at least 150 minutes of moderate activity each week. Moderate activity is exercise that makes someone breathe faster, but not so fast that they can’t hold a conversation. People with LTMCs are more likely to be less active than their peers. People have described this to us as ‘a double hit’ on their lives; they already have a painful and/or, disabling condition and then, by being less active, they are at greater risk than their peers of getting other conditions too (such as heart disease, some cancers, depression, stroke and diabetes). The number of people with LTMCs is rising in line with the aging population and so, in addition to the impact of these conditions on the daily lives of people living with them, this is placing a further financial burden on the already stretched NHS.

“Walk150” is a walking programme (website and podcasts) to help people with LTMCs and low levels of physical activity to gradually and safely increase their activity. By the end of the programme, people walk 150 minutes per week (at moderate/vigorous levels of activity). We have already worked with people with LTMCs to develop the ‘Walk 150’ programme which consists of individual physiotherapy assessments backed up by on-line information and podcasts.  A pilot study found that it is well liked by people with LTMCs and that it may be producing worthwhile increases in physical performance and levels of physical activity. We are now proposing a larger study to find out if out if the programme has worthwhile sustained long term effects on physical function and activity in this group. We will measure how far (in metres) people can walk during a 6 Minute Walking test; this tells us about how quickly someone can walk, about their endurance, about their trunk and leg muscle strength, about their balance and their quality of life. We will also measure how many steps people walk a day and the effect of “Walk150” on symptoms (pain, fatigue), quality of life, the amount and type of physical activity people are doing, their mood and happiness and the cost effectiveness of the “Walk150” programme.

We will do these measures when people join the study, and at 3 and 12 months to see how people do over time. People with a LTMC will be on the project management team. If “Walk150” is effective we will produce a downloadable package, with training materials and podcasts, so that the programme becomes available for free use by others within and outside the NHS. We will publish the results in freely downloadable respected medical journals, our website and send our press releases to charities and magazines. It is our hope that “Walk150” will help both people living with LTMCs to become able to be more active and help the NHS to effectively treat this growing number of patients in a cost- effective way in the future.

Project.Title: discovering hidden knowledge in audio and video recordings
Project.Description: The key challenges of this proposal are that speech transcripts do not contain structurally formed sentences or case distinction and their quality can be poor. Even the most advanced ASR systems produce transcripts with some degree of error. My proposed research will evaluate how ASR quality affects analytics performance and will investigate methods of post-correction. The iterative development of the analytics tool will be interspersed with regular evaluation phases to test performance. I will primarily process news AV collections provided by the BBC and the British Library. Later on in the fellowship I will conduct a domain adaptation phase to apply the technology to a different type of collection (medical or oral history).

Project.Title: anecdote, record or datum?: scientific attitudes to evidence of varying quality, 1600 - present
Project.Description: This very interdisciplinary project is all about the distinction between anecdotal and other unconventional forms of information (hereafter collectively referred to as "evidence of varying quality") in contrast to data, the usefulness of such evidence and the historical and contemporary role of such evidence in science. Evidence of varying quality, such as anecdotes, case studies and expert opinion, whilst the stuff of which hypotheses are made, is often not considered amenable to modern scientific analyses. Yet evidence of varying quality is being quantified and used by a new generation of scientists/statisticians. This project will explore what the history of experimental philosophy/science reveals about this quiet revolution and the reasons for differing attitudes to evidence of varying quality and determine the philosophical, statistical and practical constraints in using such evidence. Is the use of evidence of varying quality bad (pseudo-)science or just science with imperfect data? What forms of evidence are used by scientists and statisticians? Could this evidence be used with equal rigour in the social sciences and humanities? Thus we will document the attitude towards evidence of varying quality of Bacon and the early experimental philosophers, the influence of Enlightenment philosophers like Hume and Reid on scientists' thoughts about anecdotes, the development of statistics and its relation to scientists' use of evidence of varying quality and data, scientific attitudes towards natural history anecdotes in 19th century, the history of phenology, the history of scientific attitudes to eyewitness testimony and contemporary scientific attitudes to evidence of varying quality in the broad sense especially the emergence of Bayesian perspectives. The aim will be not only to document the history of data within science and the usages of different types of information but above all, to suggest robust methods for the handling of anecdotes and related types of information within 21st century science and scholarship more generally (i.e. in the social sciences and humanities). Finally the project may shed some wholly new light on the demarcation problem by considering the nature of the actual material under consideration by scientists, a perspective almost completely untouched in current histories of science.

Project.Title: the impact of economic pressures / sector restructuring on alcohol and drug service provision
Project.Description:
Risky drinking can be detrimental to individuals, their families, and the communities in which they live. Drug and alcohol problems do not only affect those misusing substances but also the family members of the substance user and are strongly linked to problems such as domestic violence, homelessness, crime and child maltreatment.
County Durham is the most deprived area in the north-east region of the United Kingdom (UK). Changes to the commissioning of services as well as substantial cuts to funding mean that difficult decisions are having to be made in relation to services. This research will seek to explore the impact of these economic pressures and sector restructuring on the region’s drug and alcohol service provision. To do this we will interview service users, commissioners, and practitioners to explore the recent changes.
This research involves researchers and practitioners working together to carry out the research, enabling shared learning. Firstly we will work with County Durham staff and service users to further develop the questions that are important to them and to service users. We will then carry out interviews and focus groups with service users and staff. We expect these interviews will focus on what staff and service users think about changes to provision because of cuts to services and how this is impacting on them. We will work together on analysing the focus groups and writing up the results as well as providing a case study to be used by other councils. As well as writing up the report for the funder and for academic journals/conference we will host a conference (with FUSE) in the north east of England to disseminate the findings. Moreover we will develop factsheets to be used by practitioners and short podcasts that will be available on the Teesside University and Durham Council websites as well as on ‘youtube’.

Project.Title: staying ‘better than well’: an exploration of the experience and ‘active ingredients’ of sustaining recovery within a supportive social environment
Project.Description:
This project aims to explore what helps people to maintain their recovery from alcohol related harm while attending the peer-support Serenity Café in Edinburgh. Recovery can be a challenging and fluctuating journey and individual support needs vary throughout. Services for people in recovery have changed significantly in recent years with emphasis being placed on solutions and service-user experiences rather than traditional treatment approaches. However, the ‘key ingredients’ of services that help people to sustain recovery are not yet fully understood. 
A recent study carried out by this team highlighted the importance of supportive social spaces where people meet informally and can socialise with those who have experienced the recovery journey. The proposed study firstly aims to understand more about the ‘active ingredients’ which make socially supportive spaces and informal peer-support important to the maintenance of recovery. Secondly, the project aims to understand the relationships between recovery and personal identity over time, exploring the ways in which people incorporate recovery into their daily lives and the role of supportive social environments in that transition. 
In times of austerity the relatively inexpensive supportive café model could be influential in facilitating sustained recovery, allowing service-users to develop occupational and social roles while enjoying responsive peer-support. This study is important because it seeks to understand the key factors that make the model work, providing a framework from which future policy and service provision can be developed.
The project is innovative in a number of ways. Firstly, this application includes two service-user/peer researchers from Serenity Café. Secondly, the project uses photovoice, an innovative research approach, allowing participants to use photography to explore experiences. Finally, this project will co-produce photographic materials which enable the Café to disseminate findings in exciting ways such as exhibitions, engaging display boards, innovative evidence submissions to key stakeholders and public engagement.

Project.Title: an exploration of risky alcohol use and experiences of recovery amongst people seeking asylum in the uk: a peer participatory research study
Project.Description: While it might be expected that refugees and people seeking asylum use alcohol as a way of coping with the traumatic events they experience (fleeing war, persecution, loss of family etc.), surprisingly little is known about alcohol use amongst this group. There is some evidence that young asylum seekers and those who become destitute following the asylum process engage in risky alcohol use, but little is known about the ways that asylum seekers use alcohol, the circumstances associated with misuse or pathways to recovery. This is particularly important at a time when the political climate is increasingly hostile to asylum seekers and the consequences of this are likely to exacerbate the distress they experience. Increasingly research is expanding our understanding of the pathways that people take into harmful alcohol use and recovery. As the idea of ‘recovery’ has been investigated, it is now understood to be much more than merely a reduction in alcohol use, but includes non-health benefits such as housing and improved social relationships. Research that listens to the ‘voices’ of individuals who have experienced harmful alcohol use has been instrumental in uncovering these new ideas and understanding of recovery. Nonetheless, the experience of people who are hard-to-reach has been largely absent from this body of research. This project intends to include the use of two researchers from the refugee community to interview 20-25 people to explore risky alcohol use and experiences of recovery amongst people seeking asylum in the UK. The PI has significant experience of successfully working with refugee researchers and has an established relationship, and therefore access to this hard-to-reach group. This innovative partnership study will provide us with an increased understanding of the ways that experiences during forced migration influence risky alcohol use and recovery.

Project.Title: the political economy of nature: robert jameson and the edinburgh college museum, 1804–54
Project.Description: Robert Jameson (1774–1854) was the keeper of the natural history museum of the University of Edinburgh from 1804 to 1854, as well as Edinburgh's third professor of natural history. The vast collection of specimens that he amassed through his global network of connections later became the core of the natural history collection of National Museums Scotland (NMS). Jameson’s museum was the second most important natural history collection in the British Empire after the British Museum in London, and fully justified his claim that it was the closest thing Scotland had to a national museum in the early nineteenth century. This will be the first comprehensive study of this historically important museum and the objects it contained, shedding light on contemporary natural history networks, collecting practices and how natural history objects were valorised, exchanged and used. It will explore how the collection was created and what purposes it served, while adding value to many of the objects currently in the care of NMS by reconnecting them with their own histories.

Project.Title: is jewish ethical thinking unique? a study of second temple jewish interpersonal love ethic in the light of hellenistic moral philosophy
Project.Description: This project will investigate the development of ancient Jewish ethical thinking in the Hellenistic-Roman period (ca. 200BCE to 200CE) in the light of Hellenistic philosophy. Ancient Jewish and Hellenistic ethical discourses have rarely been compared in a systematic manner, but since Jewish thinkers knew, and learned from, Hellenistic traditions, Jewish ethical thinking should be examined against the Hellenistic backdrop. The project will compare the diverse patterns of ancient Jewish thinking on the interpersonal love ethic with that of the Hellenistic philosophical schools, namely, the Stoics, the Cynics, the Skeptics, and the Epicureans. By highlighting commonalities and divergences between these traditions, the project will illuminate not only the development of ancient Jewish ethics but also the broader history and genealogies of ethics in what is considered to be the most formative period for moral philosophy.

Project.Title: mental health, gender violence and ecology in india: situating local experiences amid global and national economic re-structuring
Project.Description:
Both Gender-based violence (GBV) and global mental health are prominent in global health
debates and the 2030 agenda for sustainable development. There is growing convergence
between GBV and mental illness in clinical and public health practice. Yet, theoretical and empirical
links between cycles of violence and mental health and well-being are unexplored; grounded in
discourses divested from social and structural determinants of health. Sundarban, an ecologically
sensitive and geo-politically significant region in coastal India, is witnessing significant economic
and development-related shifts. Prior research by our Indian collaborators have documented how
these shifts shape vulnerability to psycho-social harm. The proposed project will advance this work
in exciting directions; to undertake ground work to support development of a major research
proposal on the structural and social determinants of the relationship between GBV, ecology,
mental health and well-being.
We seek seed funding to: generate preliminary data to underpin theoretical and methodological
development; strengthen local research capacity and international collaborative links within existing
networks of communities of practice and scholars. These activities are necessary given the
ecological sensitivity of Sunderban, and conceptually-novel and ambitious nature of the planned
larger collaborative research programme that will be submitted for Wellcome Collaborative research
grant.

Project.Title: decolonising the academia in south africa: socio-legal research and south african law.
Project.Description: The aim of the proposal is to enhance the research skills of the current cohort of doctoral students and early career scholars at NWU by exposing them to socio-legal research and the methodologies associated with it. Socio-legal scholarship is an interdisciplinary approach to analysing the relationship between law and society. This will be done by way of a short, immersive workshop offered at the University of Edinburgh by one of the world leaders in the field, Professor Anne Griffiths. The long-term goal of this project is to build capacity in this cohort of future researchers with a view to embedding socio-legal research and methodologies not only in their own work, but also in the legal curricula of their future employers more generally.

Project.Title: over the sea but not far away: using novel methods to explore socio-economic impacts and benefits from the aberdeen offshore wind farm
Project.Description:
This research will build on the extensive experience and skills of the project team to assess the socio-economic impacts and benefits of the Aberdeen Offshore Wind Farm.  It will explore how impacts can be most appropriately assessed, how benefits should be defined and delivered, and how both of these can influence public and stakeholder responses to the wind farm.  
The project will combine all three of the suggested research theme sub-topics to produce a comprehensive understanding of the key socio-economic issues.  More specifically it will:
-	Conduct longitudinal research to assess change: we will apply our previous published research on the way in which public responses to on- and off-shore wind farms can change over time to understand the key factors that matter, how they vary, and how shape public perceptions
-	Use innovative methods to explore value and meaning:  we will draw on our research for the Scottish Government on assessing socio-economic impacts of marine energy to holistically understand a range of different impacts that occur throughout the lifetime of the project, and how these can best be managed
-	Apply a novel benefits framework: we established, in an innovative framework developed for the Scottish Government, that definitions of relevant communities, impacts, and benefits from offshore wind energy are inescapably related to each other.  In this project, we will apply this framework to develop a comprehensive understanding of how impacts from the wind farm are shaped, how relevant communities can be involved, and how benefits can ensured.
Our research would be academically rigorous yet focused on targeted outcomes and policy relevant findings. We have the expertise, experience, and institutional support to ensure a successful project delivering both innovation and impact.

Project.Title: economic lives and survival strategies of 'repeat' refugees: learning from mixed-methods surveys amongst the burundians of north-western tanzania
Project.Description:
The mainstream approach to refugee protection, which limits refugee work rights, is often ill-suited to modern crises where
protracted and repeat instability prevents a durable mass return to countries of origin. On the ground, refugees in protracted crisis have often developed ad hoc income generating activities and safety nets, informally and sometimes across borders. This is especially true for the cases of re-displacements, the many hot spots in the world where repeat refugees are intermittently leaving from and returning to fragile countries, often from and to countries that are already
extremely poor and sometimes themselves unstable. Little is understood of such 'repeat refugees' economies', and advances in the field require a socio-economic analysis that is deeply sensitive to history and the cycles of returns and departures. By adopting this approach, the present study will not only expand the frontier of current refugee and peace building research, but it will also participate in a complete rethinking of refugee assistance and refugee crisis prevention and resolution.
The focus of this project is on the Burundians who have found shelter in Tanzania in the past year. According to World Food Programme experts, 60 to 80% of them could be repeat refugees. Anecdotal evidence from researchers and aid organisations suggest key areas of investigations that are also clear gaps in the existing literature on refugees: (1) the flow of Burundians is mixed, with 'official' refugees who go to camps, but also less 'legal' migrants who purposely avoid the camps and reportedly tap into cross-border networks for survival; (2) the strict encampment policy does prevent income generating activities to 'illegally' develop in the camps ; and (3) some of the latest humanitarian innovations In Tanzanian are around developing income generating activities for the refugees.
The core of the project consists of a mixed-methods survey of the repeat Burundian refugees in Tanzania, inside and outside refugee camps, allowing a comparison between refugees who benefited from income-oriented aid programmes from aid organisations and refugees who have not. The main methods for investigating the livelihoods of the refugees are household surveys that are inspired by recent work in economics but also history. The surveys include a module on the household history of displacement and economic activity. These data are complemented with in-depth focus groups and interviews with groups of refugees, who, based on the survey data, seem to present an interesting perspective for thickening and explaining the trends unveiled by the survey. Finally, because some behaviours may be hard to comprehend through surveys and even longer qualitative interviews, participatory mapping of economic activities and a series of behavioural games on assessing the level of trust and collective action will be organised with the refugees. The
originality of the methodological approach is, therefore, double: it combines methods and looks at economic activity through time.
The project will bring together researchers based in the UK with Burundian and Tanzanian researchers and involve key stakeholders such as policy-makers, aid organisations, and the refugees themselves at the different stages of the project (design, implementation, analysis, and dissemination of results). Standard methods of data analysis such as regression models and network and discourse analysis will be combined with innovative forms of output delivery such as interactive maps and infographics. Another key output of the research will be workshops and bilateral with policy-makers and other stakeholders that will be devised to help integrate the findings of the research into policies about refugee welfare and local economic development and could also contribute to the re-starting the social and political dialogue in Burundi.

Project.Title: economic analysis of collective bargaining extensions (cobext) project
Project.Description: Collective bargaining (CB) and its extensions are key aspects of industrial relations in many Member States (MS). Extensions, issued explicitly by governments or representing benchmarks within sectors, widen the provisions of CB (including minimum wages by occupation) to a potentially large number of firms and workers that are not members of employer associations and unions. Extensions may also influence the membership rates of the latter organisations, as well as their incentives to conduct CB. This Action will obtain and disseminate some of the first micro evidence about the economic impact of CB and its extensions, drawing on the expertise of the leading economists and former policy-makers that participate in the project, promoting greater awareness of this topic.

Project.Title: on becoming a mother: preconception experiences and needs of women with severe mental illness and their implications for health services delivery
Project.Description: This qualitative study will contribute to an understanding of the nature of stigma and how this manifests within women with severe mental illness of child bearing age and how they access and use preconception care within the health care setting. The principal aim of the present study is to identify and map current pathways for preconception care within NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde. It will establish where changes can be made to service provision to enable women to feel more empowered in their decision making processes in relation to family planning of future pregnancies. Undertaking this study will identify areas for complex intervention development with the aim of improving outcomes in both maternal and family mental and physical health. We will submit an application to NIHR to test the feasibility of developing a preconception based intervention to determine where in the care pathway this intervention should be delivered.

Project.Title: sustainable integration of wave energy in the aa economy through synergies with maritime activities
Project.Description:
Resource efficiency
2.1. Fostering renewable energies and energy efficiency
Technology transfer and university-enterprise cooperation, Renewable energy: marine

Wave energy is called upon to play a role in the European energy mix but
significant obstacles still exist. SIWEIS will foster wave energy growth through
integration with other maritime uses (transport, energy, aquaculture). Using
Blue Economy priority sectors, 5 main obstacles will be addressed: reliability;
survivability; sustainability; LCOE and environmental integration. The main
outputs will be a GIS tool and an integrated strategy to leverage wave energy
under a transnational approach.

The aim of this project is to achieve sustainable integration of wave energy
into the AA economy by means of innovative synergies with other maritime
activities (transport, energy, aquaculture & support services). Wave
energy is one of the most promising marine renewable resources and one
of the Blue Growth Priorities. Almost 45% of wave energy developers are
European and a new, homegrown industrial sector is emerging. However, the
wave energy sector is at a crucial stage where cost and risk reduction are
needed in order to attract investors. The overarching objective of SIWEIS is
to develop an integrated AA strategy to accelerate wave energy development
from basic research to demonstration projects, through the integration of wave
energy converters with existing and mature maritime economic activities.
Three specific objectives will be addressed: (1) identify synergies between
wave energy and other maritime activities and classify the AA potential
for a multiuse maritime space approach; (2) cluster wave energy resource
availability, focusing on met-ocean conditions, socio-economic benefits and
synergies with other uses; (3) identify the most relevant technological needs
for wave energy developers in the AA in order to maximize the rate of success
and minimize risks/costs of demonstration projects. The results obtained
from SIWEIS will impact on the current situation by characterizing the socioeconomic
impact of wave energy development and integration in the AA.

Project.Title: robocrab: an integrative approach to the natural ecology of decision making
Project.Description: Autonomous robots are as yet unable to operate adaptively in natural conditions. Animals have solved this problem and are highly competent and effective decision makers. The outcome of this project will be a detailed understanding of how sensory and neural systems in the crab support fast and accurate escape decisions, reflecting both what they see and its context. It will thus provide impact both in the ecology of predator-prey interactions and in design of autonomous decision making systems.

Project.Title: cognitive strategies employed by hearing and deaf secondary students while reading on line
Project.Description:
The increasing use of the Internet by schools as a teaching and learning tool, e.g., for information gathering, brings the need to better understand the reading patterns and cognitive processes readers use to access and comprehend digital texts. To maximize internet-based teaching potential, we seek to identify information-seeking and evaluating strategies used by hearing and deaf children
when reading internet-based materials. Comparing reading strategies used by hearing and deaf children –who show different visuo-spatial skills - can provide new insights into the relationship between language and more general cognitive abilities. We will compare online reading strategies (i.e., the use of graphics, text,
multiple pages and review strategies) in hearing children who use English and deaf children, who use either English or British Sign Language as a preferred language. Our goal is to determine which cognitive skills map onto diverse outcomes in online reading. The findings will inform teaching methodologies for both hearing and deaf children.

PI.Name: Rachel O'Neill

Project.Title: psi-borg- psychophysically analysis and physiologically-based recognition of computer generated humans
Project.Description:
Imagine a future where computer-generated human characters become almost indistinguishable from the real thing. It is not that far away. Real-time rendering of photo-realistic facial animation is just around the corner. Text-to-speech synthesis is already as intelligible as human speech and is getting more natural every year. To prepare for this world, in which computer generated content will be intermingled with the natural, there is a fundamental need to understand how human beings can preserve the awareness of what is real and what is not. This main objective can be further specified into 4 major facets thatcombine scientific understanding with practical benefits:
1. Discover the characteristics of human perception of computer-generated imitations of humans, to explore the edges of
lifelike characters creation.
2. An understanding of how interactions between humans and computer-generated characters affect human emotional
processing, perception and decision-making.
3. New techniques for automatic detection of computer-generated images and speech, necessary to maintain trust in online
content and computer-mediated communication, and confidence in facial- and speech-based authentication.
4. An evaluation of the societal impact of widespread computer-generated content, considering trust, acceptance and ethics.
PSI-BORG will achieve these objectives with novel interdisciplinary research that brings together methods from computer vision (facial analysis), computer graphics (photo-realistic rendering and animation), speech processing (speech synthesis), forensics & biometrics (speaker verification, identification), cognitive neuroscience & psychophysics (reaction time, detection, galvanic skin response, brain activity), and ethics. PSI-BORG directly addresses the question of being human in a technological world under Area 1 (Future technologies for societal change) of FETPROACT-01-2016.

Project.Title: reducing and preventing cognitive impairment in older age groups (the recon programme)
Project.Description:
Dementia occurs in 6.5% of those aged over 65, and the number of
sufferers will increase due to people living longer. Reduced functioning
(‘cognitive impairment’) is more common - including Mild Cognitive
Impairment (MCI) and Age Associated Cognitive decline (AACD) (for
definitions see below) - and approximately 5% progress to dementia
annually. Intensive promotion of healthy behaviours (diet/physical activity) and cognitive exercises slow cognitive decline but use considerable staff resource.

Aim: To develop and test efficient internet-supported healthy behaviour/cognitive exercises to reduce cognitive decline among older age adults.

Project.Title: mascca: membrane-assisted simultaneous capture and catalytic abatement of n2o and ch4 from waste water treatment plant emissions
Project.Description:
In 2017, non-CO2 GHGs in general were estimated to have contributed 27% to global warming -18% from CH4 and 6% from N2O and 3% (other gases). The European Commission estimates that 3%- 4% of global N2O emissions and 9% of global CH4 emissions derive from (WWTP).

Within such a framework, Membrane-Assisted Simultaneous Capture and Catalytic Abatement of N2O and CH4 from waste water treatment plant emissions (MASCCA) project aims at directly addressing the problem of non-CO2 GHG emissions of N2O and CH4
through the development of an innovative technological solution for their efficient capture and reduction. 

The MASCCA integrated technology involves several processes including the quantification of gases in biological wastewater
treatment facilities (WWTPs), the design of efficient capture systems for both gases, the subsequent separation of gases using nmembrane technologies and the final catalytic abatement destructive treatment

Project.Title: evaluation of fish waste as a novel feedstock for the bio-production of adipic acid in escherichia coli
Project.Description: Adipic acid is one of the most important compounds in the modern chemical industry and is used, amongst other applications, in the production of 6,6-nylon. Three million tonnes of adipic acid are produced each year, representing a market value of $5.6 billion. However, despite predicted increases in the demand for adipic acid in the future, due to a growing population, this cannot occur due to environmental regulations imposed as a result of the unacceptable levels of greenhouse gasses emitted from this industrial process. In particular, adipic acid production releases nitric oxide, a greenhouse gas 300-times more damaging than CO2, and is responsible for 10% of N2O emissions worldwide. Therefore, new greener methods for the production of adipic acid are urgently required. Here, we will assess the ability of genetically modified bacteria to convert fish waste into adipic acid under mild conditions via a pathway that avoids the release of N2O.

Project.Title: novel process for efficient bio-methanisation of waste-derived syngas
Project.Description: Carbogenics Ltd. and the University of Edinburgh (UoE) aim to prove the feasibility of a new fermentation technology for efficient conversion of syngas gas into bio-methane. Syngas, which contains CO and H2 is produced by pyrolysis from a broad range of carbon based material including problematic wastes. This project investigates the use of screening waste from food waste anaerobic digestion for syngas production. This abundant waste contains both plastic and biobased substances and is usually sent to landfill at high disposal costs. Thus, owners of food waste AD plants are looking for alternative ways to valorise it. Carbogenics’ new syngas fermentation technology can unlock the conversion of screening waste by means of pyrolysis and subsequent syngas biomethanisation. In this project, Carbogenics will bring in its technical and commercial knowledge in the areas of pyrolysis and fermentation, while UoE will contribute with its world-renowned scientific expertise in applied microbial ecology (Free lab).

Project.Title: reduction of landfill gas and leachate pollution from solid waste landfill via implementation of 2-dimensional nanomaterial mixed matrix membranes (mmms) to foster a green and sustainable environment
Project.Description:
Industrialization, rapid urbanization and population explosion in recent decades have 
increased solid waste generation that creates substantial challenges on solid waste 
management. In India, only 43 metric tons of solid waste is collected annually out of 
which 27.9% waste are treated and 72% waste are dumped in landfill. Landfill gas (LFG) 
is generated owing to the decomposition of solid waste. LFG contains greenhouse 
gases (GHGs) and methane (CH4). LFG emission to the atmosphere without proper 
treatment could increase greenhouse gas emission and has a great impact on global 
climate change. Percolation of water via landfill generates leachate which contains 
complex organic and inorganic contaminants. Leachate treatment is needed for 
protecting subsurface and surface water resources from deterioration. In analogous, the 
effect of solid waste is interconnected with the air, water pollution and spreading of 
diseases.  
The concern on solid waste alone is not enough but focusing direction on LFG and 
leachate management would alleviate pollution that sound well in developing 
sustainable environment for mankind. Among numerous technologies, membrane 
technology is one of the most energy-efficient alternatives for separating LFG and 
leachate treatment. Membrane technology has smaller footprint, low energy 
consumption and eco-friendly than the conventional treatment. The idea of this project is 
to efficiently separate LFG (CO2 and CH4) and leachate using membrane technology. 
Joint collaboration (India and UK)  would aid in transferring skills and technology that 
would promote novel solutions to the existing problem, foster safe environment and 
anticipated outcome would meets the constraints of the scientific, engineering and 
community members. Further, managing LFG and leachate using membrane technology 
would render significance to various environmental developments such as promote 
energy (CO2 and CH4 separation), sustainable resources for mankind, reduce climate 
change finally reduces impact of solid waste disposed at landfill.

Project.Title: molecular up-cycling: bio-transforming waste plastic into value-added products
Project.Description:
It is estimated that 8 million tonnes of plastic waste end up in the oceans each year and that by 2050 there could be more
plastic in the seas by weight than fish. This plastic is both incredibly dangerous to marine ecosystems and also sequesters
materials prepared from non-renewable fossil fuels, with just ~14% currently being recycled globally each year. It has been
estimated that recycling the remaining 86% of plastics could generate up to $120bn, but new methods and processes to
transform waste plastic into value-added products must be developed in order to realise this potential. The proposed
research will focus on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) as a feedstock for a bio-based 'molecular up-cycling' platform to
produce value-added, industrially relevant small molecules. PET accounts for 15% of plastic waste in the UK, out of which
~60% is accounted for by synthetic fibres and 30% by plastic bottles, whilst other uses include plastic wrappers and films
and thermoforming for manufacturing. Although chemical and thermal methods for PET recycling are well-established,
there is a dramatic loss in value throughout the plastic life-cycle, with the value of the waste PET bottles being 86% lower
than the virgin polymer.
This Fellowship proposal unites cutting edge research from both the chemical and biological sciences to transform waste
PET into high-value small molecules. The research will address the global plastic waste disaster twofold by (i) decreasing
the amount of plastic waste deposited in the environment in the future and (ii) transforming pre-existing, low-value waste
products into industrially relevant, value-added products via a new 'molecular up-cycling' process. The research will be
organised into two phases. Initially, a robust and efficient plastic degradation process will be developed. This will exploit
PET degrading enzymes that have been isolated from microbes found in landfill sites, which have evolved to use PET as a
carbon source for growth. In the second phase, the PET degradation technology will be integrated with 'microbial cell
factories', which we will genetically programme to turn the degradation products of PET into industrially relevant small
molecules. The initial target of the project will be the synthesis of vanillin - the primary extract from the vanilla bean and the
primary molecule responsible for the characteristic smell and taste of vanilla. Vanillin is used extensively for flavours and
fragrances and is also a valuable intermediate in the production of fine chemicals such as pharmaceuticals. As such, it has
huge commercial value, with the global market for vanillin estimated to reach $724.5 million by 2025. Beyond this, the
project also holds great potential for the production of a range of other high-value small molecules which are accessible
through developing and integrating novel, bio-compatible chemical reactions with the PET degradation system. Such compounds include pharmaceuticals, fragrance/flavouring compounds, agrochemicals and polymers. As such, it is
anticipated that this project will have significant academic and industrial value, as well having a positive impact on the
environment by removing plastic waste from the natural environment.

Project.Title: optimisation of recovery of valuable metals from waste printed circuit boards (wpcbs) through modified hydrometallurgical route
Project.Description:
The proposed work intends to maximize the recovery of valuable metals from waste
printed circuit boards which are a great emerging source for various metals. Both
research groups have separate, yet complimentary expertise and have exemplified their
expertise their respective domains through numerous research projects and published
research papers in reputed journals. The Indian partners are able to separate metallic
and non-metallic components of waste printed circuit boards whereas the recovery of
gold from mobile phone PCBs is well studied by the group of the UK partner. The
combination of these expertise would facilitate the development of a new process to
recycle waste PCBs. The process described in this proposal is expected to be
eco-friendly as it obviates the emission of hazardous fumes and toxic gases by current
pyrolysis and high temperature methods adopted by recyclers. Also, solvent extraction
techniques for the separation of metals can be applied at the site of collection of waste
electronics, so benefiting the local economy and limiting transport of materials. Being
cost effective, it would be applicable to a large number of prospective users in Asian
countries.

Project.Title: innovative biological methanation and fuel processing for the production of liquefied biomethane as a regional waste treatment concept
Project.Description:
Energy collection, conversion and storage, renewable energy
Bioenergy
LNG, Liquefied Biomethane, Biological Methanation, Gas Upgrading, Liquefaction


The BioMeLT project aims at developing new and innovative technologies for converting bioresidues or biowaste and excess
renewable electricity to liquefied biomethane (LBM) for maritime and heavy-duty road transport and reducing GHG
emissions and pollutants in Europe. The BioMeLT process shall be implemented to existing small and medium scale
(bio-)waste treatment plants switching to Pt-LBM mode whenever excess renewable electricity is available. For the BioMeLT
process, e.g. the unused EU municipal solid biowaste potential can be applied, covering the EU transport sector fuel
capacity.
As biomass gasification results in the most critical gas, the WoodRoll® gasification technology from CE will serve as uniform
starting point for evaluating the BioMeLT process chain. For small and decentralized application, a simple and robust
methanation concept is favourable in terms of costs and user-friendly operation. Therefore, three new and innovative
Biological Methanation (BM) concepts will be evaluated, covering intrinsic kinetics, optimization of mass transfer and back
coupling effects on the entire process chain. The project will contribute to extending the knowledge in the field of BM, which
will help to quantify the potentials of this promising technology. In parallel to the research on BM, gas upgrading and
liquefaction technologies will be optimized and adapted to the process chain’s needs. Sound reactor modelling will allow
scale-up of the process chain to demonstrator scale directly. The industrial partners cover the scope of all applied
technologies and will contribute to transferring the results into the market.
The implementation strategy and the use of renewable electricity complies with the EC SET plan and H2020 perspectives of
applying interconnections between the energy networks and offering power grid storage and flexibilization options.
Furthermore, it gives the EU LNG strategy a green perspective in short to mid term by substitution of LNG by LBM.
Sponsor.Name: european commission
Scheme.Name: horizon 2020 - secure, clean and efficient energy
PI.Name: Stefano Brandani
