Project.Title: enabling bio co2 capture technologies for the european waste-to-energy sector
Project.Description:
Outline:

Climate change and waste management are societal challenges that have high priority as demonstrated
by the first universal climate agreement adopted by 195 countries at the Paris COP21 in 2016 and the
EU action plan for the Circular Economy Package, setting clear targets on waste management and
recycling to develop a sustainable, low carbon, resource efficient and competitive economy in the
future. Non-recyclable waste logically finds its role by feeding back its energy content in heating,
cooling and electricity production, compatible with the 7th Environment Action Programme to phase
out landfilling in the EU, and to develop a resource-efficient, green, and competitive low-carbon
economy. According to the Confederation of European Waste-to-Energy Plants (CEWEP) 88.4 Mt of
waste were thermally treated in Europe in 2014 in 455 plants, corresponding to an equal amount of
CO2 emissions (following the IPCC methodology), and generating 38 TWh of electricity and 88
TWh of heat. According to EUROSTAT only 13% of municipal solid waste (MSW) were energy
recovered in 2013, with a great disparity between the countries. These facts are a striking evidence of
the large potential for both retrofit and greenfield commercial CO2 capture projects for the waste-toenergy
(WtE) sector in the short term. Additionally, it is accepted that a fraction of 33% to 50% of
waste is of biogenic origin, therefore enhancing the CO2 reduction potential of the WtE sector through
the possible concept of carbon negativity (bio-CCS). The need for carbon negative solutions can be an
opportunity to introduce CCS to large CO2 emitters at community service level. Although there is little
public acceptance of CCS in the WtE to the applicants’ knowledge, it could attract for support from
stakeholders in the same way that CCS in heavy industries does. The WtE sector is not included in EU
Emissions Trading System and will not have access to flexible mechanisms and possibilities within
ETS. To follow-up on the EU 2030 targets of 40% reduction, cuts will have to be taken by the sector
itself. As such, the CapeWaste project intends to be a reference project in CCS applied to the WtE
sector in Europe. The unique application of CO2 capture technology to a WtE plant, as known by the
applicants, is the pilot tests performed at the Klemetsrud plant near Oslo in 2016. According to the
public information available, the project has shown that conventional post-combustion CO2 capture is
technically feasible. In parallel to the roadmap from the EC Communi-cation Initiative on waste to
energy, the CapeWaste project will address technological, commercial and societal issues for
introducing CO2 capture into the WtE sector. CapeWaste intends to progress a panel of technologies
for retrofit and greenfield plants, that have the potential to achieve further improvement in efficiency
and costs in the WtE sector.

Full:

Climate change and waste management are two high priority societal challenges as demonstrated by Paris COP21 and the EU's Circular Economy Package, setting clear targets on waste management and low carbon economy for the future. CO2 capture from the waste sector is an industrial initiative that addresses both challenges with the added potential for being carbon negative (Bio-CCUS) and stimulating job creation. Recent feasibility studies and pilot scale testing at Waste-to-Energy sites in Norway, the Netherlands, and the UK, are strong drivers to establish a European project gathering a convincing consortium in order to advance selected CO2 capture solutions for a challenging fuel like waste. CapeWaste intends to address the challenges of selected capture technologies that have a potential for large scale demonstration within 2025. These technologies are categorized as suited for retrofit (solvent based and calcium looping), and greenfield applications (oxy-fuel combustion and oxy-sorbent enhanced reforming gasification. To accelerate the deployment of these technologies, lessons must be learned at a scale that benefits the industrial development, therefore several pilot operation activities are planned in a total of four industrial sites and several large scale laboratory facilities. One example is the delivery of the basis for a pre-FEED of the potential future Norwegian Haraldrud Waste-to-Energy plant (EGE) with oxy-fuel CO2 capture. An in-depth analysis of selected technologies will be performed through environmental assessment by combining Life Cycle Analysis and scenario modelling tools. Policy aspects is also included to analyze the implication of CCS from the waste sector as a carbon negative solution. 24 partners (research, academic, industry, agency) from Germany, Netherlands, Norway, Romania, and UK form an experienced project consortium with access to top class facilities.

Project.Title: reuse, recycling, and redemption in buddhist manuscripts
Project.Description: Issues of life and death in Japanese Buddhist art revolved around reuse and recycling. Yet because these practices have been overlooked, we do not fully understand the creative ways in which the living channelled their grief and ensured better karmic outcomes for dead loved ones. Focusing on Buddhist palimpsests, in which new text is transcribed on top of existing writing, this project explores how medieval Buddhists observed the deceased’s memory and recovered their presence after death. Mourners copied sacred text on repurposed letters directly atop the original writing or on the paper’s back. These textual compositions challenge art historical notions of  foreground/background and dominant/periphery. In some cases, the original letter was deconstructed and reformed into new paper, exposing a radical concept that presence is embedded even within the fibres of paper itself. These neglected yet fecund manuscripts thus draw together critical themes of memory, embodiment, and medieval recycling in ways that resonate across cultures and disciplines looking at the materiality of death.

Project.Title: beyond nature: engineered enzymes and modified nicotinamides for sustainable biosynthesis
Project.Description: Synthetic biology is a transformational technology that has the potential to revolutionise energy, manufacturing, healthcare and waste-remediation, facilitating sustainable economic growth and positive environmental impact worldwide. Advances in knowledge and understanding over the past decade have enabled the design of biological systems that make compounds such as medicines, materials and fuels that are essential in our everyday lives. These products can be made directly from renewable resources using biological means, offering a route to a net neutral carbon economy. However, real world application of these technologies continues to be challenging as biology has vast complexity and our understanding of these systems is limited. The aim of this research is to address both of these problems through the combination of chemical design and enzyme engineering, which will allow the introduction of a new independent biological energy circuit into bacteria and develop a new biological reaction for use in sustainable compound production. In summary, the project will expand the number of possible reactions that can be programmed into biological systems ensuring diversification of the bioeconomy and the drive toward a sustainable future.
Sponsor.Name: engineering and physical sciences research council
Scheme.Name: fellowship
PI.Name: Stephen Wallace

Project.Title: nest:  next generation indoor solar cells for energy sustainable iot
Project.Description:
NEST targets the development of a green indoor photovoltaic (PV) cells converting both natural and artificial low-light power
produced inside the buildings and to make use of this clean source of energy for generating sustainable power to Internet-ofThings (IoT). To reach this innovative objective, the ground approach is based on the best proven technology for this type of
application, namely indoor dye-sensitized solar cells technology (indoor-DSC) (TRL3) with including specific development in
terms of materials (dye, electrolyte, cell structure optimization) in order to reach 45 % power conversion efficiency under 200
– 1000 lux range power from LEDs. Going beyond materials tailoring and lab-device optimization towards module levels,
NEST will encompass also new technological innovations for DSC modules with the development of ultra-thin flexible glass
modules of up to 70 cm2 including a laser-sealed hybrid glass-frit encapsulation. NEST technology will burgeon important
advances towards a low-cost, lightweight and ultra-thin module adapted to sustainable IoTs in order to render them totally
portative and powered without means of plug-in recharge or grid-connections. IoTs will be soon a mass product, NEST
anticipates recyclability activities of the module components including systematic LCA loop calculations towards reaching
second-life DSC modules with specific objectives in terms of performances.

Project.Title: crafting myanmar. the role of the youth in the sustainable creative economy
Project.Description:
The story of Myanmar's transformation has typically been told from the top-down, with a clear emphasis on the importance of military and/or charismatic leadership . Exceptions are rare, especially when it comes to capturing the role, challenges and aspirations of local youth. The project seeks to address this gap in research and scholarship by generating knowledge on Myanmar's youth (one in two people is below the age of 30). Integrating insights from the sociology of youth, urban studies and political economy , this project seeks to provide a nuanced understanding of Myanmar's youth, its aspirations, challenges and potential. Focusing on the cases of Yangon, Mandalay, and Lashio, it uses the creative economy as a vantage point to generate knowledge on this issue and arts and practice-methods to empower and amplify the voices and skills
of local youth and integrate them in the process of knowledge production and dissemination.

Project.Title: towards a sustainable future for sri lanka's elasmobranch fisheries
Project.Description:
Elasmobranchs are of global conservation concern with over a quarter of the >1,250 species considered
threatened with extinction. Population declines are primarily due to overfishing, either through targeted
fisheries, or as bycatch, particularly within tuna fisheries. Despite increasing recognition of these issues,
significant knowledge gaps remain regarding the distribution and population structure of most elasmobranchs,
resulting in limited fisheries regulation or conservation management planning at a national level.
Sri Lanka operates a significant tuna-fishing fleet and, partly as a consequence, has one of the world’s largest
multi-species elasmobranch bycatch fisheries and as such, is a key focal country for elasmobranch
biodiversity conservation. There is an urgent need to develop alternative, sustainable, fishing and commercial
trade practices at a national level however, to date there is little awareness of the opportunities and benefits of
such approaches among the Sri Lankan fishing industry.
This project aims to support management of Indian Ocean elasmobranch populations through delivering
biological data to inform Sri Lankan fisheries policy, developing national capacity for monitoring, control and
surveillance of shark and ray fisheries, and engaging with industry and community stakeholders to promote
alternative tuna-fishing methods that support sustainable local economic development and ensure long-term
elasmobranch conservation.

Project.Title: towards a sustainable platform for supporting mental wellbeing and resilience in nepal
Project.Description:
The people of Nepal, a landlocked country in the Himalayan region, face many challenges to their mental health, including poverty, emigration, and trauma due to the recent civil war (1996-2005)
and earthquake (2015). The aim of this grant is to kickstart the sustainable development of a technology platform that Nepalese people can use to improve their mental wellbeing under difficult circumstances, and to build a national and international network of stakeholders to support sustainable development and maintenance. The platform will be designed to support interventions that increase a sense of belonging and foster wellbeing in place. Crucially, the  platform will use local languages instead of English and familiar visual designs and colour schemes, and it will be anchored in local contexts and environments of use.

Project.Title: dynamics: design of yield and natural resource-augmenting measures for the sustainable intensification of farming systems
Project.Description:
DYNAMICS will identify and validate scalable pathways for sustainable intensification (SI) of smallholder farming systems in
East Africa. A multi-disciplinary team will work with regional and local stakeholders, an approach which will ensure demanddriven research and innovation through planning, implementation, scaling and dissemination phases. We focus on dominant
farming systems: maize mixed, root crops, highland perennial, highland temperate mixed and agro-pastoral. DYNAMICS will
be delivered through 6 work packages: 1) facilitating stakeholder platforms for priority setting, evaluation and validation of
interventions, initiating public-private partnerships for scaling promising interventions, and capacity development building on
existing Africa-EU partnerships; 2) validating and operationalising a quantitative framework for the evaluation of SI
interventions; 3) piloting pathways towards SI of smallholder farming systems that recognise different agro-ecologies and
farming household diversity and are gender and culturally responsive; 4) co-creating natural resource management tools and
products with specific focus on efficient use of water and nutrients and the build-up of soil organic matter, aiming to restore
and protect land resources for future generations; 5) assessing and accelerating the scalability of validated SI interventions
within current and future scenarios, as affected by major drivers of change; and 6) engagement and knowledge exchange.
DYNAMICS embeds inclusive and equitable approaches that address gender and generational differences. The project uses
novel data science and informatics techniques, innovation mapping, and includes value chain approaches with investment
partners. We will address the challenge of moving towards SI of agriculture to ensure food security and reduce negative
environmental impacts of agriculture in a changing climate with unpredictable and restricted water supply and demand, and
increased degradation of resources.

Project.Title: reduction of landfill gas and leachate pollution from solid waste landfill via implementation of 2-dimensional nanomaterial mixed matrix membranes (mmms) to foster a green and sustainable environment
Project.Description:
Industrialization, rapid urbanization and population explosion in recent decades have 
increased solid waste generation that creates substantial challenges on solid waste 
management. In India, only 43 metric tons of solid waste is collected annually out of 
which 27.9% waste are treated and 72% waste are dumped in landfill. Landfill gas (LFG) 
is generated owing to the decomposition of solid waste. LFG contains greenhouse 
gases (GHGs) and methane (CH4). LFG emission to the atmosphere without proper 
treatment could increase greenhouse gas emission and has a great impact on global 
climate change. Percolation of water via landfill generates leachate which contains 
complex organic and inorganic contaminants. Leachate treatment is needed for 
protecting subsurface and surface water resources from deterioration. In analogous, the 
effect of solid waste is interconnected with the air, water pollution and spreading of 
diseases.  
The concern on solid waste alone is not enough but focusing direction on LFG and 
leachate management would alleviate pollution that sound well in developing 
sustainable environment for mankind. Among numerous technologies, membrane 
technology is one of the most energy-efficient alternatives for separating LFG and 
leachate treatment. Membrane technology has smaller footprint, low energy 
consumption and eco-friendly than the conventional treatment. The idea of this project is 
to efficiently separate LFG (CO2 and CH4) and leachate using membrane technology. 
Joint collaboration (India and UK)  would aid in transferring skills and technology that 
would promote novel solutions to the existing problem, foster safe environment and 
anticipated outcome would meets the constraints of the scientific, engineering and 
community members. Further, managing LFG and leachate using membrane technology 
would render significance to various environmental developments such as promote 
energy (CO2 and CH4 separation), sustainable resources for mankind, reduce climate 
change finally reduces impact of solid waste disposed at landfill.

Project.Title: shining a light on sustainable agriculture: applying an evidence-based framework for assessing sustainability of agricultural interventions in africa
Project.Description: Agriculture provides most of the edible nutrients used by mankind and is maintaining billions of livelihoods, not just those of farmers but also retailers, consumers and other value chain actors. Furthermore, it plays a key role in regulating environmental services mainly through land and water use, nutrient cycles, and climate feedbacks. On current projections, however, agriculture needs to do more. Firstly, production must increase to provide enough food for a rapidly growing world population. Agriculture then needs to fulfil its potential to contribute to reducing poverty and improving the nutrition of people in low and middle-income countries. Areas of land that are suitable for spatial expansion of agriculture are extremely limited. This dictates that future advances must focus on intensifying the use of current agricultural land and other inputs. Moreover, this cannot simply be a short-term imperative but rather must be achieved in ways that can meet the needs of future generations, i.e. any intensification promoted must be sustainable intensification (SI). Currently, there is no commonly accepted way to assess whether SI pathways are indeed sustainable. In this project we will use mainly existing datasets to develop repeatable methodologies for applying the recently-developed Sustainable Intensification Indicator Framework (SIAF) to this question. The SIAF allows us to evaluate changes in production intensity driven by interventions or other factors across five sustainability domains: production, economic, human, social and environmental. The framework also has the potential to be implemented at multiple scales and the project proposed here aims to strengthen its capacity to do so in a systematic fashion. The project's activities will be based on a set of three contrasting case studies - in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia and Uganda - conducted with local implementing partners. Studies will test whether SIAF can be applied repeatedly across the case study production systems and agro-ecologies to generate interpretable qualitative and quantitative assessments of the sustainability side of the SI trajectories currently being promoted by the case study projects. The results of our analyses will be discussed with and evaluated by local partners to ground truth the utility of the approach. We will also compare results amongst case studies to identify common lessons on the implementation of SI. Finally, we will evaluate the SIAF approach used and conduct a critical assessment of whether systems approaches, like that employed by the SIAF, generate useful information for both local partners and more regionally-oriented policy prioritization as well as generating new scientific insights into the functioning of the contrasting production / agro-ecosystems studied. We will produce a robust, easily-applied 'Sustainable Intensification Assessment Tool' (SIAT) to assess and guide 'local' SI options in smallholder farming systems in low and middle-income countries.

Project.Title: modelling sustainable intensification pathways for brazilian livestock production (msip)
Project.Description:
This project considers environmental and economic trade-offs inherent in the need for Brazil to sustainably produce more from agriculture while minimising environmental costs in terms of greenhouse gas emissions from production (i.e. livestock), deforestation and associated loss of ecosystem services. A wider context for this imperative is the increasing global demand for food production, the need to moderate or at least understand changing consumption patterns (esp. meat), and Brazil's ambition to maintain its pre-eminent status as a global agri commodity exporter, while maintaining domestic food security and social equality.
Sustainable agricultural intensification (SAI) is the term coined for this challenge, and widely discussed in academic and policy circles. However, it is arguably not substantiated by convincing models showing production and consumption trade-offs at different scales. This project contributes by using a mathematical modelling approach applied to depict farms and producing regions. A mathematical model also allows us to engage in the currently debated issue of reducing meat consumption; specifically using real data to illustrate the consequences of reducing consumption in a more systematic rather than partial way.
This research team has already made a significant impact to this debate in developing model outputs to describe the options for intensifying Cerrado beef production systems. This multi-disciplinary contribution has been recognised domestically in Brazil by EMBRAPA (https://goo.gl/5L5U8X) and in terms of the design of key policy incentives for low carbon agriculture - Agricultura de Baixo Carbono, (ABC), and internationally in terms of Brazil's commitments at COP21, where the country proposed a voluntary emissions reduction target of around 40% relative to baseline emissions by 2030 to be achieved by Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC).
This project aims to improve the model using evidence from experimental farms developed with UFMT and EMBRAPA in a number of ways to characterise intensification scenarios and cost-benefit trade-offs in other Brazilian ecosystems (or biomes). This includes livestock and soybean production plus mixed crop and livestock; its consequences in terms of deforestation, climate change mitigation, and implications for climate adaptation and of consumption shifts. The benefits can be characterised as direct and indirect, in that intensification can be direct in terms of measures that reduce emissions and that make the system more resilient, and indirect related to land sparing and hence the reduction of deforestation. As noted the modelling can evaluate both the supply and demand side perspectives, allowing us to analyse production ambitions, while also addressing the potential system consequences of supply or consumption management implicit in emerging dietary guidelines.
The following research questions will be addressed through further model innovation:
How much emissions mitigation is delivered through SAI applied at different scales and at what cost per tonne of emission (CO2e)?
How do SAI measures also contribute to system adaptation to climate change and what are the associated net-benefits including the synergies and trade-offs with mitigation benefits?
In which biomes might SAI yield greatest net benefits?
What are the biophysical, economic and institutional barriers to intensification at different scales of production and what does this imply for policy design?
What are the potential system consequences of reduced livestock consumption nationally? How does implicit change in consumption alter production system and therefore carbon footprint of products?
How does including other lifecycle impacts incl. those related to soybean production change the SAI calculus?
The research comprises 3 work packages focusing on model improvement, experimental data collection, farmer consultation, and model scenarios for policy design

Project.Title: laura jeffery british academy sustainable development programme 2018
Project.Description:
Authorised discourses on heritage and development alike are often said to marginalise local participation, but heritage can play a pivotal role in the informal economy of developing countries, and its potential is not yet fully realised beyond immediate economic gains. This project focuses on the contribution of intangible cultural heritage
(ICH) to post-conflict transformation. Investigating how craft practices can contribute to sustainable livelihoods, inclusivity, and a more equitable society in post-war Sri Lanka, this interdisciplinary project cuts across the themes of heritage, dignity, and violence.
In collaboration with international development agencies, government institutions, third sector organisations, grassroots enterprises, and HEIs, this project will use participatory and co-creation methods to engage with socio-material practices of
Palmyrah handicraft production in Jaffna and to develop community-based approaches to sustainable development and heritage management.

Project.Title: a feminist road map for sustainable peace (led by swedish defence university)
Project.Description:
The overall purpose of the proposed research environment is to create a grouping of researchers of
sufficient diversity and depth to address one of the more complex and challenging issues of our time:
the repeated failure to build sustaining and sustainable peace in fragile and war-affected countries.
We believe this can be accomplished by significantly strengthening and deepening the Women,
Peace and Security agenda such that it addresses the transnational political-economic processes
that tend to undermine peacebuilding in postwar states. As existing theories and methodologies fail
to adequately capture the complexity of the relationship of these processes to peace, the project
draws on theoretical and methodological approaches from multiple disciplines and sectors. It is
organised around a series of international, collaborative knowledge-building workshops, spaced over
four years, which bring together academics, policymakers and practitioners. Each addresses a
particular transnational political-economic dynamic of postwar contexts, such as transportation or
energy infrastructure, extractive industries, commercial export agriculture, or public finance
management, and analyzes the ways that these impact gender relations and other structural
inequalities. The aim of each is to produce knowledge that can underpin and facilitate critical and
practical engagement with, and modification of, those processes, providing a ground-breaking
"Feminist Roadmap for Sustainable Peace".

Project.Title: law carbon practicies: mapping and transforming practices in food, energy and construction towards a sustainable economy.
Project.Description:
Energy and food production and consumption make about half of the global emissions that must be reduced to achieve a liveable planet. Practice theory offers a method for identifying the limits and possibilities of change and practical implications for transformative low-carbon governance. Our objectives are to :
•	using practice theory, identify points for leveraging transformative change in people’s values and practices in contrasting case studies 
•	Conduct research in dialogue with key stakeholders who can take change forward..
•	Create documentation of the research process, stakeholder dialogue and lessons from comparative analysis that will inspire scaling up similar activities elsewhere.
. Our cases involve 1) legal interventions attempting to reduce emissions, 2) life-stage transition as an opportunity of fostering consumption practices change, 3) attempted lower-carbon food production in a deprived community, 4) transformative empowerment potential of off-grid and renewable energy and 5) a site of contradictory change in meat consumption practices. These cases offer contrasting constellations of non-academic partner interests and levels of power that make success in reducing carbon emissions more or less difficult. Teams from the Netherlands, Norway, the UK and India, working in high, upper- and lower-middle income contexts, will share insights developed from these practical examples on how to transform towards more sustainable societies, and map transferable principles for wider change. We will create impact through relationships with non-academic partners, their networks introducing the practice approach to policy and practitioner work and networks of academics with mutually productive research interests.
School: School of Social and Political Science

Scheme.Name: general scheme

Project.Title: can a football-based weight management/physical activity/healthy living programme be adapted for delivery in secure institutional settings to support at-risk groups in positive, sustainable behavioural change?
Project.Description:
Obesity and physical inactivity are major public health problems. Football Fans in Training (FFIT) has successfully used the draw of Scottish Premier League clubs to engage overweight/obese men (a hard-to-reach group) in weight loss and physical activity. However, external constraints mean some men cannot attend club-based weekly programme sessions. The project aims to explore the potential of adapting FFIT for delivery to two such populations (prisoners/patients and shift workers) at secure institutions.
A 2-phase, mixed-methods programme development/pilot evaluation. Phase 1 uses scoping reviews to identify effective components of weight/physical activity/dietary interventions for these populations, and focus groups/interviews to explore the views of participants and staff delivering prototype interventions, which will also be observed. The Phase 1 findings will inform development of separate Phase 2 interventions for prisoners/patients and shift workers. Before-and-after process evaluations will examine their potential to deliver sustained behavioural and physical/mental health changes to the target populations.

Project.Title: sustainable plant protection using peptides to halt pests & diseases in integrated strategies
Project.Description:
University of Glasgow lead.

This project for the ‘Innovations in Plant Protection, SFS-17-2017’ topic will deliver novel, innovative, specific, effective, biopesticides, with significantly reduced environmental impact and which will positively impact food security. The SAPPHIRE project, in delivering its objectives and by cooperating with relevant, parallel, existing H2020 programmes, will address the specific challenge and scope of the topic thus: 

We will deliver
•	Low- or zero-residue environmentally friendly peptide biocontrol agents for sustainable, targeted and efficacious insect pest control thereby lowering reliance on traditional chemical insecticides and avoiding the build up of resistance.
•	Innovations in plant protection/plant health, including plant-disease and plant-insect interactions, towards increased stress resilience for more reliable crop yields.
•	Increased productivity by reducing pest and pathogen-associated losses in fresh produce, contributing to Food and Nutrition Security.
•	New processes towards acceptability, regulation, validated commercialization and appropriate and use of novel biopesticides.

Project.Title: living energy: building interdisciplinary, practice based research capacity for sustainable energy in sub-saharan africa and south asia
Project.Description:
India, Nepal and many sub-Saharan African countries rely on hydrocarbon or biofuels and other environmentally, or economically unaffordable or unreliable energy sources that inadequately meet their rural and urban energy demands.  The equitable provision of secure, sustainable and affordable energy in Sub Saharan Africa and South Asia poses a global challenge that is concurrently social, technical, economic, political and ecological. UN Sustainable Development Goals seek to ensure the availability of affordable, secure and clean energy provision (SDG7) within an equitable and prosperous economy with decent work (SDG8) whilst maintaining or restoring terrestrial and coastal ecosystems from which energy fuelstock is sourced sustainably (SDG15). The scale and interlinked nature of the social, economic and environmental challenges demands a response that itself is interlinked across these countries and communities to provide capacity-building, capability training and education; collaborative research, innovation and knowledge exchange; and effective partnerships with policy and practice stakeholders to increase the sustainable provision and end-use of energy.

Living Energy is a strategic programme of capacity and capability strengthening, partnership building and research, which will catalyse a wider 10-year vision for the production of researchers with the skillsets, networks and know-how to tackle pressing development challenges in sub-Saharan Africa and south Asia. Living Energy aims to synergise the UK's academic capability, in both training and research skills, to support 5 countries (India, Nepal, Malawi, Tanzania, Mozambique) and in-country partners to develop cohorts of skilled interdisciplinary-capable researchers able to inform, co-develop and support communities of practice to tackle goals of delivering socially and environmentally sustainable forms of clean energy. Across five partner countries Living Energy will deliver on UN Sustainable Goals 7, 8 and 15 in line with the objectives of the UK's Aid Strategy and the GCRF agenda.  

Living Energy will deliver outcomes that drive development agendas in these countries, and beyond, to enable transitions to more sustainable provision and end-use of energy. At the end of the 4 years Living Energy will have: 1) provided a programme of local and distance training in research methods to 10,000 graduate researchers equipping them to lead projects to tackle these SD challenges; 2) established an interactive team of 50 doctoral researchers across participating disciplines; 3) created study opportunities and mentorship to 75 early career researchers; 4) delivered bespoke research training to 100 career professionals and executives; 5) funded 15 "living labs" of research that provide opportunities for knowledge exchange, practice based research training and the development of interdisciplinary skills; 6) embedded collaborative, cross-disciplinary and practice based approaches to research training pedagogies in teaching/training curricula at 5 higher education institutions; 7) identified and demonstrated pathways to energy resilience/sustainability through peer-reviewed output; 8) increased UK and partner countries human capacity to address sustainable energy challenges; 9) established and developed numerous effective partnerships with UK and in-country practice partners, and with the policy-forming agencies in and alongside governments, their agencies and energy providers; 10) Increased the numbers of UK academics and institutions contributing to the local development challenges.

The legacy of Living Energy will include 10,000 trained graduate researchers; embedded collaborative, inter-disciplinary and practice-based approaches to research training at five higher education institutions in partner countries; and in-country partnerships enabling pathways for delivery of economically, socially and environmentally sustainable systems.

Project.Title: efficient, reliable and safe biomass handling, pretreatment and processing for a sustainable eu bio-based economy
Project.Description:
Production technology, process engineering
Forestry, biomass production (e.g. for biofuels)
Agroindustry
Biomass, agriculture, forestry, pretreatment, handling, conveying, silos, dust explosions, bulk
solids, particulate solids, pelletization, discrete element method

This decade’s major challenge for the EU economy is to decouple its growth from the use of resource-input or the
environmental impact-output. The use of biomass is the main opportunity for this decoupling. For this ‘third industrial
revolution’ the industry needs a group of highly skilled staff with scientific, technological, managerial and entrepreneurial
competences for the multi-disciplinary field of biomass handling and processing The efficient and safe use of biomass
becomes a fundamental concept of this revolution, given the limited and fragmented availability of the biomass feedstock.
Often the lack of knowledge and use of innovative and specific techniques for biomass characterisation, equipment and
systems design and safety causes biomass transformation plant stoppage and thus substantial losses in terms of resources,
time and money. The innovative training network “Efficient, reliable and safe biomass handling, pretreatment and processing
for a sustainable EU bio-based economy (BIOHAPPBY)” is part of the solution. By joining forces of many sectors relevant to
biomass handling, pretreatment and processing, i.e. universities and research centers, software houses, densification
equipment suppliers, storage equipment designers, safety systems providers, plant constructors, bioenergy producers and
biorefineries, BIOHAPPBY proposes the training of highly skilled, interdisciplinary experts on an international research
programme. It will provide significant advances in the scientific understanding of the physical phenomena controlling the
biomass solids behaviour in handling systems and support groundbreaking technologies for the biomass pre-treatement,
storage, handling and safety. Industry- close development and market uptake on those technologies will ensure reliable,
economical, efficient, sustainable and safe handling and feeding processes for biomass valorisation plants.

Project.Title: appropriate technologies for water treatment and utilisation for the sustainable development and re-afforestation of turkana county (northern kenya)
Project.Description:
This project addresses the issue of scarcity of fresh water in arid areas of Sub-Saharan Africa, as exemplified in the
Turkana County in North West Kenya where most of the water available for human consumption or agricultural use is
extracted from boreholes. All too often, this water is harmful due to its salinity content, and the need for desalination is
acute but largely unmet.
We propose using the locally abundant sunshine and wind for powering desalination. However, local communities or
businesses will only adopt desalinating systems that are cheap enough to procure, build, operate and maintain using local
materials, skills and supply chains. One such 'appropriate' technology here would be reflective parabolic troughs that focus
solar light onto pipes where the water is circulated. The resulting water vapour is then condensed to fresh water. The
remaining saline water also gets sterilised, and may be kept for other uses like washing.
The main objectives are described as follows:
1. Investigate appropriate business models and the development of local ownership and stewardship of desalination units.
This includes: documenting the availability of relevant technical skills and suppliers in Turkana and Kenya, and the local
market for water purification; checking compliance with regulations; and studying the wider social environment and
governance of water resources, esp. gender, age, and the co- existence of multiple communities including pastoralists,
farmers and refugees, so that we help ensure fair access, avoid conflict and facilitate adoption of the technology.
2. Develop appropriate designs and construction for desalinating devices, including prototypes and prototype testing. In
particular: A parabolic trough as previously described; and a device that captures moisture from the air. The systems will be
built and deployed in the field, and their performance monitored to enhance design and operation. Trials on the ground will
also address issues of scale formation and bacteriological quality of water. Specifications and preliminary designs will be
produced to supply markets and stakeholders identified in WP1, and local partners encouraged to promote prototype
deployment.
3. Investigate the use of the water for irrigation and re-afforestation. Trees are a critical market for water use. They can
transform the local economy and even the local climate, and people rely on them for shade, fruit and timber. We will
investigate the best use of both the desalinated water and the resultant brine by-product for agricultural, horticultural and
pastoralist activities. Some tree species that are both tolerant to salinity and of economic interest (esp. fruit trees) will be
planted in selected areas, with due consideration given to the drainage of water from these areas to avoid contamination of
freshwater bodies.
4. A virtual "Joint Institute for Research and Training in Water and Energy Access" to continue and amplify this project
beyond the grant period. Drawing on the advice of local stakeholders (community groups, NGOs and officials), and the
combined expertise of its members (namely: the University of Edinburgh, the Kenya Forestry Research Institute, the
University of Strathmore based in Nairobi, the University of Jaramogi Oginga Odinga Science and Technology, and The
East-African branch of UK-based NGO Practical Action), the Institute will devise research programmes as well as training
programmes for local communities, entrepreneurs, craftsmen, engineers, scientists and policymakers.
5. Demonstrating prototypes to local stakeholders. This will encourage communities, entrepreneurs and officials to adopt
and deploy the technology. For this purpose, we will also produce a clear manual and Youtube videos, and the
demonstration of prototypes, both in operation and also in construction, with involvement of local artisans and of
communities seeking to remedy the quality of their borehole water.

Project.Title: coaster: coastal erosion hazard assessment and sustainable prevention measures for the indian sub-continent
Project.Description:
Coastal erosion and its mitigation is a global challenge problem, which has direct and indirect environmental, socio-economic, and institutional impacts worldwide. Coastal erosion is driven by relative sea level rise, tides, cyclones, and
extreme waves all of which are affected by climate change and variability.
Sea level rise, more intense cyclones, waves, and surges all pose serious threats to the vast number of people who live
along the coastal areas of India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. These three developing countries experience severe coastal
erosion problems which result in damage to coastal structures, roads, dwellings, infrastructure, tourist facilities, historic
sites, fisheries, etc. For example, 3,829 km of India's 8,414-km long coastline is eroding. Bangladesh is experiencing beach
erosion that exceeds 100 m/yr at certain sites. Sri Lanka is losing 175,000 - 285,000 m2 per year of coastal land to the sea.
The foregoing examples illustrate the scale of coastal erosion in the Indian Subcontinent.
This proposal aims to assess coastal erosion and its mitigation in the context of the Indian Subcontinent. To achieve this,
CoastEr will establish a collaborative partnership between engineers and scientists from India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and
the UK. Using climate change scenarios, we propose to investigate present and future coastal erosion problems and
suggest sustainable engineering mitigation measures. This will involve making informed assessment of the effect of future
climate change/variability scenarios on sea level rise, cyclones, storm surges and extreme waves. Results from advanced
numerical modelling tools and scaled ocean laboratory facilities will then be used to study the effects of climate drivers on
coastal hydrodynamics, sediment transport, morphodynamics, deposition and erosion, and the coastal ecosystem. The
project will produce coastal erosion zonation maps according to present and future climate scenarios; these maps will be
useful to decision makers responsible for coastal management in India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. We will explore the
vulnerability to climate change of protected estuaries and coastal ecosystems such as the Sundarbans. From shoreline
change observations along the coast of the Indian Subcontinent, the overseas researchers will help create a GIS database
of significant scientific value that would be useful for coastal management activities and marine spatial planning. This
dataset will be made freely available, enabling further advances to take place in coastal erosion research. Mitigation
approaches will be recommended for particularly vulnerable sites, based on physical and numerical model studies of
different hard and soft engineering measures. In the ODA context, the proposal is directed towards sustainable
infrastructure development and engineering for disaster resilience through the use of digital data.

Project.Title: development of smart, small, sustainable wind turbines
Project.Description:
1. Abstract of the Project
In this project, it is aimed to initiate new research and innovation collaboration between
three leading wind energy research centers in Turkey and UK by pursuing solutions for
problems of local communities in wind energy sector. The project partners are:
● Middle East Technical University (METU) - Wind Energy Centre, Ankara
● University of Strathclyde (UoS) - Wind Energy Centre for Doctoral Training, Glasgow
● University of Edinburgh (UoE) - Institute for Energy Systems, Edinburgh
The main objectives to be achieved can be listed as follows:
● Giving young researchers the possibility to expand their horizons by collaborating
with the other researchers in the leading wind energy institutions as well as share
their cultures
● Creating the possibility for local communities to produce their own electricity by
focusing on the reliability and efficiency of medium-sized wind turbines, allowing
wind turbines which are easy to install and operate, and also reduced overall cost of
energy
● Creating technological solutions focusing on medium sized wind turbines and
wind/solar hybrid energy systems
● Designing the next-generation of smart-grid ready wind turbines, by utilizing
distributed generation and energy storage
It is expected that the outcomes of this project will initiate collaboration in long term
research projects between UK and Turkey, and help to bring the UK’s expertise in renewable
energy to Turkey. Furthermore, the project results will be disseminated to local
communities and wind turbine manufacturers in UK and Turkey, thus creating job and
funding opportunities in the long run.
Keywords: Wind Energy, energy efficiency, direct-drive generators, smart-grid

Project.Title: data-driven intelligent energy management for environmentally sustainable energy access
Project.Description:
This project aims to develop an intelligent energy management
platform and key strategies for the successful transition to a lowcarbon
sustainable society. This will be achieved by integrating smart
technologies – Internet of Things (IoT), Information & Communication
Technologies (ICT), Distributed Energy Resources (DER) and digital
networks for energy infrastructure. The workplan is designed to
realise this through an innovative programme involving UK and Indian
partners with complementary skillsets, mutually enriching, benefiting
both countries.
Key project objectives:
1. A research program on data-driven software technology platforms
for intelligent energy management;
2. Internal and outreaching exchange and dissemination of skillsets
and knowledge

Energy security and sustainable low-carbon economies is the prime objective of climate change
mitigation strategy.India-UK partnership, through UKIERI project, aims to pursue multi-disciplinary
international collaborative research and develop capacity-building to deliver the reliable,
sustainable, affordable green energy society without compromising its economic and social
developments that India as well as UK need. This will also help to promote much greater
decentralised on-site clean energy production and more efficient consumption to satisfy the
potential demand from the two billion Indian people who still lack access to basic modern electric
energy.
The key objective of this UK-India joint research proposal is exchange of skillsets and knowledge
towards the development of a data-driven intelligent energy demand management platform to
accomplish the optimal penetration of low carbon energy-productive economic activity and
energy-efficient end use for sustainable society. The intellectual merit of the proposed research is
the development of a software technology platform -- comprising a set of common knowledge,
theoretical approaches, mathematical models and decision support via optimization and analytical
tools -- that will contribute in making possible the promising environmentally sustainable energy
access. This project proposal include the following objectives:
1) To develop key strategies, novel algorithms and models in order to define interactions of
smart technologies, distributed energy resources, digital networks to enable
environmentally sustainable energy access.
2) To integrate ICT and IoT devices for developing data-driven software tool for real-time
energy monitoring and management.
3) Real-time information management, knowledge-based systems and decision support
development for optimum operations and energy management under normal and missing
information
4) To carry out simulations and tests using laboratory-scaled platform, to test and validate
the most promising solution and provide project outcome.

Project.Title: diagnostic innovation and livestock (dial): towards more effective and sustainable applications of antibiotics in livestock farming
Project.Description:
The widespread use of antibiotics in livestock farming, in many circumstances, serves as alternative to the diagnosis, targeted treatment and prevention of disease in individual animals, flocks and herds. Relationships and practices between diagnosis, prescription, treatment and prevention have become stretched to the point of rupture, a rupture thrown into sharp focus by the AMR issue. Better, smarter, more rapid and more accessible diagnoses, driven by a shift in the behaviours and conditions associated with diagnostic decision-making (whether performed in the laboratory or at the point-of-care by veterinarians or farmers) represents a critical step to delivering more effective and sensible use of antibiotic medicines in animal health (Kessel, 2014; Schroeder, 2016). Improvements in diagnostic development and practice, however, and in their relationship to prescription and treatment, requires social, governance and technical innovations, understanding the parameters and conditions of which demands urgent research. 
This project addresses the range of behaviours associated with diagnoses in animal health as socio-technical and knowledge practices requiring regulatory interventions (devising and standardizing processes), practical applications (diagnostic tool development and diagnostic practice), awareness and behavioral change (in responsive and ‘response-able’ practices, including decisions to diagnose or not-to-diagnose), innovation (from the development and trialing of new diagnostic tools to new ways of doing diagnostics and their relationship to other interventions) and effective and sensible translations (through treatment decision-making, prescription, medicine use and preventative intervention). Empirically, this original and far-reaching project will bring improved understanding of current knowledges, practices and behaviours (and their interdependence) to the field of veterinary diagnostics and, critically, to the relationship of these diagnostics to disease treatment and prevention. It will identify drivers for behavior change (in the widest sense) in these domains, and will provide an experimentally based trialing and assessment of the flexibilities, capacities and conditions for (and barriers to) improvement and innovation in diagnostics and diagnostic practice. From the lessons learnt, the project will contribute to the strategic progress towards better use of antibiotics in livestock farming. 
This is a four-year multidisciplinary collaboration involving geographers, veterinary scientists and STS scholars. It builds directly on the sub-themes of the ESRC call in focusing on: the awareness and engagement of key actors in antibiotic use through diagnostic practice and development within livestock farming; in addressing formal and informal market access with respect to both antibiotics and diagnostic tools/technologies and the standardization, or otherwise, of relevant processes and practices; in developing an interdisciplinary approach to stewardship that builds on previous work by the research team on understanding the responsibilities, practices and drivers of stakeholders (Bruce, 2010; Buller et al., 2014; Tait and Banda, 2016; Hinchliffe et al., 2016; Reyher 2016a, 2016b); and, finally, in driving innovative, regulation behavior and practice, with respect to the regulation and governance of diagnostic development, to the business strategies of both developers and veterinary practices and to innovative and experimental interventions in diagnostic and clinical practice which directly impact on-farm sustainable animal health and welfare. The interdisciplinary research team will work with and draw original empirically driven information, understanding and analysis from diagnostic tool developers and regulators, veterinary practices and professional bodies, farmers and treatment, decision-makers, veterinary laboratories, the food industry and government regulatory authorities to develop durable and innovative strategies for facilitating and advancing smarter approaches to the use of antibiotics in agriculture.

Project.Title: building sustainable refugee bureaucracies in protracted displacement: a creative ethnography of the emotional lives of urban refugee youth in beirut
Project.Description:
Building Sustainable Refugee Bureaucracies in Protracted Displacement: A Creative Ethnography of the Emotional Lives of
Urban Refugee Youth in Beirut
Today, more than 65 million people are forcibly displaced, with developing regions hosting more than 86% of refugees
under UNHCR's mandate. Those younger than 18 comprise more than 50% of refugees worldwide, and in Lebanon, they
comprise 53% of its refugee population. Importantly, around 50% of Lebanon's displaced youth are in cities, not in formal camps - challenging humanitarian agencies' ability to integrate refugees with Lebanon's own vulnerable or at-risk urban youth. But since refugee youth living outside of regulated camps are now perhaps the most vulnerable and fastest growing group in forced displacement, the need to create urban spaces that allow for their dignity, safety and rights, as well as access to services, educations and futures in long-term displacement, remains one of aid organizations' most urgent and long-term challenges. Our proposed research directly addresses this need, and thereby contributes to one of the most pressing 21st century issues at the heart of both displacement and development policies.
Refugees - including displaced youth - often highlight that life in displacement is a social process involving the collective rebuilding of physical, social and moral worlds. It is important to acknowledge the suffering and loss involved in being a refugee. But it is equally vital to recognise the potentials that lie in these young people's deep, internal resources, and their abilities to rebuild their lives. This research seeks to understand these emotional resources and rebuilding processes, trying to grasp (1) displaced youths' everyday, emotional lives; (2) how their social connections and mutual interdependencies sustain them in long-term displacement; (3) and how these understandings can be used to help to make refugee and
development policies more responsive and sustainable.
Our research proposes an innovative combination of ethnography, interviews and creative workshops to help us explore these topics. We draw on studies of emotions to design creative arts- and skills based workshops and platforms. These have two aims: they are designed to help us explore young refugees emotional lives and experiences, but they are also intended to provide practical, technical educational and employment skills for young participants, and useful policy platforms to strengthen the capacity of our partner refugee and development organizations in Lebanon.
We propose visual art/mural-making, music and photography/film workshops because there is mounting evidence of the effectiveness of participatory visual and creative, arts-based methods in understanding the everyday lives of young people.
Our workshops are delivered in informal educational settings to include both refugee and at-risk Lebanese youth. Held across 3 phases at 4-month intervals, they follow the same group of 40 youth aged 11 to 16. In Phase 1, the participants create individual-skill based work expressing dimensions of their everyday lives; Phase 2 adds group work to explore their experiences of 'home' and 'friendships'; while Phase 3 includes all workshop participants to produce a collaborative, public facing joint exhibition of their art to be shared with the wider Lebanese community.
In bringing displaced and Lebanese youth communities together through creative platforms, the research findings will contribute to a better understanding of forcibly displaced youths' everyday  connections and relationships, whilst also communicating the need to make visible the many intimacies that sustain these young people's everyday emotional and social worlds. We hope to thereby assist refugee and development organizations - and so the country's long-term development - by contributing to sustainable solutions for youth in protracted displacement.

Project.Title: just solar: sustainable development and global supply chains
Project.Description:
This is the first study of renewable energy policies and programmes in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia that investigates the impact of increased demand for solar energy across the global supply chain, from sites of mining and mineral extraction, manufacturing and assembly, waste disposal and recycling. The project fits squarely into the British Academy’s theme of Sustainable Growth and asks: (i)
Are current patterns of growth and innovation in the global solar economy equitable and inclusive? (ii) Does the solar economy generate rewarding and empowering employment? (iii) Does the solar economy create sustainable forms of production and consumption?

Project.Title: sustainable integration of wave energy in the aa economy through synergies with maritime activities
Project.Description:
Resource efficiency
2.1. Fostering renewable energies and energy efficiency
Technology transfer and university-enterprise cooperation, Renewable energy: marine

Wave energy is called upon to play a role in the European energy mix but
significant obstacles still exist. SIWEIS will foster wave energy growth through
integration with other maritime uses (transport, energy, aquaculture). Using
Blue Economy priority sectors, 5 main obstacles will be addressed: reliability;
survivability; sustainability; LCOE and environmental integration. The main
outputs will be a GIS tool and an integrated strategy to leverage wave energy
under a transnational approach.

The aim of this project is to achieve sustainable integration of wave energy
into the AA economy by means of innovative synergies with other maritime
activities (transport, energy, aquaculture & support services). Wave
energy is one of the most promising marine renewable resources and one
of the Blue Growth Priorities. Almost 45% of wave energy developers are
European and a new, homegrown industrial sector is emerging. However, the
wave energy sector is at a crucial stage where cost and risk reduction are
needed in order to attract investors. The overarching objective of SIWEIS is
to develop an integrated AA strategy to accelerate wave energy development
from basic research to demonstration projects, through the integration of wave
energy converters with existing and mature maritime economic activities.
Three specific objectives will be addressed: (1) identify synergies between
wave energy and other maritime activities and classify the AA potential
for a multiuse maritime space approach; (2) cluster wave energy resource
availability, focusing on met-ocean conditions, socio-economic benefits and
synergies with other uses; (3) identify the most relevant technological needs
for wave energy developers in the AA in order to maximize the rate of success
and minimize risks/costs of demonstration projects. The results obtained
from SIWEIS will impact on the current situation by characterizing the socioeconomic
impact of wave energy development and integration in the AA.

Project.Title: environmental sustainability and economic cooperation in the longue duree: a comparative approach to locality, history and development
Project.Description:
In recent years there have been multiple challenges to the existing understandings of economic growth and the environment, and the difficulties in balancing economic, social, and environmental goals. There is growing awareness of the challenges posed by climate change and the depletion of natural resources, and the urgency of developing balanced approaches for future economic growth and environmental sustainability. At the same time, the uneven economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic and the lingering repercussions of the 2008 financial crisis continue to raise important questions regarding social and economic equality, how to manage access to financial resources, and how to protect the agency and opportunity of individuals within a globalized economic system dominated by large multinational corporations. This network seeks to explore and bridge these two issues of our times - sustainable development and economic inequality. In particular, we seek to explore diverse models of economic cooperation and sustainable resource management through comparative and interdisciplinary engagement with historians, anthropologists, political scientists, geographers, and sociologists, with the goal of developing future research agenda into sustainable growth that can incorporate a diverse range of economic, environmental, and social objectives.

Contemporary environmental and economic crises highlight the importance of incorporating a humanistic approach to growth and development that brings to the fore sustainable and equitable patterns of resource management. As such, this network brings together humanities and social science researchers in order to explore the historical and cultural contexts surrounding diverse models of economic cooperation and resource management. In this way, we seek to provoke new understandings of sustainable development, both past and present, while also fostering new collaborations across disciplines and regions in order to highlight the significance of the social and cultural context of sustainable growth. In particular, we seek to prompt new insights and comparative studies into sustainable growth through the example of the Korean kye - a type of organization that has been used to manage a wide range of resources throughout Korean history including forests, fishery rights, education, and financial resources, to name just a few. By bringing examples of Korean kye organizations over time into dialogue with comparative models of economic cooperation and sustainable development from other regions, we aim to generate new directions for future research into alternative models of growth and economic
activity.

Overall, this project will search for links between historically specific examples and contemporary case studies in order to develop a deeper understanding of the interrelations between environmentally sustainable growth and social and economic equality. We will create an environment for interdisciplinary conversations where researchers can learn from one another, while using discussions of kye as a vehicle to expand the understanding of sustainable development and create a foundation for future collaborative research. Throughout this process, we will foster strong ties between researchers in both South Korea and the United Kingdom by hosting a programme of visiting research fellowships and international workshops and conferences that will not only provide a valuable contribution to academic knowledge but also support researchers - especially early career researchers - to develop future research and international collaborations.

Project.Title: strategising for sustainability: combating climate change in partnership with indigenous communities in kiribati and samoa
Project.Description:
In 2018, the Presidencies of COP 23/24 launched the Talanoa Dialogue Platform as a strategy for combating climate change, taking their cue from the indigenous Pacific tradition of talanoa: a process of inclusive, participatory and transparent dialogue, to enable decision-making for the collective good. This project uses talanoa methods to engage/empower indigenous communities in Kiribati and Samoa, both of which are experiencing increasingly severe climate change impacts. The project will include a series of workshops involving the sharing of indigenous narratives of environmental change and aspirations for future resilience/adaptation, to inform (i) the production of an environmental strategy game (and accompanying
website/resources) to be used as community education tools; and (ii) reports on health and environmental impacts of climate change to be used to guide resilience and restoration initiatives. All activities and outputs will be co-produced and transdisciplinary in design and execution, integrating knowledge across indigenous and academic communities.
Sponsor.Name: british academy
Scheme.Name: knowledge frontiers: international interdisciplinary research projects
PI.Name: Michelle Keown

Project.Title: genomic selection to improve the efficiency and sustainability of tilapia aquaculture in south east asia
Project.Description:
The vast majority of global aquaculture takes place in developing countries, where it helps address several UN Sustainable Development Goals, either directly through human consumption, or indirectly through economic growth. Innovation in aquaculture production has major potential to raise incomes of small-scale producers, and to add resilience to food systems supporting livelihoods in vulnerable regions. However, intensification of aquaculture poses environmental concerns, and increasing the efficiency of fish production systems is essential to meet this global demand in a sustainable manner.

Nile tilapia is arguably the world's most important food fish, and is one of the cheapest and most accessible source of animal protein, providing vital micro and macro nutrients for cognitive and physical development. However, substantial barriers to increasing tilapia aquaculture include variable production efficiency across diverse farming systems. Feed is the biggest cost in intensive fish farming systems, and reducing feed consumption for a given productivity level is therefore a key goal. Improved feed efficiency reduces the use of natural resources, including fish oil and fish meal, thus contributing to the preservation of marine ecosystems. Improved feed efficiency also reduces nutrient outputs which can be detrimental to the environment, and reduces energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions associated with feed production.

Genetic improvement of feed efficiency in tilapia has major potential but is hampered by the operational challenge of high-throughput methods for recording feed efficiency, as well as lack of tools and optimised strategies to incorporate feed conversion traits into the breeding program goals. In this proposal, research outputs from previous BBSRC-funded projects relating to genomic selection and development of a Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) array for tilapia will be translated to achieve genetic improvement of feed efficiency, with Vietnam as an exemplar country.

The project was co-developed by scientists at The Roslin Institute, University of Edinburgh (UK), WorldFish, and The National Breeding Centre for Southern Freshwater Aquaculture (Vietnam). Together the team will perform a large scale feed efficiency trial at the breeding centre in Vietnam, where individual records will be matched to genotypes using the SNP array, genetic parameters will be estimated, and optimised methods for performing genomic selection will be tested. The results will be applied to select parent fish with high breeding values for feed conversion, and the performance of their progeny will be benchmarked against families with lower breeding values.

The tilapia strain with improved feed efficiency will be disseminated via the existing system of multiplication hatcheries and smallholder farmers in Vietnam. A workshop and promotional material will be developed to communicate the benchmarking trial results, and to encourage regular uptake of genetically improved stock by these stakeholders. The outputs will include economic and social benefits for the project partner and smallholder farmers in Vietnam, via reduced feed costs and more efficient production systems. The impacts extend to human health via provision of cheap and sustainable sources of animal protein and nutrients, and to the environment via reduced used of marine sourced feed ingredients and higher production output per unit of pond space.

While Vietnam is the exemplar country (4th largest aquaculture producer globally), the techniques developed will be applied in several other Asian countries where WorldFish supply genetically improved tilapia (Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Timor-Leste, Bangladesh, India). Therefore, the project has major potential to address the challenge of improving productivity and incomes of small scale producers with reduced environmental impact, and improving access to sustainable sources of animal protein.

Project.Title: peaks: promoting education and awareness of indigenous knowledge for sustainability
Project.Description:
Unesco reports that cultural heritage - both tangible and intangible - connects us to the past and provides invaluable insights into our identities and evolution, and plays an important role in economic growth, poverty reduction and sustainable development. Africa has some of the world's most glaring education inequalities; children who are born poor, female, or in rural or conflict-affected regions, face extreme disadvantage in education. PEAKS takes a multidisciplinary and multistakeholder approach to using indigenous knowledge, held in memory institutions like national libraries and national
archives in Africa, to promote education, develop cultural identity, bridge gender gaps, influence behavioural changes and promote sustainable livelihoods of African people, especially those who are marginalised and/or affected by crises and disaster.

In phase 1, PEAKS focuses on 4 African countries - Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi and Nigeria -- where education of a large number of children is often affected by a variety of factors such as poverty, natural disasters and conflicts. Subsequently, with advice from the African Union and other African partners, other countries will be added to ensure that the cultural and historic contexts, challenges, needs and capacity of all the regions in Africa are addressed. The project
takes a bottom-up approach to engage with a range of stakeholders at the supply side of indigenous information like national libraries and national archives in Africa, and at the demand side of information especially school teachers, schoolchildren and young adults, as well as other stakeholders like government departments, international organisations, NGOs and businesses, to co-develop a research agenda and build equitable partnership for developing sustainable solutions.

In phase 1, PEAKS will develop case studies using indigenous content and learning contexts in the partner countries where a large number of school age children are affected or marginalised due to protracted crisis and conflicts. Through the case studies and engagement with the wider audience in several African countries, PEAKS will co-develop a research agenda and through subsequent commissioned projects in phase 2, build capacity in content development for education using African indigenous and government information, and develop skills training of information professionals, teachers,
schoolchildren and other stakeholders for classroom teaching and lifelong learning.

Project.Title: international: integrating globally-recognised sustainability metrics for tropical perennial crops in a one-stop shop cool farm tool
Project.Description:
We will develop a fully integrated environmental decision support tool for tropical perennial crops and deliver a full technical specification for inclusion into the online, and freely available Cool Farm Tool. The Cool Farm Tool is owned by the Cool Farm Alliance (CFA) who will partner on this project. It is a business-led initiative to assess and improve the sustainability of agriculture-based supply chains. It is funded via a membership model, with membership consisting of over 50 companies including for example major multinationals such as Unilever, PepsiCo, Heineken, Danone, Nestle, Marks and Spencer, and Tesco. Members pay to maintain the tool and deploy at scale in their supply chains but it is a core principle of the Alliance that the tool is and will always be free-to-use for farmers.
The CFT itself is a science-based decision support tool designed for use by farmers at farm scale. It has benefitted from significant NERC Discovery and Innovation funding in the past and as a result includes a growing suite of metrics for crop and livestock systems in an expanding set of geographic locations (over 100 countries). Several case studies have shown the impact that has been derived using the tool, for example PepsiCo's "50-in-5" (http://pepsico.co.uk/live/story/celebrating-sustainable-farming) and egg production in North America resulting in a 25% reduction in the carbon footprint from primary production (Vetter et al 2018).
Tropical perennial crops are of huge importance to global food supply chains and typically have high dependence on smallholder farmers in DAC countries where decision-support has been hindered less scientific evidence and the focus of researchers in temperate regions. This project build on numerous previous NERC and Wellcome Trust outputs and exploits established successful relationships between the project partners to ensure delivery. We will develop modules based around the existing CFT methods to allow a one-stop shop assessment tool for carbon and water footprinting and biodiversity impacts of farm practice in tropical perennials. Through partnership with the Cool Farm Alliance and the £5.4M Wellcome Trust funded SHEFS project we will ensure delivery of a tool which has practical value to farmers and supply chains. This business-led, science-based, and farmer-focused project will thereby provide robust metrics which will allow farmers to engage and demonstrate their positive actions for sustainability into international supply chains, and the businesses to identify good practices to embed in their sustainable sourcing strategies. The possibility to combine, in a single decision support tool, the multiple impacts of farm practices is attractive for many reasons, not least being that it will reduce the current burden on farmers to conduct multiple assessments of dubious value on multiple impacts for multiple buyers.
