Project.Title: shining a light on sustainable agriculture: applying an evidence-based framework for assessing sustainability of agricultural interventions in africa
Project.Description: Agriculture provides most of the edible nutrients used by mankind and is maintaining billions of livelihoods, not just those of farmers but also retailers, consumers and other value chain actors. Furthermore, it plays a key role in regulating environmental services mainly through land and water use, nutrient cycles, and climate feedbacks. On current projections, however, agriculture needs to do more. Firstly, production must increase to provide enough food for a rapidly growing world population. Agriculture then needs to fulfil its potential to contribute to reducing poverty and improving the nutrition of people in low and middle-income countries. Areas of land that are suitable for spatial expansion of agriculture are extremely limited. This dictates that future advances must focus on intensifying the use of current agricultural land and other inputs. Moreover, this cannot simply be a short-term imperative but rather must be achieved in ways that can meet the needs of future generations, i.e. any intensification promoted must be sustainable intensification (SI). Currently, there is no commonly accepted way to assess whether SI pathways are indeed sustainable. In this project we will use mainly existing datasets to develop repeatable methodologies for applying the recently-developed Sustainable Intensification Indicator Framework (SIAF) to this question. The SIAF allows us to evaluate changes in production intensity driven by interventions or other factors across five sustainability domains: production, economic, human, social and environmental. The framework also has the potential to be implemented at multiple scales and the project proposed here aims to strengthen its capacity to do so in a systematic fashion. The project's activities will be based on a set of three contrasting case studies - in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia and Uganda - conducted with local implementing partners. Studies will test whether SIAF can be applied repeatedly across the case study production systems and agro-ecologies to generate interpretable qualitative and quantitative assessments of the sustainability side of the SI trajectories currently being promoted by the case study projects. The results of our analyses will be discussed with and evaluated by local partners to ground truth the utility of the approach. We will also compare results amongst case studies to identify common lessons on the implementation of SI. Finally, we will evaluate the SIAF approach used and conduct a critical assessment of whether systems approaches, like that employed by the SIAF, generate useful information for both local partners and more regionally-oriented policy prioritization as well as generating new scientific insights into the functioning of the contrasting production / agro-ecosystems studied. We will produce a robust, easily-applied 'Sustainable Intensification Assessment Tool' (SIAT) to assess and guide 'local' SI options in smallholder farming systems in low and middle-income countries.

Project.Title: travel, environment, sustainability: a literary and cultural history of irish and scottish coastal routes
Project.Description:
COASTAL ROUTES is an interdisciplinary project mapping travellers' routes and responses to coastal environments within
the archipelago. Focusing on a neglected body of travel texts on Ireland's West and the Scottish Highlands between 1770
and 1840, the project investigates similarities and differences in the ways in which discourses of travel shaped an ecological
awareness. Drawing on developments in geocriticism and environmental humanities, COASTAL ROUTES charts the impact
of historical perceptions on ideas of improvement, progress, and resource development. Bringing close textual analysis of
travel accounts into dialogue with a range of historical sources (maps, periodical journalism, guidebooks), the project
contrasts the ways in which tourists construct landscape as a resource; considers how they reflect changing attitudes and
values; and argues for an evolving environmental consciousness. Using Geographical Information Systems (GIS) to create
maps that mobilise questions about the relationship between travel and environment, this literary geography analyses how
environmental narratives grew up around particular locations. COASTAL ROUTES makes a timely contribution to the UN's
Agenda 2030 as it sits at the nexus of Goals relating to sustainable economic growth, consumption and production patterns
as well as sustainable development of marine resources. The recovery of historical attitudes towards coastal environments
as expressed in cultural productions generates insights into travellers' past experiences of nature, raising awareness for the
importance of natural capital and sustainability. Bringing British and Scottish travel writing into dialogue for the first time,
COASTAL ROUTES makes an innovative contribution to archipelagic criticism, Irish/Scottish studies, geocriticism and
environmental humanities while seeking to contribute to more environmentally aware practices in tourism as well as cultural
and natural heritage management.
Sponsor.Name: european commission
Scheme.Name: horizon 2020 - marie sk_odowska-curie actions
PI.Name: Penny Fielding

Project.Title: the uk software sustainability institute: phase 3
Project.Description:
Phase 3 of funding for the Software Sustainability Institute, a collaboration between the universities of Edinburgh, Manchester, Oxford and Southampton to improve the quality, reusability and integrity of research software.

In Phases 1 (Prepare) and 2 (Deploy) we developed an understanding of the state of the nation of research software, its developers/users, its requirements, and how software is changing the way research is conducted. Building on our experience and expert understanding, Phase 3 (Expand) will focus on the creation of sustainable and self-supporting communities of practice to empower cultural change that enables better practice to be widely adopted to: foster a culture of sharing expertise and enabling; integrate project consultancy, training and awareness raising to effect and support change; move from local and individual actions to national and community level effects. Our goal is that the UK research community be enabled to take full advantage of software and, in doing so, to support the conduct of excellent research.


Our objectives are:

A) Widespread adoption of research best practice: agreeing and defining best practice with reference to research software, and enabling its widespread adoption to ensure the reliability and reproducibility of modern research. Enabling development of models and blueprints for initiating, nurturing and maturing communities of practice, enhancing our status in the UK and internationally as the go-to institution for insight into research software matters and catalysing new international collaborations.

B) Cutting-edge policy and guidance: collaborating with stakeholders to create and disseminate evidence-based guidance, infrastructure, policies and tools. This leads to improved reusability of research software and its associated research outputs.

C) A capable research community: based on a sustainable and scalable community-led model that will push the boundaries of knowledge across domains to maintain excellence and drive innovation and career paths, to increase the recognition of research software. Supporting collaboration in the UK research society and helping it become more resilient and sustainable will achieve an increased social and cultural impact.

D) An open evidence bank: identifying and generating datasets, conducting analysis to provide insight and evidence of the importance of software, people and practices. This enables costing of resources required to develop, maintain and preserve research software.


To achieve these goals, we will be:

1) Raising awareness: empower and develop a cohort of ambassadors for good practice through our Fellowship; outreach to stakeholders at all levels on research software issues; to deliver adoption of best practice.

2) Seeding change: build multiple sustainable Communities of Practice (CoP): for research domains, for techniques, for stakeholder groups, for UK institutions; set up expert panels that commission topic-based programmes of workshops, policy studies and outreach; nurture and scale existing CoPs e.g. through RSE exchanges; develop tools and services to support CoPs; to guarantee the widespread adoption of research best practice.

3) Providing expertise: create regional training hubs to continue growth of provision; commission new courses; refocus open call consultancy; conduct feasibility study for an RSE brokerage; to form a capable research community.

4) Influencing policy: publish new guidance and standards; work with international collaborators to put policy into practice; conduct research that improves understanding of research software; to deliver cutting-edge policy and guidance and build an open evidence bank.

Project.Title: exploiting the self-regulatory circuit of nitrate assimilation in plants for improved nitrogen use efficiency and crop sustainability.
Project.Description:
The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations projects that in the next 30-40 years the world will be one
third more populous. This increase in the global population will put extraordinary pressure on agricultural systems. A
concurrent boost in agricultural production will be required to meet already overburdened food, fiber and fuel demands.
However, up to 35% of crop production is lost due to pathogen and herbivorous insect attack. Thus, the development of
new strategies to improve durable plant resistance is of great economic and social importance.
Currently, crop protection practices are mainly based on toxins and pesticides. These chemicals often offer limited efficacy
and are potentially hazardous to human health and the environment, while still leading to economic losses of billions every
year. Conversely, genetic and biochemical improvement of plant immunity represents a safe and sustainable alternative to
equip plants with defences against disease.
Effective plant immune responses rely on recognition of the attacker's strategy. Plants discriminates between attack by
biotrophs (i.e. pathogens that feed on living host cells), necrotrophs (i.e. pathogens that kill the host cell before feeding)
and herbivorous insects by triggering specific hormonal signalling networks that tailor the defence response according to
the attacker encountered. Key players in these networks are the hormones salicylic acid (SA), jasmonic acid (JA) and
ethylene (ET). Whereas SA is central to defence responses against biotrophs, JA/ET are generally involved in responses to
necrotrophs and insects. Interestingly, an antagonistic effect between SA and JA has been described frequently. This
hormonal trade off in immunity enables plants to prioritize defences against the attackers encountered, but in current
chemical and genetic crop protection strategies, stimulation of defence against one type of attacker often leads to severe
susceptibility to attackers of another type.
SA- and JA/ET-mediated defence responses involve accumulation of the free radical nitric oxide (NO), which has been
implicated in the control of protein activity, localization and conformation through the formation of S-nitrosothiols (protein-
SNO). Plants genetically manipulated to overproduce NO (nox1 mutants) or unable to degrade the main intracellular NO
bioreservoir, S-nitrosoglutathione (gsnor1 mutants), display increased levels of protein-SNO and severe susceptibility
towards pathogen infection. Recently, exciting findings demonstrated for the first time how specificity in protein-SNO
signalling is achieved in plants. The oxidoreductase enzyme, TRX-h5, the gene family of which comprises dozens of
members in plants, was shown to display denitrosylase activity towards protein-SNO. Importantly, overexpression of TRXh5
was shown to rescue disease resistance in nox1 mutants, but not in gsnor1 mutants. Altogether, these latest findings
suggest that like TRX-h5, other members of the TRX family may also control specific subsets of protein-SNO that regulate
particular metabolic redox networks. This proposal, to be completed at the Institute for Molecular Plants Science in the
University of Edinburgh, employs state-of-the-art genetic, genomic and analytical techniques to study the role of TRX
members in providing specificity to protein-SNO signalling during cross-talk between SA and JA/ET-mediated plant immune
responses. By increasing our understanding of TRX-based resistance trade-offs, we may ultimately be able to genetically
uncouple these antagonistic immune pathways to provide plants with resistance against a broad-spectrum of different
attackers.

Project.Title: tools for adaptive re-use of heritage assets for sustainability and economic growth
Project.Description:
Adaptive re-use of cultural heritage has emerged as a promising solution to the widening gap in what is publicly available in terms of resources and what is necessary in order to adequately preserve and sustain Europe’s rich diversity of cultural heritage assets. Our rationale in this proposal is that fully understanding and making constructive use of the latent potential embodied in the idea of adaptive re-use for placemaking, job creation and economic growth demands a novel approach; in
our case, a targeted, iterative design strategy, engaging a critical mass of multi-stakeholder participants into a comprehensive and extended innovating process centered on the four pillars of preservation, financing, business models and integrated governance. We carry out case studies in Edinburgh, Zagreb and three adaptive re-use intervention locations in Portugal, to build a knowledge base and decision support capability to enable creation of successful adaptive re-use blueprints with high replicability and up-scaling potential.

Project.Title: wythenshawe researching local food for increasing sustainability and health
Project.Description:
Rationale and context: Local food is widely seen as an essential feature of a sustainable and healthy food system. It is
commonly understood to be fresher and more nutritious, as well as being better for the environment through avoidance of 'food miles' - excessive transport contributing to climate change and resulting in a loss of food quality and nutrition. Local food is also thought to help promote a more vibrant local economy through shorter food supply chains. Nonetheless, despite the easy claims that local food is inherently good, sustainable and healthy, there is currently significant concern that moves towards local food may increase existing social inequalities. Local food is perceived by many to be expensive, and often as not easily accessible, available only through specialist locations such as farmers' markets, rather than through supermarkets. If only those with considerable resources are able to consume local, sustainable and organic food, then existing health disparities between rich and poor may be increased and other inequalities compounded.
In this conflicted context, our distinctive analysis is that:
- definitions of local food are generally, and paradoxically, abstracted and universalised, rather than being tailored to
specific 'locals';
- current definitions of local food are usually top down and often exclude local stakeholders, in particular local residents, from discussions about food systems;
- many existing proposed solutions risk obscuring the interests of those on low incomes with regards to local, organic and more sustainable food and food systems.
Our partnership: To address these current challenges, we have developed a project built on a unique partnership with a successful local food organisation in an area of considerable social deprivation, vibrant community action and local pride.
Real Food Wythenshawe (RFW), based in South Manchester, are an experienced organisation with a solid track record of innovative community-focussed interventions in an area of significant deprivation. Their work has been recognised through the award of £1M of Big Lottery Funding, as well as through their growing national reputation.
Methods, aims and objectives: Our ambitious project aims to reconceptualise local food through community-based
participatory research. Our approach is based on excavating local food knowledges and practices through activities such as oral history interviews, photo shares, memory days, local mapping of available food, and archival research, and then creatively engaging local residents with the emergent data to reimagine a site-specific local food for the present and future. We will then use the data and findings to produce a series of outputs tailored to specific stakeholders, for further and wider impact on Wythenshawe and beyond.
Benefits and applications: In the context of a rapidly transforming landscape of food policy and food governance, we
anticipate that our outputs will be of considerable use to policy-makers and other stakeholders. Now is a crucial moment to ensure local residents and those who will be buying and consuming food are involved in these conversations. In addition to academic outputs, we have a well-developed and integrated plan of outputs focused on different stakeholders and addressing different spatial and temporal horizons, including: a new publicly available archived dataset on local food; a Strategic Plan for Food in Wythenshawe; a Toolkit for Reimagining Local Food which will propose a site-specific process for tracing and (re)making relationships between people and the food they consume, enabling other groups to produce food plans tailored to their own locale. Our Policy Briefing aimed at other stakeholders in food discussions will locate the importance and benefits of actively involving local residents in the context of the rapidly shifting policy landscape.

Project.Title: black ecologies: race and the long anthropocene
Project.Description:
My project reads literature at the intersection of race and the environment, repositioning late nineteenth and early twentieth-century Black writers such as Frederick Douglass and Pauline Hopkins alongside contemporary Black authors including Alexis Pauline Gumbs and Marlon James, to demonstrate that many of the problems that define contemporary ecology have always been present in writing about chattel slavery and its afterlives. I ask how Black writing, from the nineteenth-century onwards, reframes the epoch we now know as the Anthropocene, arguing that literature allows us to understand the animating relationship between race and the environment while also providing space to imagine a world outside the joint violence of anti-Black racism and environmental destruction.

I am particularly excited about undertaking this work as it bridges the gap between three disparate conversations occurring in the environmental humanities, Black Studies, and literary criticism. Working at this intersection, my work uses literature as a way to both imagine and build a more sustainable and equitable future. That is, alongside tracing how the same political and economic forces have largely been responsible been responsible for both anti-Black violence and environmental destruction from the inception of chattel slavery to the present, I also look at how literature provides us with the opportunity to imagine a world outside of these twinned cycles. The goal of this research is to not only build a literary archive, but to translate this work into practice, arguing for the importance of literature in constructing alternate futures.

Project.Title: violence against land, violence against bodies: indigenous women's nonfiction writing in the anthropocene
Project.Description: My project will explore how nonfiction writing by Indigenous women writers negotiates the Anthropocene, specifically examining how these writers treat the intrinsic connections between violence against land and violence against Indigenous female bodies. This work aims to build upon existing scholarship on Indigenous peoples and the Anthropocene, as well as addressing what I perceive as gaps in environmental humanities scholarship on Indigenous nonfiction and Indigenous gift paradigms. It also aims to respond to the underrepresentation of BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and other people of colour) women writers in contemporary nature and place writing, at a time of global environmental crisis in which it is vital that we widen the frame and make space for alternative experiences of the natural world.

Project.Title: cultures, histories and futures of the anthropocene middle east
Project.Description: Climate change is perhaps the greatest challenge facing the welfare of developing countries today. As the United Nations Development Programme notes, climate change poses a 'massive threat to development' through rising temperatures and sea levels, water acidification and soil erosion as well as the complex linkages between changing environmental stresses and political crisis, conflict and migration. This challenge has been recognised by the promulgation of 'climate action' as one of the UN's key sustainable development goals. The Middle East, in the words of the second Arab Human Development Report (2009), is at particular risk from climate change challenges, and a link between the changing environment and present conflicts in the region, such as in Syria and Yemen.

Project.Title: tracking phosphorus to understand peatland algal bloom formation
Project.Description:
Peatlands are vital to humanity by providing countless benefits and ecological services; removing carbon dioxide from
the atmosphere, storing and purifying water, mitigating floods and providing a unique habitat for many plants and
animal species.
Globally, peatlands have been damaged by human activities such as afforestation releasing rather than storing
carbon. To reverse this trend, >1 million hectares of peatland forestry are now being felled across the UK.
However, several years after the tree felling started, a new ecosystem threat in the form of algal blooms has appeared
in the nearby water bodies. Caused by excess phosphates, released during or after felling, algal blooms endanger
water quality, fish populations, animal habitats and recreational activities.
In this work, I aim to determine the fate of the main algal bloom promoter, phosphorus, in restored peatlands of the
world’s biggest blanket bog, the Flow Country, Scotland using state-of-the-art analytical techniques. I will characterise
the movement and the forms of phosphorus in the peat and water bodies relative to deforested plots. This research is
imperative for the development of mitigating strategies that must become part of restoration projects involving tree
felling in peatlands. Only then can we preserve these vital ecosystems and their inhabitants.

Project.Title: innovative biological methanation and fuel processing for the production of liquefied biomethane as a regional waste treatment concept
Project.Description:
Energy collection, conversion and storage, renewable energy
Bioenergy
LNG, Liquefied Biomethane, Biological Methanation, Gas Upgrading, Liquefaction


The BioMeLT project aims at developing new and innovative technologies for converting bioresidues or biowaste and excess
renewable electricity to liquefied biomethane (LBM) for maritime and heavy-duty road transport and reducing GHG
emissions and pollutants in Europe. The BioMeLT process shall be implemented to existing small and medium scale
(bio-)waste treatment plants switching to Pt-LBM mode whenever excess renewable electricity is available. For the BioMeLT
process, e.g. the unused EU municipal solid biowaste potential can be applied, covering the EU transport sector fuel
capacity.
As biomass gasification results in the most critical gas, the WoodRoll® gasification technology from CE will serve as uniform
starting point for evaluating the BioMeLT process chain. For small and decentralized application, a simple and robust
methanation concept is favourable in terms of costs and user-friendly operation. Therefore, three new and innovative
Biological Methanation (BM) concepts will be evaluated, covering intrinsic kinetics, optimization of mass transfer and back
coupling effects on the entire process chain. The project will contribute to extending the knowledge in the field of BM, which
will help to quantify the potentials of this promising technology. In parallel to the research on BM, gas upgrading and
liquefaction technologies will be optimized and adapted to the process chain’s needs. Sound reactor modelling will allow
scale-up of the process chain to demonstrator scale directly. The industrial partners cover the scope of all applied
technologies and will contribute to transferring the results into the market.
The implementation strategy and the use of renewable electricity complies with the EC SET plan and H2020 perspectives of
applying interconnections between the energy networks and offering power grid storage and flexibilization options.
Furthermore, it gives the EU LNG strategy a green perspective in short to mid term by substitution of LNG by LBM.

Project.Title: application of genomic tools to improve mexican shrimp aquaculture
Project.Description:
Shrimp is the most important aquaculture species in Mexico, and is worth
~£0.5 Bn per annum. The State of Sinaloa is the second biggest producer
nationally, contributing 38% of the total production, and approximately
15,000 people are employed by this industry.
Despite a positive production trend, Mexican shrimp farming has been
severely hampered by diseases in recent years by pathogens such as the
White Spot Syndrome Virus (WSSV). There are no vaccines or treatments
available to prevent or control this disease, therefore genetic technologies
to improve innate resistance of the shrimp are desirable.
DNA sequencing technologies have facilitated rapid development of
reference genomes and genotyping tools for many aquaculture species.
Research using these tools has shown that resistance to disease is
heritable, which can be exploited via breeding programs to decrease
mortality and, hence, improve production. The implementation of such
genetic technologies into Mexican shrimp aquaculture to tackle disease
threats requires (i) the development of suitable genomic tools, and (ii) the
training of technical personnel from academia and industry on their
application.
The purpose of this project is to setup a collaboration between specialists
in these fields from the UK (led by The Roslin Institute) and Mexico (led by
ICMYL-UNAM) to (i) organize a framework for mid-term joint research
projects, technical courses, workshops, academic visits, publications, (ii)
develop genomic tools to enable the application of the advanced breeding
technologies to Mexican shrimp aquaculture; and (iii) to engage with the
industry to realize the potential of these tools for impact on production.
Successful outputs will reduce disease outbreaks, and hence increase
sustainable growth of the Mexican shrimp industry in the mid-term. As a
consequence, the economic status of the people that depend both directly
and indirectly from this activity will be positively impacted.

Project.Title: genomic selection to improve the efficiency and sustainability of tilapia aquaculture in south east asia
Project.Description:
The vast majority of global aquaculture takes place in developing countries, where it helps address several UN Sustainable Development Goals, either directly through human consumption, or indirectly through economic growth. Innovation in aquaculture production has major potential to raise incomes of small-scale producers, and to add resilience to food systems supporting livelihoods in vulnerable regions. However, intensification of aquaculture poses environmental concerns, and increasing the efficiency of fish production systems is essential to meet this global demand in a sustainable manner.

Nile tilapia is arguably the world's most important food fish, and is one of the cheapest and most accessible source of animal protein, providing vital micro and macro nutrients for cognitive and physical development. However, substantial barriers to increasing tilapia aquaculture include variable production efficiency across diverse farming systems. Feed is the biggest cost in intensive fish farming systems, and reducing feed consumption for a given productivity level is therefore a key goal. Improved feed efficiency reduces the use of natural resources, including fish oil and fish meal, thus contributing to the preservation of marine ecosystems. Improved feed efficiency also reduces nutrient outputs which can be detrimental to the environment, and reduces energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions associated with feed production.

Genetic improvement of feed efficiency in tilapia has major potential but is hampered by the operational challenge of high-throughput methods for recording feed efficiency, as well as lack of tools and optimised strategies to incorporate feed conversion traits into the breeding program goals. In this proposal, research outputs from previous BBSRC-funded projects relating to genomic selection and development of a Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) array for tilapia will be translated to achieve genetic improvement of feed efficiency, with Vietnam as an exemplar country.

The project was co-developed by scientists at The Roslin Institute, University of Edinburgh (UK), WorldFish, and The National Breeding Centre for Southern Freshwater Aquaculture (Vietnam). Together the team will perform a large scale feed efficiency trial at the breeding centre in Vietnam, where individual records will be matched to genotypes using the SNP array, genetic parameters will be estimated, and optimised methods for performing genomic selection will be tested. The results will be applied to select parent fish with high breeding values for feed conversion, and the performance of their progeny will be benchmarked against families with lower breeding values.

The tilapia strain with improved feed efficiency will be disseminated via the existing system of multiplication hatcheries and smallholder farmers in Vietnam. A workshop and promotional material will be developed to communicate the benchmarking trial results, and to encourage regular uptake of genetically improved stock by these stakeholders. The outputs will include economic and social benefits for the project partner and smallholder farmers in Vietnam, via reduced feed costs and more efficient production systems. The impacts extend to human health via provision of cheap and sustainable sources of animal protein and nutrients, and to the environment via reduced used of marine sourced feed ingredients and higher production output per unit of pond space.

While Vietnam is the exemplar country (4th largest aquaculture producer globally), the techniques developed will be applied in several other Asian countries where WorldFish supply genetically improved tilapia (Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Timor-Leste, Bangladesh, India). Therefore, the project has major potential to address the challenge of improving productivity and incomes of small scale producers with reduced environmental impact, and improving access to sustainable sources of animal protein.

Project.Title: isp18 pump-priming: using genomic data to improve aquaculture of tilapia
Project.Description:
Tilapia are one of the most important fish species in aquaculture in terms of worldwide production (>3.5 million metric tonnes per year) and production levels are continuing to grow. Its suitability for aquaculture derives from its largely herbivorous diet, rapid growth rate and tolerance of high stocking density. Nile tilapia makes up the majority of tilapia production. This species originated in Africa, where it has been cultivated since Egyptian times, and was distributed into Asia in the mid-20th century1. Tilapia is now arguably the world’s most important foodfish, contributing to food and nutrition security of many nations. Selective breeding of tilapia for genetic improvement of key traits such as growth and disease resistance is a major goal of several multinational breeding companies and non-profit organisations. 

This proposed project to generate a genetics resource for commercial tilapia is a collaboration between The Roslin Institute (University of Edinburgh) and WorldFish, an international, non-profit research organization that works to reduce hunger and poverty across the world by improving fisheries and aquaculture. WorldFish’s Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia (GIFT) strain of Nile tilapia originated in the Philippines and the breeding programme was moved to Malaysia in 20022. GIFT has been bred for increased growth rate and successfully disseminated across the world. Since GIFT is the basis of the vast majority of commercial tilapia aquaculture worldwide, gathering data on genetic characteristics of these populations is essential to inform choice of base populations and breeding strategies to optimise genetic gain in commercial and non-profit tilapia aquaculture, thereby enabling benefit for farmers in many countries. 
	
Initial research by Roslin and WorldFish led to the development of a ThermoFisher Axiom SNP array to facilitate genomic selection in tilapia. The purpose of this proposal is to further evaluate this product and use it to address breeding-related questions relevant for the tilapia aquaculture industry. Therefore, this project will involve generation and analysis of whole-genome sequences (WGS) and SNP genotypes for tilapia from several tropical countries. This data will be exploited to test the performance on diverse populations of tilapia of the new SNP array. A secondary output will be the opportunity to identify “selection signatures,” regions of the genome associated with selective breeding and adaptation to particular environments. Previous work3 has demonstrated genotype-by-environment interactions in the GIFT strain, suggesting the possibility of environment-specific breeding schemes. Investigating environmental adaptation in GIFT will help inform this decision, which has cost and logistical implications.

Project.Title: aqua-faang: advancing european aquaculture by genome functional annotation
Project.Description:
Aquaculture, fisheries
Genomics, comparative genomics, functional genomics
Epigenetics and gene regulation
Animal genetics
Functional annotation of fish genomes

Recent developments in genomics have advanced innovation in European aquaculture. However, despite the creation of
reference quality genome sequences for the main species, our understanding of genome functions remains limited. AQUAFAANG will deliver a step improvement in understanding of genome function and exploitation of genotype-to-phenotype
prediction in the six most important European farmed fish species. The project brings together world-leading interdisciplinary
expertise and industry partners providing direct pathways to commercial exploitation. AQUA-FAANG will functionally
annotate the genomes of all six species, employing standardized experimental assays and analysis pipelines defined by the
FAANG initiative. AQUA-FAANG datasets will be shared and coordinated with other FAANG initiatives via the FAANG data
coordination centre, and made available through the Ensembl genome browser. As infectious disease is of paramount
concern for sustainable aquaculture, the project focuses on understanding functional genomic regions in both healthy and
immune-challenged fish. This will improve knowledge of the genomic basis for disease resistance and is complemented by
novel approaches to increase understanding of immune cell heterogeneity. Standardized comparative analyses will provide
essential insights into genome functions that cannot be gained from study of single species. Functional assays will be used
to study intermediate phenotypes and prioritise causative genetic variants in trait-associated genomic regions to accelerate
selection of disease-resistant stocks. Functionally-enriched marker panels will be developed to improve accuracy of genomic
selection. An active programme of stakeholder engagement and dissemination will ensure uptake of project outputs by
industry, academia, the public and in policy. The outputs will enhance precision breeding, drive competitiveness within the
aquaculture sector, and enhance food and nutrition security in Europe.

Project.Title: biological cell inspired reactor for clean energy production
Project.Description: This project seeks sustainable solutions to today’s energy production challenges by mimicking biological cell strategies. Today, 96% of the global production of hydrogen is based on steam reforming of fossil fuels followed by the water gas shift (WGS) reaction, which produces about 250 million tons of carbon dioxide per year. The aim of this project is the development of a cell inspired reactor, which would allow the transition from the current brown hydrogen economy to a green one in an environmentally friendly way.

Project.Title: change - ccus whole system advances for clean energy in europe
Project.Description:
Energy collection, conversion and storage, renewable energy

CO2; CCUS; EERA; transport, flexible integrated energy system; regional strategies; SET-Plan

CHANGE - CCUS wHole system Advances for cleaN enerGy in Europe
Although Europe benefits from a rapid increase in wind and solar power, this renewable energy system (RES) can be asynchronous with demand. Security of supply can only be guaranteed when conventional power plants are used to balance the grid. Future fossil power will therefore need to operate flexibly. Also, energy intensive industries, industrial processes that emit CO2, and H2 production all rely on fossil energy. It is widely recognised that carbon capture, use and storage (CCUS) will be needed to decarbonise these emitters. Capture plants will produce fluctuating CO2 streams, requiring flexible operation which creates a number of fundamental challenges that CHANGE will address through targeted, low-TRL research and leveraging national programs. CHANGE will create a European Common Research and Innovation Agenda to support the SET Action Plan. CHANGE is a proposal from the EERA CCS Joint Programme which will benefit from the capacity within its wider 39 participants.
CHANGE will develop optimized flexible CCUS infrastructure plans in a new European RES. CHANGE will increase the adoption of three novel capture technologies, including a concept that can switch between H2 and electricity production, a nano-based post combustion technology and Calcium Looping technology integrated with solar energy. New supply chains will be identified by investigating conversion of CO2 to fuels during high RES availability. CHANGE will reduce CO2 transport and storage costs by macro-regional infrastructure planning and optimise CO2 storage management that is integrated with emerging low-carbon energy sectors. It will lower costs and risks by improving thermodynamic modelling of impure CO2 transport and by improving monitoring CO2 quality. CHANGE will build a networking platform for CCUS in four European regions, and provide action plans to meet their specific needs.

Project.Title: appropriate technologies for water treatment and utilisation for the sustainable development and re-afforestation of turkana county (northern kenya)
Project.Description:
This project addresses the issue of scarcity of fresh water in arid areas of Sub-Saharan Africa, as exemplified in the
Turkana County in North West Kenya where most of the water available for human consumption or agricultural use is
extracted from boreholes. All too often, this water is harmful due to its salinity content, and the need for desalination is
acute but largely unmet.
We propose using the locally abundant sunshine and wind for powering desalination. However, local communities or
businesses will only adopt desalinating systems that are cheap enough to procure, build, operate and maintain using local
materials, skills and supply chains. One such 'appropriate' technology here would be reflective parabolic troughs that focus
solar light onto pipes where the water is circulated. The resulting water vapour is then condensed to fresh water. The
remaining saline water also gets sterilised, and may be kept for other uses like washing.
The main objectives are described as follows:
1. Investigate appropriate business models and the development of local ownership and stewardship of desalination units.
This includes: documenting the availability of relevant technical skills and suppliers in Turkana and Kenya, and the local
market for water purification; checking compliance with regulations; and studying the wider social environment and
governance of water resources, esp. gender, age, and the co- existence of multiple communities including pastoralists,
farmers and refugees, so that we help ensure fair access, avoid conflict and facilitate adoption of the technology.
2. Develop appropriate designs and construction for desalinating devices, including prototypes and prototype testing. In
particular: A parabolic trough as previously described; and a device that captures moisture from the air. The systems will be
built and deployed in the field, and their performance monitored to enhance design and operation. Trials on the ground will
also address issues of scale formation and bacteriological quality of water. Specifications and preliminary designs will be
produced to supply markets and stakeholders identified in WP1, and local partners encouraged to promote prototype
deployment.
3. Investigate the use of the water for irrigation and re-afforestation. Trees are a critical market for water use. They can
transform the local economy and even the local climate, and people rely on them for shade, fruit and timber. We will
investigate the best use of both the desalinated water and the resultant brine by-product for agricultural, horticultural and
pastoralist activities. Some tree species that are both tolerant to salinity and of economic interest (esp. fruit trees) will be
planted in selected areas, with due consideration given to the drainage of water from these areas to avoid contamination of
freshwater bodies.
4. A virtual "Joint Institute for Research and Training in Water and Energy Access" to continue and amplify this project
beyond the grant period. Drawing on the advice of local stakeholders (community groups, NGOs and officials), and the
combined expertise of its members (namely: the University of Edinburgh, the Kenya Forestry Research Institute, the
University of Strathmore based in Nairobi, the University of Jaramogi Oginga Odinga Science and Technology, and The
East-African branch of UK-based NGO Practical Action), the Institute will devise research programmes as well as training
programmes for local communities, entrepreneurs, craftsmen, engineers, scientists and policymakers.
5. Demonstrating prototypes to local stakeholders. This will encourage communities, entrepreneurs and officials to adopt
and deploy the technology. For this purpose, we will also produce a clear manual and Youtube videos, and the
demonstration of prototypes, both in operation and also in construction, with involvement of local artisans and of
communities seeking to remedy the quality of their borehole water.

Project.Title: improved phosphorus and eutrophication status assessments for humic lakes in light of climate change pressures and departure from eu directive
Project.Description:
Phosphorus is an essential component of most living organisms but it can also cause excessive growth of algae in surface
waters even when it is present at relatively low concentrations (10s of parts per billion). This process is called
eutrophication and it is a problem because costly management plans often need to be actioned to restore the quality of the
water, e.g. to achieve good or high status as currently required under the European Union Water Framework Directive.
Recently, it has been observed that phosphorus concentrations in surface waters, especially lakes in upland, organic-rich
catchments, are increasing and this is being linked to climatic change. Firstly, transport from the surrounding catchment is
being enhanced by increased loss of dissolved organic carbon and phosphorus, which is associated with the organic
carbon via bridging links with iron, is co-transferred to the lake waters. Secondly, internal loading of phosphorus in the lake
bottom sediments is leading to increased concentrations in lake waters because of climatic change. This is because
increased periods of stormy weather leads to greater re-suspension of bottom sediments and transfer of phosphorus from
the near-surface sediment porewaters (the water directly in contact with the sediment). It also occurs because there is
increased stratification even in shallow lakes which are a common feature in many upland, organic-rich areas and this can
mean that poorly oxygenated sediments are in more frequent contact with the bottom lake waters. These conditions are
conducive to transfer of phosphorus from the sediment into the lake water.
Although it is known that soluble reactive phosphorus (orthophosphate) is the main form which can be taken up by the
bloom-forming organisms in the water, total phosphorus is the currently used model parameter to determine water quality.
With total phosphorus concentrations increasing, it is likely that more and more lakes will not achieve the required good or
high status. However, we don't know how much of this additional phosphorus is available to aquatic organisms. For
example, if most of it is unavailable, management plans may be enacted where they are not needed.
From an initial screen of the literature, there is a large body of published information from studies in many parts of the world
and from many different disciplines that needs to be critically evaluated and drawn together to address this knowledge gap.
The main aim of this proposal is to carry out a systematic review of the literature and to draw together evidence that will
improve our understanding of the (i) processes controlling the transport of phosphorus from catchment soil to lake water,
and (ii) how phosphorus is cycled from bottom sediments tot lake water, under the pressure of climate change, in organic
rich regions of the world.
The outcomes of this systematic review of the literature will be to inform future research on how climate change will affect
(i) the forms of phosphorus and its associations with natural organic matter in catchment runoff and lake waters and (ii) the
availability of different forms of phosphorus for uptake by aquatic organisms in highly coloured lakes located in organic-rich
regions of the world. This will ultimately facilitate development of more accurate, climate change-proof models for use in
assessing the phosphorus concentration of lakes in carbon-rich zones will be of tremendous direct benefit to the UK's
environmental regulators (e.g. the Environment Agency, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency) and policy makers
(e.g. DEFRA) and to their equivalent organisations in other countries.

Project.Title: phytofuel: optimization of biofuel production from phytoremediation of contaminated soil
Project.Description:
The objective of PhyToFuel is to set up a harmonized methodology to clean up contaminated soils, producing energy crops
avoiding iLUC and transforming biomass into clean liquid biofuel. The consortium includes partners from Italy, Belgium,
Greece, Spain, Tunisia, Ukraine, United Kingdom. PhyToFuel will also assess and mitigate the short and the long term
environmental risks connected to the preparation of lands for phytoremediation, adopting an all-embracing monitoring
system of the whole process from contaminated land to clean liquid biofuel in two test sites. In this project, pyrolysis is
proposed as a viable option for the treatment of contaminated biomasses given its capability to function as a multiproduct
provider (e.g., biofuels, bulk chemicals, supply of surplus power and heat. A special attention will be given to the
concentration of PTEs in the char, to the reduction of their mobility and to the energy efficiency of the process. According to
a circular economy vision a synergic approach will be adopted coupling the phytoremediation practice and the biofuel
production to the valorization of each material flux through the production of energy and materials that may be used in
assisting the different steps of the whole production chain. An integrated qualitative and quantitative framework, namely
Quantitative Story Telling, will be adopted to evaluate environmental, technical and socio-economic performance of the
phytoremediation-feedstock-transformation chain and the overall sustainability of this complex metabolic system. To reach
the ambitions and expected impact of the PhyToFuel project a plan of communication & dissemination, as well as
exploitation of the activities results will be set up. This plan will be strictly linked to the activity of exploitation of PhyToFuel,
seeking to generate knowledge outside academic environments to the benefit of the social, cultural and economic
development.

Project.Title: biofuels production from lignocellulosic biomass via supercritical technologies
Project.Description:
Biomass is one of the most promising sources for the production of renewable fuels and chemicals. However, the
commercial technology to convert these feedstocks to fuels and chemicals are very few. Biomass usually contains
water since the drying process is energy-intensive; the super critical water (SCW) gasification is a promising
technology for biomass with high moisture contents. Bio-oil is made by biomass pyrolysis. Bio-oils can also be
processed to produce value added chemicals. One of such potential chemical is phenol (phenols, substituted
phenols and their derivatives), which normally comes as lignin degradation product during flash pyrolysis. These
phenols are most promising alternative to petro-derived phenols which find huge market in resin, composite
wood and laminate industry. The supercritical CO2 extraction emerges as a new technology for natural phenols,
which has advantage over traditional solvent extraction process by eliminating the polluting organic solvents.
Supercritical fluid processing of biomass to chemicals represents an alternative path to enzymatic hydrolysis of
cellulose to sugars or thermo-chemical gasification process. The major focus of the research work is to develop
the following technologies: I) Conversion of biomass to value added chemicals such as fermentable sugars
specifically glucose or fuel gas such as methane using supercritical water and its further conversion to ethanol,
and II) Extraction of the phenolic fractions from bio-oil using supercritical carbon dioxide. The major goal of the
proposed research work is to develop an integrated process for the complete conversion of biomass to ethanol
and phenols using supercritical technology. The long term goal of the present research is to develop an
integrated process for complete utilization of biomass for the production of chemicals and fuels using
supercritical fluid techniques. It is expected that this new lignocellulosic biomass technology will enable the
development of bio-refineries which will produce value added chemicals together with biofuels.

Project.Title: optimisation of wave energy converters: a joint geometry and energy-maximising control approach
Project.Description:
Wave energy technologies with the potential to be progressed up to market entry, achieving a competitive levelised cost of energy, need to be identified. To determine the most promising technologies, it is key to be able to explore the design space at early stages to avoid expensive design-build-test iterations later on. This can be done with the help of improved tools for early stage design and optimisation of Wave Energy Converters (WECs). This project aims to combine a flexible geometry optimisation tool with a moment-based constrained optimal control mathematical framework (able to maximise power extraction from ocean waves), so that the WEC hull geometry and the control system can be optimised simultaneously and a wide range of innovative solutions can be generated. This methodology not only allows for a better representation of the system dynamics including device limitations, such as stroke, velocity and PTO-force constraints, but given the computational efficiency of the moment-based control strategy, this energy-maximising framework is suitable for joint geometry and control optimisation. More realistic optimisation
results will be generated with this method, which will aid technology developers to improve their WEC designs at the early stages, and funding bodies to assess current designs and their potential for
improvement with respect to the theoretical optima.

Project.Title: modeling and integrating of wave energy con-verters with forecasting systems (waves)
Project.Description: The design of electrical grids is a challenging task that requires raising the level of abstrac-tion of its elements to overcome complexity. Grid design efficiency does not only depend on its elements but also on the nature of the surrounding climate. Therefore, data forecast models for wave, wind and weather should be integrated with the renewable energy source models to forecast the amount of energy which will be produced and transmitted to the grid. Modeling languages and semantic specification are necessary to address grid specifications at this level of the abstraction. In order to verify the grid design models and reach real grid implementation, code generation is needed for simulation and performance analysis of the designed models and also to support the grid developers to try different types of grid ele-ments and test them at different locations. Therefore, there is a need for a framework which integrates grid elements with climate forecast models, supports the exploration of different types of renewable resources and locations, and provides performance analysis of such re-sources.

Project.Title: sustainable integration of wave energy in the aa economy through synergies with maritime activities
Project.Description:
Resource efficiency
2.1. Fostering renewable energies and energy efficiency
Technology transfer and university-enterprise cooperation, Renewable energy: marine

Wave energy is called upon to play a role in the European energy mix but
significant obstacles still exist. SIWEIS will foster wave energy growth through
integration with other maritime uses (transport, energy, aquaculture). Using
Blue Economy priority sectors, 5 main obstacles will be addressed: reliability;
survivability; sustainability; LCOE and environmental integration. The main
outputs will be a GIS tool and an integrated strategy to leverage wave energy
under a transnational approach.

The aim of this project is to achieve sustainable integration of wave energy
into the AA economy by means of innovative synergies with other maritime
activities (transport, energy, aquaculture & support services). Wave
energy is one of the most promising marine renewable resources and one
of the Blue Growth Priorities. Almost 45% of wave energy developers are
European and a new, homegrown industrial sector is emerging. However, the
wave energy sector is at a crucial stage where cost and risk reduction are
needed in order to attract investors. The overarching objective of SIWEIS is
to develop an integrated AA strategy to accelerate wave energy development
from basic research to demonstration projects, through the integration of wave
energy converters with existing and mature maritime economic activities.
Three specific objectives will be addressed: (1) identify synergies between
wave energy and other maritime activities and classify the AA potential
for a multiuse maritime space approach; (2) cluster wave energy resource
availability, focusing on met-ocean conditions, socio-economic benefits and
synergies with other uses; (3) identify the most relevant technological needs
for wave energy developers in the AA in order to maximize the rate of success
and minimize risks/costs of demonstration projects. The results obtained
from SIWEIS will impact on the current situation by characterizing the socioeconomic
impact of wave energy development and integration in the AA.

Project.Title: aowec - array optimisation of wave energy converters
Project.Description:
Wave energy converters, electrical architecture, adding value, minimizing LCOE, optimised grid architecture, array layout, cost assessment

Needs addressed
The primary challenge for the wave energy sector is to develop a technology that can efficiently convert ocean energy resources at a competitive Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE). This begins with the engineering challenges at the prototype stage. However, this cost competitiveness needs to follow through the Technology Readiness Levels (TRLs) to commercial-scale projects. In recent years, developers have largely focused on improving conversion efficiency, both mechanical and electrical. However, lack of standard marine electrical architecture for the next stage of development has led to only limited improvements in array electrical systems. In the case of wave energy devices, this issue has a significant impact when it comes to defining the devices internal electrical design and electrical network, as Wave Energy Converters (WECs) need to demonstrate efficient and economically feasible concepts that can be easily integrated into offshore networks.
State of the art
Previous studies have analysed various network architectures for ocean energy systems. However only a few studies detail the expected Capital Expenditures (CAPEX) and Operating Expenditures (OPEX) of proposed solutions. The works that specify potential CAPEX and OPEX outlays do not give ocean energy developers the information necessary to optimise device, array and transmission level electrical architectures.
Project goals
The first goal of this project is to define an optimal high-level Wave Energy Converter (WEC) internal electrical architecture aimed at minimising LCOE. The second, and primary goal of the project, is to study preferred, optimised array electrical architectures for sub-10MW and early commercial arrays. By considering both electrical design stages at such an early stage of development the project will provide a unique opportunity to investigate the trade-offs within a coordinated design process of a commercial scale WEC array.
At both WEC and array levels, the proposed architectures will use available technologies, where possible, to ensure cost-effectiveness and accessibility to the widest range of developers. The European Marine Energy Centre (EMEC) wave test site will be used as a case study for design, which will allow an early stage assessment of future early commercial arrays to be developed. This will provide a clear guidance for the development of future WEC prototypes and early commercial systems, in order to maximize performance and value, whilst minimizing complexity and technical risk, at each stage of development and deployment.

Project approach
The consortium will approach the work by initially focussing on the CorPower (CPO) WEC; both at a WEC and an array level. All electrical analysis will be performed using commercially available software and CPO’s architecture will be compared to known alternatives using LCOE as the comparison metric. The proposed architectures will use existing and available technologies, where possible, to ensure cost effectiveness and accessibility to the widest range of developers. This approach will also de-risk the technologies for other developers.
A case study will be formulated for an array of CPO devices deployed at the EMEC. This approach is being taken due to the availability of both CPO and EMEC operational data. The operational data will calibrate and validate the models used in the analysis of the various architectures.
Expected results and impacts
This work is intended to build upon existing studies and guidelines to allow ocean energy developers, and more specifically wave energy developers, to make informed decisions regarding system electrical architectures. This work will allow developers to improve their integration with the electrical grid. Thus, guiding them toward a better and faster insertion into the European and global electricity market.

Project.Title: business case selection for wave energy technologies
Project.Description:
Needs addressed
Wave energy converter (WEC) technology is not yet sufficiently developed enough to achieve acceptable techno-economic performance or commercial applicability, both of which are required if WECs are to become economically viable. 
State of art
Based on discussions with industry experts, it is estimated that individual companies need to invest in the order of £50 million over five years to bring a WEC from being proven at part-scale to demonstration at full-scale. A key obstacle is pre-commercial technology finance, particularly funding to support device and component developers in the middle ground from the key TRL 3 and upwards stages (to TRL6) in the evolution of their projects. 
Some floating wind technologies are, nowadays, in demonstration phases achieving a TRL 7-8, taking advantage of the success of offshore wind which is achieving an energy cost of around 10 pence per kWh. It may be shared in order to reduce the final cost of WEC implementation the synergies between WEC technology and other marine technologies which are already in demonstration phase.
Planned goals
This project will investigate the business models currently in use by WEC technology developers and will propose revised models aimed at leveraging greater funding and reducing investor risk. 
Furthermore, it has become apparent that the implementation of new funding strategies is crucial if investor confidence in the sector is to be improved.  Large investors with significant backing, from both the public and private sectors, need to be engaged from the outset to provide confidence that projects will survive.  One such investment model involves innovative public acquisition, whereby a research centre is funded to select a WEC technology from the market and work to validate it.  Private sector acquisition would follow the validation phase and a developer would take ownership of the technology in order to implement it in a commercial setting.
The project will be focused on addressing three main targets:
a.	The lessons learnt from other successful marine energy sectors business models which could provide beneficial if transferred to WEC technology developers will be investigated.  
b.	Aspects of the technology development process which exhibit the greatest potential for cost reduction and best practices will be analysed, with particular focus on operations and maintenance activities. 
c.	Finally, innovative financial mechanisms involving public and private agents for WEC technology will be proposed.
Expected results
1.      New Business Models for WEC Developers: New insights that help to overcome the current obstacles, especially, related to pre-commercial technology finance.
2.      WEC Roadmap, coupled to the current floating wind & MuP demonstration projects, in order to take advantage of their momentum and obtain mutual benefits.
3.      New and innovative financial tools to enhance WEC demonstration projects, achieving public support and private commitment.
Potential impact
The ultimate impact of the proposed project will be to accelerate the commercialisation of wave energy technologies. This will entail bringing the cost and reliability, amongst other aspects, of wave technologies to a level where they are able to compete with alternatives such as floating wind.
Our project will offer a new pathway to accelerate the WEC technology through an in-depth analysis of other MER business models, technical synergies and new financial tools. First stage will be to achieve TRL-6 (WEC demonstration project) coupled with some floating wind or MuP project.

Project.Title: retrofitting scotland’s buildings: constructing a method for investigating the role of sub-contracting supply chains and delivery partners
Project.Description:
The UK has some of the poorest energy performing buildings in Europe; which contribute to high rates of fuel poverty and excessive greenhouse gas emissions. In Scotland, this challenge is being tackled through a national-scale energy retrofitting scheme: Scotland’s Energy Efficiency Programme (SEEP). This Programme is a long-term infrastructure priority over the next 15-20 years. The success of SEEP is reliant on the coordination and activities of supply chains including Local Authorities, intermediary organisations and contractors. Despite this, little is known about the way that complex sub-contracting chains take shape around retrofit projects, or the experiences of those involved in
delivering such schemes. Focusing on SEEP, this pilot project will investigate the formation and management of complex supply chains in large scale energy retrofitting.

Project.Title: ukccsrc - the united kingdom carbon capture and storage research centre
Project.Description:
The UKCCSRC is a national UK research hub for Carbon Capture and Storage with three main priorities:

Delivering Research Impact Developing Leaders Shaping Capability

Strategy - The UKCCSRC will bring strategy to UK academic CCS research in support of government targets.

Impact - will be maximised by providing a national focal point for CCS R&D to bring together the user community and

academics to analyse problems, devise and carry out world-leading research and share delivery. A key priority will be to

help rebuild the UK economy by driving an integrated research programme focused on maximising the contribution of CCS

to a low-carbon energy system for UK.

Research will be linked to the following pathways to impact in future stages of CCS deployment:

a) Maximise the learning from the DECC CCS demonstration programme to reduce costs and risks for subsequent CCS

projects to.

b) Develop a knowledge base for rollout of CCS as part of UK electricity sector decarbonisation in the 2020s, including for

the life of this CCS infrastructure until 2050 and beyond.

c) Prepare for extensive deployment of CCS to meet UK 2050 targets, including CCS on industry, very low residual

emissions from CCS on fossil fuels and negative emissions from biomass with CCS.

Leaders - The UKCCSRC will cross institutional and disciplinary boundaries to bring together visionary leaders able to set

research agendas that fully combine the intersecting fields of knowledge required to maximise the potential of CCS,

inspirational team leaders for complex, long-term research programmes, and will also provide leadership development

opportunities for early- and mid-career researchers.

Capability - The UK CCS Research Centre will provide CCS researchers with the space, support and opportunities to foster

creativity and to empower them to deliver the highest quality long-term research in CCS areas where there is current or

future national need.

The activities of the UKCCSRC will be overseen by a broadly-based independent Board, reporting to RCUK and other

funders. A Management Team made up of the Principal Investigator/Director and eight Co-Investigators plus a Secretariat

will be responsible for running the Centre. Nine additional Research Area Champions will also help cover the wide range of

different specialised knowledge fields involved in implementing CCS systems.

The existing UK CCS Community Network will be operated by the Centre, giving a fully inclusive forum for UK CCS

stakeholders and a route for all UK academics to engage with the UKCCSRC.

The UKCCSRC initial funding supports a core research programme (£3M) that covers a number of evident gaps in existing

research and also includes scoping research in areas likely to be of strategic importance. It also funds shared national

facilities (£2M plus £2.9M from DECC). A further £1.5M has been set aside for flexible seed funding to be allocated on a

competitive basis for emerging strategic research needs.

Academic Beneficiaries

Describe who will benefit from the research [up to 4000 chars].

The Centre will be expanded by a number of routes:

a) Academic researchers on existing and new CCS projects will be invited to link these to the Centre.

b) Non-academic partners in projects that are linked to the Centre may become UKCCSRC Affiliates

c) Additional funding for UKCCSRC research programmes will be sought from RCUK and other UK and international

government-funded sources and also from industry.

Research and Pathways to Impact Delivery (RAPID)

The key overall strategy for future UKCCSRC expansion is to couple research with impact from the outset. Proposed

research will have to be linked to plausible routes to deliver a positive impact for CCS deployment. The RAPID process will

run throughout the course of the UKCCSRC with results summarised in a RAPID Handbook, updated yearly.

Project.Title: nmdeveloping new modelling capabilities of regenerative heat exchanges for low temperature applications in carbon capture
Project.Description:
The objective of this project is to further develop new engineering options to reduce water usage in carbon capture systems for power generation, steelworks, oil refineries, cement plants with regenerative heat exchanger technology. A 9 month secondment within the Howden Group will allow developing new software tools to evaluate performance and size rotary heat exchanger products for carbon capture. Specific challenges include low temperature operation (30 – 100 ºC) and the condensation and evaporation of water within the wheel, as opposed to high temperature operation at 150-350 ºC for coal-fired power plant applications where water behaves as vapour. This requires adding to the existing software code a stand-alone model using engineering principles, which the secondee acquired during her PhD studies at Edinburgh University. 

The proposed work plan consists of: 
• Gain a deep understanding of the fundamental principles and the source code of Howden’s proprietary software used for performance analysis and sizing. 
• Fully identify the new expected operational conditions when rotary heat exchangers are implemented in carbon capture systems covering a wide range of operation temperatures. 
• Assess the effects/implications of a low temperature application on the rotary heat exchangers performance and sizing 
• Provide detailed technical description of all the phenomena involved (e.g. water condensation, water evaporation) and a technical report to enable Howden’s program modifications. 
• Develop a stand-alone simplified model of the rotary heat exchangers including the water condensation/evaporation phenomena taking place at low temperature. 


Upon completion of the project, a first important step towards rolling out a new tool for sizing of equipment in carbon capture applications to Howden’s engineering teams will have been completed. The following phase, beyond this project, would consist of continuing the roll out within the company to the commercial teams.

Project.Title: socio-ecological dynamics of infectious disease at the livestock-human-wildlife interface.
Project.Description:
Wildlife diseases affect livestock, hunting, and conservation interests and involve
anthropogenic decisions that affect and are affected by disease transmission and associated risks. These
coupled systems generally involve multiple hosts distributed over geographically and socioeconomically
heterogeneous landscapes. These complexities create many challenges for resource managers tasked with
constructing coherent, cost-effective and workable disease control strategies. Our proposed research is
designed to address these challenges by investigating the overarching research question "How do the
spatio-temporal dynamics of infectious disease transmission interact with human risk responses to
influence risk-management decisions for complex disease networks that bridge natural and managed
landscapes?".Specifically, our cross-disciplinary team will investigate: (i) how animal and land use
management decisions over geographically and socioeconomically heterogeneous landscapes create or
mitigate disease risks to wildlife and livestock, and how these effects and associated risk-management
opportunities differ across landscapes and from those in aspatial settings; (ii) the natural cross-system
"communities" that influence decision-making and control; (iii) the important socioeconomic-ecological
tradeoffs for managing disease risks in complex spatial networks with different characteristics, and how
targeted management strategies might be developed to reflect these tradeoffs. Conceptually, we will
develop a spatial, "multiscale socioeconomic-ecological multi-layer network" framework to understand
the epidemiological, population, and behavioral dynamic interactive feedbacks among the economic and
ecological subsystems. Using bioeconomic modeling and adaptive management approaches, we will
examine cost-effective management in this complex setting. Further insights will be gained via two case
studies: (a) bovine tuberculosis in Michigan deer and cattle; (b) brucellosis in Greater Yellowstone Area
(GYA) elk and cattle along with potential chronic wasting disease in GYA elk
Sponsor.Name: national science foundation
Scheme.Name: general scheme
PI.Name: Rowland Kao
Name_of_Call: CNH2: Dynamics of Integrated Socio-Environmental Systems

Project.Title: us-uk collab: integration of epidemiology and social science for better wildlife and farm management of a multi-host pathogen
Project.Description:
In this proposal, we shall address the critical question of integrating social science and economic perspectives into
quantitative models applied to real-life problems of infectious disease management in livestock and wildlife. We shall
exploit two exceptionally well-described systems (Michigan USA, and Great Britain) where bovine Tuberculosis (bTB) has a
substantial and long term cost to individuals in affected areas and to the broader public and where there are well
documented, dynamic tensions between the priorities of different stakeholders.
In Michigan, we shall consider the joint ecological and epidemiological problem of deer population management and cattle
Tb prevention in the context of the hunting and farming communities, where attempts to encourage hunters to engage in
deer population control have had mixed success, and risk mitigation interventions have great potential but the challenge
lies in farmers modifying their husbandry practices and behaviours.
In GB, we shall identify differences in the dynamic network of livestock movements when comparing Scotland to the Low
Risk Area (LRA) in England, and develop new estimates of the risk of acquiring bTB over those networks. By integrating
knowledge of risk perception into models of disease spread, we shall determine whether known differences in risk in
comparing Scotland to the LRA are due to epidemiological or farmer decision-making factors.
We shall (i) exploit exceptional, dense datasets in both these systems that describe both the host populations and disease
in order to estimate the benefits of adherence to good biosecurity practice, and (in Michigan) good wildlife management
practice and (ii) generate new data describing the social context of infectious disease spread. Integrating these data, we
shall synthesize a novel analytical framework via a suite of mathematical, agent-based simulation and network models in
order to (i) evaluate and optimise potential control strategies that account for epidemiological risk, human behaviour and
socio-economic context, (ii) test them in the context of the detailed agent-based simulations, and (iii) translate the agentbased
models to more generalised network models, facilitating further comparison and extension to other systems.

Project.Title: biocompatible and biodegradable monodisperse zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (zif-8) nanoparticles for efficient and safe nanomedicine
Project.Description:
ZIF-8 possesses high surface area and natural biodegradability and is very
suitable for drug delivery. However, the size of ZIF-8 nanoparticles cannot be
freely tuned in the range of below 200 nm, a desirable dimension for drug delivery,
and the surface is short of functional groups for anchoring drug molecules and
targeting ligands. To address these, the following will be performed.

(1) Synthesize size tunable ZIF-8 nanoparticles by using templates (e.g., poly
(acrylic acid sodium salt)). The templates will also provide functional groups (e.g.,
-COOH) on the surface of the nanoparticles. To prepare monodisperse
nanoparticles, I will make use of microfluidic reactor for nanocrystal synthesis.
Different reactants will be precisely injected into the reactor through Asia pump. 

(2) Conjugate drug molecules (e.g., siRNA, DNA, and methotrexate) and targeting
ligands (e.g., folic acid and peptide) to ZIF-8 nanoparticles through covalent bonds
such as peptide bond using EDC chemistry.

(3) Explore the kinetics of drug release and the degradation of the nanomedicine in
phosphate-buffered saline.

The morphology, size, structure and surface of the nanomaterial and the release
and degradation kinetics of the nanomedicine will be investigated through
characterization techniques including SEM, TEM, XRD, FTIR, NMR, XPS,
electrophoresis, UV-Vis absorption, and fluorescence spectroscopy.
